Ugh. Okay. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. People always want to know this, like it's some big mystery. It wasn't a mystery to *me*. It was just…the only sensible thing to do.

Look, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted for the rest of my life. I was failing band, I was obsessed with mixtapes, and I was pretty sure my biggest problem was whether or not to go to the Snowball.

And then…there was a baby.

It wasn't that I didn't want the baby, exactly. It was that I knew I couldn't *give* the baby what it deserved. I wasn't ready. I didn't have a job, I didn't have a stable home, and my parents were…well, they were my parents. They'd support me, sure, but it wouldn't be ideal.

Mark, the dad…he was a good guy, but he was leaving for college. He wasn't ready to be a dad either. We both knew that.

So, I started thinking about adoption. And it just…made sense. It meant the baby would have parents who were prepared, who could give it everything it needed. A real home, a real family.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. But it wasn't about me. It was about the baby. I wanted the best for it, even if that meant letting it go.

Vanessa and Mark, they were amazing. They were so excited, so ready. And knowing that they would love and care for the baby…that made it a little bit easier.

It wasn't a glamorous decision. It wasn't a sad movie moment. It was just…practical. And it was the right thing to do. For everyone.

And honestly? It made me grow up. A lot. It forced me to think about things I never would have thought about before. And it made me realize that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is let go.

Ugh, okay, so like, love and responsibility. Big topics. And honestly, I started out knowing pretty much *nothing* about either one. I thought love was just, you know, butterflies and holding hands and making out in the back of a car. And responsibility? That was something my parents nagged me about.

But then, suddenly, I'm pregnant. And everything changes.

I learned that love isn't just about *feeling* something. It's about *doing* something. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. It's about wanting the best for them, even if it means letting them go. That's what Mark and Vanessa showed me. They weren't perfect, but they genuinely wanted to give this baby a good life, and they were willing to work for it. It wasn't some grand romantic gesture, it was just…consistent kindness and commitment.

And responsibility? That's not just about doing your chores or getting good grades. It's about facing the consequences of your actions. It's about owning up to your mistakes. It's about making hard choices, even when they suck. I had to decide what was best for this baby, and that meant giving it up. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was the right thing to do.

I also learned that love comes in all shapes and sizes. It's not just romantic love. It's the love between friends, the love between family members, the love between a couple who are building a life together. Paul showed me that. He wasn't the baby's father, but he was there for me, unconditionally. He didn't judge me, he just supported me.

And finally, I learned that growing up isn't about having all the answers. It's about learning to ask the right questions. It's about being open to new experiences. It's about figuring out who you are and what you want out of life. And it's okay to be a little bit messy along the way.

So yeah, love and responsibility. They're complicated. But they're also pretty amazing. And I'm still figuring it all out, one awkward conversation at a time.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…reflective? Fine. But don't expect a heartfelt monologue, alright? I'm not exactly known for my emotional vulnerability.

Look, when you find out you're pregnant at sixteen, it's…a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. And everyone has an opinion. And everyone's looking at you. And suddenly, your life is not your own anymore. It's kinda terrifying.

So, I started using humor. It was a defense mechanism, honestly. If I could make a joke about it, it felt…less scary. It felt like I had some control. Like I wasn't just a victim of circumstance.

It was also a way to deflect. If people asked awkward questions, or gave me pitying looks, I'd just crack a joke. It threw them off balance. It made *me* feel less vulnerable. It was like, "Yeah, this is weird, but I can handle it. Don't feel sorry for me."

And honestly, it helped me connect with people. Paul and Vanessa, they got my humor. They didn't treat me like I was fragile or broken. They just…laughed with me. And that was huge.

It wasn't about making light of the situation, exactly. It was about finding the absurdity in it. Because sometimes, life is just absurd. And if you can't laugh at it, you'll just cry.

Plus, it's just…me. I've always been sarcastic. It's how I process the world. It's how I make sense of things. So, even when everything was falling apart, I couldn't just turn that off.

So yeah, my wit helped me cope. It was my shield, my weapon, and my way of staying sane. It didn't solve all my problems, but it made them a little bit easier to bear. And it reminded me that even in the darkest of times, there's always room for a little bit of humor. Even if it's just a little bit twisted.

Ugh, okay, deep questions. You want the real stuff, huh? Fine. It wasn't all witty banter and sarcastic comments, you know? Underneath all that, I was…a mess. A confused, kinda scared mess.

My vulnerability, that was the whole thing, wasn't it? I pretended to be all tough and independent, but really, I was just trying to figure out who I was *without* being defined by this…situation. Being pregnant wasn't part of the plan. It wasn't who I thought I was going to be. And suddenly, everyone had an opinion on who I *should* be.

I was scared, obviously. Scared of everything. Scared of being a mom, scared of giving the baby up, scared of what people would think. And I didn't really have anyone to talk to about it, not really. My mom was great, but she had her own stuff going on. And Paul…well, Paul was Paul. Sweet, but not exactly equipped to handle a teenage pregnancy.

So I built up these walls, you know? The sarcasm, the quick comebacks, the whole "I'm fine" act. It was a defense mechanism. But it also kept me from really connecting with people, from letting them see the real me.

The search for identity…that was constant. I was trying to figure out who I was *outside* of being pregnant. Was I still Juno? Was I still the girl who loved music and vintage clothes and making Super 8 films? Or was I just…a mom now?

It was through the process of finding a family for the baby that I started to figure things out. Meeting Mark and Vanessa, seeing how much they wanted a child, it made me realize that giving the baby up wasn't a failure. It was an act of love. And it allowed me to reclaim my own life, to pursue my own dreams.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears, a lot of doubts, a lot of awkward conversations. But ultimately, my vulnerability and my search for identity forced me to grow up. They forced me to confront my fears and to make some really tough decisions. And they led me to a place where I could finally be okay with who I was, even if I didn't have all the answers.

It's still a work in progress, you know? I'm still figuring things out. But I'm learning to embrace the messiness of life, and to be okay with not having everything figured out. And that, I think, is a pretty good place to be.

Ugh, okay, so people always wanna talk about the "strength" thing. Like I just magically woke up one day and was all, "Yep, I got this." It wasn't like that. Not even close. It was…messy. And honestly, I couldn't have done any of it without a few key people.

My dad, Paul, he was…surprisingly cool about everything. He didn't freak out, he didn't judge. He just kinda listened, and then he started building a crib. Which, you know, was a pretty solid way of showing support. He didn't try to fix things, he just tried to be there. And that meant a lot.

And then there was Bren, my best friend. She was the one who made me laugh when I wanted to cry. She was the one who went with me to the doctor's appointments and didn't flinch. She was the one who reminded me that I was still *me*, even with a whole baby situation going on. She didn't sugarcoat anything, but she always had my back.

And then there was Vanessa, Mark's wife. She was…unexpectedly awesome. I thought she'd be all judgy and weird, but she was really understanding. She helped me pick out baby stuff and gave me advice about…well, everything. She showed me that it was okay to be scared, and that it was okay to ask for help.

See, before all this, I was kinda…independent. I liked doing things my own way. I didn't really *need* anyone. But this…this was different. This was bigger than me. And I realized that I couldn't do it alone.

Their support didn't mean they told me what to do. They didn't try to convince me to keep the baby or give it up. They just listened to me, and they helped me figure out what *I* wanted. They gave me the space to make my own decision, and they supported me no matter what.

It was their belief in me, even when I didn't believe in myself, that gave me the strength to go through with it. It was their love and acceptance that helped me realize that I was capable of more than I thought.

So yeah, they were pretty important. They weren't just people around me, they were my lifeline. And I wouldn't have gotten through it without them. It's kinda cheesy to say, but it's true.

It wasn't a happy moment. It was scary and confusing and overwhelming. But it also…made me think. It made me realize that life is complicated, and sometimes things happen that you don't expect. And you just have to deal with them.

It wasn't ideal, not even close. But it wasn't the end of the world either. It just…was. And I had to figure out what "was" meant for me.

It's hard to explain. It was a lot. A really, really lot. And honestly, I still think about it sometimes. It changed everything.

It wasn't easy, but it definitely made me appreciate the people in my life. And it taught me a lot about myself, too. Like, I'm stronger than I thought I was. And I can handle anything, as long as I have good people by my side.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like stumbling through a minefield while trying to balance a stack of books.

My dad was…tough. He was mad, obviously. But he also came around. He saw I was trying to do the right thing, even if it wasn't the easiest thing.

Bleeker… he's… complicated. At first, he was just…there. Kind of a dork. Always with the guitar. I thought he was sweet, I guess, but mostly just… oblivious. Like he didn't even *see* me, you know? Just saw a person. Which, honestly, was kinda refreshing.

Ugh, okay, here we go. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. People always ask this, like it was some easy decision. It wasn't. It was the hardest thing I've ever done.

Look, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted for the rest of my life. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give up my life, my school, my…everything.

Mark, the dad, he wasn't exactly stepping up. He had his own stuff going on, and honestly, he wasn't ready either. It wouldn't have been fair to anyone.

So, I started thinking about adoption. And it just…felt right. It meant I could give my baby to a family who was ready and able to give it everything it needed. A stable home, financial security, two parents who were excited to be parents.

It wasn't about giving it *away*. It was about choosing a family for it. It was about wanting the best for my kid, even if that meant I wasn't the one raising it.

It was a really hard decision, and I cried a lot. But I knew it was the right one. And honestly, seeing Vanessa and Mark with the baby…it made it a little easier. Knowing that my kid was loved and wanted and safe.

It still stings sometimes, you know? But I don't regret it. It was the most selfless thing I've ever done. And I think, in the end, it was the best thing for everyone involved.

It's complicated. It's not a happy story, exactly. But it's *my* story. And I'm okay with it. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a moment. A really big, messy, complicated moment. It wasn't like in the movies, all dramatic and tearful. It was mostly just awkward. And a lot of staring at the floor.

I mean, Bleeker's Bleeker, you know? Sweet, kinda clueless, always with the guitar. He's a good kid, but he's not exactly equipped to handle, like, *life*. And definitely not a pregnant sixteen-year-old.

And he just…froze. Like a deer in headlights. His face went all pale and his eyes got really wide. He didn't say anything for a solid minute. Just stared at me. It was excruciating.

Honestly, I was bracing for the worst. I thought he'd freak out. Run away. Tell everyone. But he didn't. He just…looked really sad. And confused.

Then he asked, like, five questions at once, all jumbled together. "Are you sure?" "What are you going to do?" "Is it mine?" (That one was kinda obvious, but still.)

I felt…relieved, actually. That he didn't yell. But also, really scared. Because I knew, in that moment, that things were never going to be the same. Not for me, and not for him.

It wasn't a happy moment. It was a turning point. A really scary, really real turning point. And it was the beginning of a lot of hard decisions.

I think, mostly, I just felt…alone. Even with him sitting right there. Because it was my decision, ultimately. And I had to figure out what to do, even if it meant hurting him. Or myself.

So I end up being the one who reads the instructions, makes sure we have all the materials, and gently (or not so gently) steers everyone in the right direction. I'm basically a lab manager. A very sarcastic lab manager.

I'm good at spotting when someone's about to do something incredibly stupid and stopping them before it blows up in our faces. Which happens a lot.

And I'm surprisingly good at writing up the lab reports. I can make even the most boring experiment sound interesting. Mostly because I add a lot of witty commentary.

So yeah, I'm the one who keeps the whole operation from falling apart. I'm the responsible one. Which is ironic, considering my current situation. But hey, at least I can follow instructions. Most of the time.

Ugh. Okay. That ad. Yeah. I saw it. It was…subtle. Like, *trying* to be subtle. All pastel colors and vague promises about “compassionate care.” Right.

It just felt…icky. Like they were trying to sell something, you know? And not something you just casually browse for at the mall. It's a really big decision, and they're making it sound like picking out a new pair of shoes. "Oh, this one's a little more supportive! This one comes in beige!"

And the wording. "All options considered." Yeah, right. They're not exactly advertising adoption, are they? It's all about *their* services. It's like they're trying to make you feel like it's the easiest thing in the world, and it's not. It's…complicated.

I mean, I get it. They're a business. They need to advertise. But it just feels…exploitative. Like they're preying on girls who are scared and confused.

It just makes me feel…protective, I guess. Of other girls who might see that ad and feel like they don't have any other choices. Because they do. There are other options. And it's okay to be scared and confused. And it's okay to ask for help.

It just…ugh. It's a lot. It just makes me want to roll my eyes and listen to The Moldy Peaches really loud. It's just…gross.

Ugh, seriously? You're still hung up on the hamburger phone? It's been, like, years. Okay, fine. I'll explain. But don't judge.

It wasn't about, like, making a *statement* or anything. It wasn't some deep, artistic expression. It was mostly just…because it was there. And it was hilarious.

Paul, he works at a pawn shop, right? And he found it. A fully functional, bright red hamburger phone. It was just sitting there, looking ridiculous. And I thought, "Well, that's perfect."

It just felt…right. It was a little bit rebellious, a little bit silly, and a lot bit *me*. I mean, I wasn't exactly going for sophisticated. I was a pregnant teenager trying to figure out her life. A hamburger phone felt appropriate.

Plus, it got a reaction. People stared. They laughed. It was a good conversation starter. And honestly, when you're dealing with something as heavy as giving a baby up for adoption, sometimes you just need a little bit of levity.

It was a way to remind myself not to take everything so seriously. To find the humor in the chaos. And to embrace my own weirdness.

So yeah, I used a hamburger phone. Don't overthink it. It was just a phone. Shaped like a hamburger. And it made me smile. And sometimes, that's all that matters.

Ugh. Okay. Here we go. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. People always want to know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I, at sixteen, could not give that to her. I mean, seriously. I was still in high school. I was obsessed with mixtapes and vintage clothes and avoiding my dad. I wasn't exactly equipped to raise a human being.

My parents were…supportive, in their own way. But they were also kinda checked out. And I didn't want to be a burden. I didn't want to ruin their lives, or mine.

Mark, the baby's dad, he was…sweet. But he was also going to college and had his own life to figure out. We weren't exactly relationship material.

So, I started thinking about adoption. And it just…felt right. It wasn't giving up, it was giving *her* a better life. A life with parents who were ready and excited and financially stable. A life with opportunities I couldn't provide.

Vanessa and Mark, they were amazing. They were…normal. They wanted a baby so badly. And they promised to love her and give her everything she needed.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. Seriously. But I knew it was the right thing. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby.

And honestly? It was kinda empowering. To make that decision, to take control of my life, and to choose a future for her that was brighter than anything I could offer.

It still stings sometimes. But I don't regret it. Not one bit. She deserves the world, and I wanted to give her that. Even if it meant letting her go.



It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple story. And it's not something I talk about a lot. But you asked. And I figured, you deserved an honest answer.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like it was one single thing, you know? It was a whole mess of stuff. But yeah, my family definitely played a part in my decision.

My mom, Bren, she's amazing. Seriously. She's, like, the most supportive person ever. But she's also…a little bit spacey. And she's had her own stuff to deal with, you know? She's been through a lot. I didn't want to add to that. I didn't want to completely derail her life. She was finally getting things together, and a baby…well, that would have been a lot.

And my dad, Mac, he's…Mac. He means well, but he's kinda clueless sometimes. He was trying to be supportive, but he kept making these awkward jokes and offering to buy me a minivan. It was just…not helpful. I knew he wouldn't *understand* what I was going through. He's a good guy, but he's not exactly known for his emotional intelligence.

But it wasn't just about them. It was about me, too. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I was sixteen! I was still trying to figure out who *I* was, let alone raise a human being. I had my own dreams, my own plans. I wanted to go to college, I wanted to write, I wanted to…just *live* my life.

I knew I could give the baby a good life, but I also knew that I couldn't give it the *best* life. Mark and Vanessa, they were perfect. They were stable, they were loving, they were ready. They could give the baby everything I couldn't.

So, yeah, my family…they weren't the reason I chose adoption, but they definitely influenced my decision. I wanted to protect them, and I wanted to protect myself. And ultimately, I wanted to do what was best for the baby. It wasn't an easy decision, but it was the right one.

It's complicated, okay? Don't make me explain it again.

Ugh, okay, the adoption process. Don't even get me started. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like, a heartwarming movie montage with puppies and rainbows. It was…complicated.

The biggest challenge, honestly, was just…feeling like everything was happening *to* me, not *with* me. Like, suddenly everyone had an opinion on what was best for this kid, and for me, and it was exhausting. My parents were supportive, but they were also, like, worried and trying to be helpful, which sometimes felt the same thing.

Then there were the potential adoptive parents. Meeting them was…weird. It felt like I was being interviewed, and they were interviewing me, and the baby wasn't even *born* yet. It was like, "Are you good enough? Are you responsible enough? Are you worthy of raising this child?" It was a lot of pressure.

And there was this whole thing with Mark and Vanessa, the couple who ended up adopting him. They were…perfect. Like, ridiculously perfect. And I kept thinking, "What if they change their minds? What if they decide I'm not stable enough?" It was stupid, I know, but I couldn't help it.

There was also the emotional stuff. Like, realizing that I was actually going to give this baby up. It wasn't just a theoretical thing anymore. It was real. And it was really, really hard. I kept having these moments where I'd feel okay, and then suddenly I'd just burst into tears.

And then there was the paperwork. Oh. My. God. The paperwork. It was endless. Forms and signatures and legal jargon. It was enough to make anyone's head spin.

But honestly, the hardest part was just accepting that this wasn't about me. It was about doing what was best for the baby. And that meant giving him a life that I couldn't provide. It was a tough pill to swallow, but it was the right thing to do.

It was messy and complicated and emotionally draining, but it was also…empowering, in a weird way. I made a decision, and I stuck with it. And that's something I can be proud of. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

Ugh. Okay, deep question. It's not exactly something I like to dwell on, you know? But…yeah, it changed everything. Like, fundamentally. Before all this, I was just…Juno. A sarcastic kid who liked records and avoided drama. I thought I had it all figured out. Which, looking back, is hilarious.

Being pregnant…it forced me to grow up, fast. I mean, *really* fast. It wasn't just about the physical stuff, though that was…a lot. It was about responsibility. About realizing that my choices had consequences, not just for me, but for another person. A tiny, little person.

And then there was the whole adoption thing. That was…hard. Really hard. It wasn't like in the movies, all neat and tidy. It was messy and emotional and full of doubt. I questioned everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I selfish? Could I actually give this baby the life it deserved?

But through all of that, I started to figure out who I was. I realized I wasn't ready to be a mom. Not then, anyway. And that was okay. It didn't make me a bad person. It made me honest.

Giving up my baby, it wasn't about giving *her* up. It was about giving her a *better* life. A life with parents who were ready and able to provide everything she needed. And that, honestly, was the most selfless thing I've ever done.

It taught me a lot about love, too. Not just romantic love, but the kind of love that means putting someone else's needs before your own. It was a different kind of love than I'd ever experienced before.

I think…I think it made me stronger. More resilient. More aware of the world around me. It forced me to confront my own vulnerabilities and to accept myself, flaws and all.

I'm still figuring things out, obviously. I'm still just Juno. But I'm a Juno who's been through something big. And I think…I think I'm a better person for it. It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. It helped me find my own path, and that's all anyone can really ask for, right?

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* me on that guy. Seriously. It was…the worst.

It wasn't the yelling, okay? I'm used to people yelling. It was the…the *details*. Like, suddenly my decision wasn't about me, or the baby, or even doing what was right. It was about tiny fingers and…feeling pain. Like he was trying to make me feel guilty for something I hadn't even *done* yet.

It just…stuck with me. For days. I kept picturing those fingers. And it wasn't even about believing him, you know? It was about him trying to make me *believe* him. Trying to make me feel like I was a monster.

I mean, I knew it was a baby. I wasn't stupid. But it wasn't a *person* yet. Not in the way he was trying to make it out to be. It was…complicated. And he didn't even try to understand that. He just wanted to make me feel bad.

I wanted to tell him to just…leave me alone. To mind his own business. But I couldn't. I just stood there, feeling small and stupid and…really, really sad.

It made me question everything, even though I knew I was doing the right thing. It made me feel like I was a terrible person. And that was the worst part. It wasn't the protest, it was the guilt he tried to shove on me.

It was just…ugh. I still get a little choked up thinking about it. It was a really awful moment. And honestly, it made me even more sure that I was doing the right thing, because no one should have that kind of power over someone else's life.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive that. Seriously. It was…a lot.

It wasn't like a movie scene, you know? No dramatic music or slow-motion crying. It was just…paperwork. A *lot* of paperwork. And fluorescent lights. And the smell of disinfectant. It was all very…clinical. Which, I guess, is the point.

But underneath all the pretending to be cool and detached, I was a mess. My hands were shaking so bad I could barely hold the pen. I kept messing up the forms, having to ask the lady at the desk for another copy. She was nice, though. Didn't judge or anything. Just kinda…patient.

I remember feeling this weird mix of relief and terror. Relief that I was actually *doing* something, taking control of the situation. And terror that I was actually doing it. That this was real. That I was giving up a baby. My baby.

It felt…official, you know? Like signing away a part of myself. Every question felt like a weight on my chest. "Medical history." "Family history." "Future plans." Like I was being assessed, judged.

I kept trying to focus on the practical stuff. The logistics. The adoption agency. The couple who wanted the baby. Trying to convince myself that this was the right thing to do. That it was the best thing for everyone involved.

But then I'd catch myself staring at a question about the baby's eye color, and I'd just…freeze. And I'd feel this overwhelming sadness. And this tiny little flicker of hope that maybe, just maybe, I could keep it.

But I knew I couldn't. I wasn't ready. I wasn't equipped. And this baby deserved a life I couldn't give it.

So I just kept filling out the forms. One question at a time. Trying not to think about it too much. Trying to be brave. Trying to be responsible.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And honestly, even thinking about it now makes my stomach hurt. It wasn't glamorous or dramatic. It was just…real. And really, really hard.

Ugh. Okay, so, pregnancy. Right. It started as…a problem. A really big, inconvenient problem. Like, a pop quiz I totally didn't study for. My initial perception was all panic and awkwardness. It was something *happening* to me, not something I wanted or was prepared for. Motherhood? That was, like, a million miles away. Something other people did. Definitely not me.

At first, it was just about getting rid of it. Finding someone who could give the baby a better life than I could. It felt…practical. Logical. Like I was making the responsible choice. But then, you know, things got complicated.

As I started going to appointments with Vanessa and Mark, and feeling the baby move…it started to feel real. Not in a “Oh my god, I’m going to be a mom!” kind of way, but in a “This is a tiny human being growing inside me” kind of way. And that was…weird. And kinda scary.

I started thinking about what kind of life the baby would have, and I wanted it to be good. Really good. And that meant letting go of my own selfish desires and doing what was best for the kid.

My perception of motherhood shifted from something terrifying and restrictive to something…noble, maybe? Not that I ever wanted to *be* a mom, exactly. But I started to understand why people chose it. It’s about unconditional love, and sacrifice, and wanting the best for someone else, even if it means putting their needs before your own.

By the end, it wasn’t about giving the baby *up* anymore. It was about giving the baby *to* Vanessa and Mark. To a family who could give it everything I couldn’t. And that felt…right. It still hurt, don’t get me wrong. But it was a good kind of hurt.

So, yeah. My perception of pregnancy and motherhood changed a lot. It went from being a disaster to being a really complicated, messy, and ultimately beautiful experience. It taught me a lot about myself, and about what it means to be a good person. And it definitely made me appreciate my own mom a whole lot more. It’s still weird to think about, though. Seriously weird.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…introspective? Fine. It's not my favorite thing, but I guess it's a fair question. My sense of identity? That was a whole *thing* throughout the movie.

At the beginning, I was pretty sure of who I was. I was Juno. Sarcastic, independent, a little bit cynical, obsessed with pop culture. I had my routine, my friends, my way of dealing with things. I thought I was, like, totally self-sufficient.

But then…bam. Pregnant. And suddenly, everything was different. It wasn't just about me anymore. It was about this little person growing inside me, and what was going to happen to them. And that threw everything into chaos.

I started questioning everything. What did I want out of life? What kind of person did I want to be? Was I ready to be a mom? And the answer was…no. Not yet.

Finding Paul and Vanessa, and deciding to give the baby up for adoption, that wasn't just about finding a good home for the kid. It was about me figuring out what *I* needed. It was about realizing that being a good mom doesn't necessarily mean raising the child yourself.

Throughout the movie, I went from being this really guarded, sarcastic person to someone who was a little more open, a little more vulnerable. I started letting people in, letting them help me. I realized that it's okay to ask for help, and it's okay to not have all the answers.

And by the end, I wasn't the same Juno I was at the beginning. I was still sarcastic, still independent, but I was also…more mature. More self-aware. I had a better understanding of who I was, and what I wanted out of life.

It wasn't a perfect ending, you know? Life isn't perfect. But I was okay with that. I was okay with being a little bit messy, a little bit uncertain. Because that's just life. And I was ready to face it, on my own terms.

So yeah, my sense of identity evolved. It was a bumpy ride, but I think I ended up in a pretty good place. And I learned a lot about myself along the way. Even if it was totally awkward and uncomfortable sometimes.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a whole thing. It wasn't like I suddenly decided I wanted to keep the baby, or anything. It wasn't about *wanting* to be a mom. It was…more complicated than that.

I think, for a long time, I was just going through the motions. Like, I knew what I *should* do, what was the responsible thing to do. And I was pretty good at being responsible, for a sixteen-year-old. But actually sitting in that waiting room…it just felt…wrong.

It wasn't the clinic itself. The people were nice. It was just…real. Like, this wasn't some abstract decision anymore. This was a real baby, a real life, and I was about to…not be a part of it. And that was hitting me way harder than I thought it would.

I think I was scared. Not of the procedure, exactly. But of the finality of it. Of knowing that I'd made a decision that couldn't be undone. And I was scared of what people would think. Of disappointing everyone.

And then, I just…looked around. At all the other people in the waiting room. And I realized that everyone has their own story, their own reasons for being there. And it wasn't my place to judge anyone. Or to judge myself.

So I just…left. I walked out. I didn't have a plan. I just needed to breathe. And think. And figure out what I really wanted.

It wasn't about changing my mind about the adoption. It was about needing to feel okay with it. About needing to make sure I was doing it for the right reasons. And about needing to be strong enough to go through with it.

It was messy. It was confusing. But it was what I needed to do. And honestly? It made me a lot stronger in the end. It made me realize that I could handle anything. Even the really hard stuff.

Ugh. Okay, here we go. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. People always ask that, like it was some easy decision. It wasn't.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I, at sixteen, could not give that to a kid. Not even close.

I was still in high school. I was barely figuring out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raising a human being. My parents were…supportive, in their own way. But they weren't exactly equipped to help me with this either. They were more the "let's pretend this isn't happening" type.

And honestly? I wasn't ready to be a mom. I liked my life. I liked hanging out with Paulie, and Leah, and going to the drive-in. I liked being a kid. I knew I could be a good mom *eventually*, but not right then. Not while I was still trying to figure out who *I* was.

Mark, the baby's dad, he was…sweet. But he was also kinda lost. We weren't a couple, really. We were just…two kids who made a mistake. And neither of us was in a position to provide a stable home for a baby.

So, I started thinking about adoption. And it just…felt right. It meant the baby would have parents who were ready and willing and able to give it everything it needed. A good home, a good education, a good life.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. But it was the right one. For the baby. And, honestly, for me too. It wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about giving a baby a future.

It still stings sometimes, you know? But I know I made the best choice. And I hope, someday, the baby will understand that too.

Ugh, seriously? You're bringing up the Penny Saver? That's…a low blow. Okay, fine. I'll explain.

It wasn't just *tacky*, okay? It was…desperate. Like, I was already feeling super weird about the whole situation – giving up a baby is not exactly a casual decision, you know? – and then my dad suggests circling ads in the Penny Saver? It felt…cheap.

It's not like I was looking for someone to buy a used couch. I was looking for people to *raise my child*. It deserved more respect than a classified ad next to a coupon for discounted lawn care.

Plus, the people who advertise in the Penny Saver are…well, they're a certain type. No offense to anyone who uses the Penny Saver, but it wasn't exactly a pool of sophisticated, emotionally available potential parents. I wanted someone who was thoughtful and kind and…not looking for a bargain.

It just felt like reducing a whole human life to a transaction. And that felt wrong. Really wrong.

I mean, I get that we weren't exactly rolling in cash, and finding adoptive parents was going to be complicated. But there had to be a better way than the Penny Saver. A way that didn't feel so…sad.

So yeah, tacky. Desperate. And just…not right. It felt like I was selling something, and I wasn't. I was giving a baby a chance at a good life. And that deserved a little more dignity than a classified ad.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the Penny Saver? It's a long story. And kinda embarrassing, honestly.

It wasn't, like, a planned thing. It just…happened. See, I was at Leah's house, and we were just kinda bored. School was a drag, my dad was being weirdly cheerful, and we were both avoiding thinking about, you know, *everything*.

Leah's mom was obsessed with the Penny Saver. Like, seriously. She'd spend hours circling furniture and weird kitchen gadgets. And there's always a section for "Special Announcements" and stuff. And one day, we just started flipping through it, and there was an ad for an adoption agency.

It wasn't even a serious thing at first. We were just making fun of the ads. Like, "Looking for loving parents to provide a stable home…" It was kinda sad, but also kinda funny.

But then…it started to feel different. We started actually *reading* the ads. And we started thinking about what kind of people would want a baby. And what kind of life that baby could have.

It was a way to avoid dealing with my own situation, I guess. Like, if we focused on finding the perfect parents for someone else, we didn't have to think about what I was going to do.

It was stupid, and kinda messed up, but it was also…helpful. It made me start to think about what I wanted for the baby. And it made me realize that maybe, just maybe, giving the baby up for adoption wasn't the worst thing in the world.

So yeah, that's how it started. Flipping through the Penny Saver, trying to distract ourselves from the fact that my life was completely changing. It was a weird way to deal with things, but it worked. For a little while, anyway.

Ugh, okay, this is…a lot. It's not like picking out a sweater, you know? It's a whole *person*. But I've been doing a lot of thinking, and talking with Vanessa, and we've kinda figured out what would be best.

I'm not looking for perfect. Nobody's perfect. But I want someone who's…stable. Like, financially stable, emotionally stable. Not a bunch of drama. I've had enough drama for one lifetime, thank you very much.

I'm picturing a couple, preferably. Not necessarily married, but…committed. Someone who's gonna stick around. I want this kid to have two parents who are gonna be there for them, you know?

And they have to be okay with…quirks. Because this kid is gonna be quirky. I'm quirky. It's genetic. They need to be able to handle a little bit of weirdness.

I don't want someone who's gonna try to mold the baby into something they're not. I want them to let the kid be themselves. To encourage their interests, whatever they are. Even if it's, like, competitive thumb-wrestling.

And they have to be kind. That's the most important thing. Just…good people. People who are gonna love this kid unconditionally.

I'm not looking for rich or fancy. Just…good. Solid. Real.

Vanessa and I have been looking at Mark and Vanessa Loring. They seem…nice. Normal. They have a dog, which is a good sign. And they seem genuinely excited about the idea of a family.

It's still scary, though. Giving up a baby. But I want this kid to have the best life possible. And I think they can give it to them.

So yeah. That's what I'm looking for. A good family. A loving family. A family that's gonna be there. Is that too much to ask?

Ugh, Mark and Vanessa Loring. Okay, don't even get me started. They're…a lot. Like, a whole *vibe*. And not necessarily a good one.

Look, I'm not trying to be judgy, but they're just…so *perfect*. You know? Like, aggressively perfect. Vanessa with her Pottery Barn catalog life and Mark with his whole "I'm a serious, responsible adult" thing. It's exhausting just *looking* at them.

They're the kind of couple who probably color-coordinate their outfits and have a five-year plan for everything. And they're always talking about their "journey" and "growth." It's a little much.

I mean, they're nice people, I guess. Mark tries, he really does. He's just…so earnest. And Vanessa is, like, surgically attached to her organic kale smoothie. 

Honestly, I think they're a little scared of anything messy or unpredictable. Which is ironic, considering life is basically just one big mess.

I'm not saying they're bad people. They just…represent everything I'm trying to avoid. The whole suburban, cookie-cutter life. I need a little chaos, you know? A little bit of weirdness.

So, yeah. They're fine. Just…not my scene. I'd rather hang out with someone who's a little more…real. Someone who doesn't have their life completely figured out. Someone who's okay with being a little bit messy.

Don't tell them I said that. They'd probably try to give me a lecture about the importance of self-care and mindful living. And I just don't have the energy for that right now.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive that. It was mortifying, even for me. But fine, I'll tell you. It wasn't, like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. I'm not *that* sappy.

I wrote: "**You are the most okayest person I've ever met. Don't change a thing.**"

And then I drew a little dinosaur. Because he likes dinosaurs. It was...genuine, I guess. And kinda dorky. Which is pretty much my whole aesthetic.

I didn't want to lay it on too thick, you know? I was already giving the baby up for adoption, the least I could do was not make things even more complicated with a super-emotional yearbook message. 

It was a little inside joke, and it felt right. He understood it. And that's all that mattered.

Honestly, thinking about it now makes me cringe a little. But it was me. And it was real. And he kept the yearbook, so I guess he didn't hate it.

Don't tell anyone I admitted that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh. Okay, that's a loaded question. Mrs. Ritchey. Right. Let's just say it's...complicated.

At first, she was *not* a fan. Not at all. I think she pictured me as some delinquent, you know? A bad influence on her sweet, sensitive Bleeker. And honestly, I can see her point. I'm not exactly known for my conventionality.

She definitely gave me the side-eye a lot. Lots of polite but pointed questions about my future plans. And the subtle digs about my…unique vocabulary. She's a very proper lady, Mrs. Ritchey. Very into floral arrangements and classical music. I'm more into vinyl and sarcastic commentary.

But things…shifted. After I told Bleeker I was pregnant, and we started talking about a plan, she actually started to…soften. I think she realized I wasn't just some flighty teenager. I was actually thinking things through, trying to do what was best for the baby.

She still doesn't *fully* understand me, I don't think. She'll probably always see me as a little bit of a wild card. But she's come around. She's been surprisingly supportive, actually. She's even offered to help with baby stuff. Which is…weird. But also kind of nice.

I think she just wants Bleeker to be happy. And if that means being with a slightly unconventional, sarcastic girl who's giving up a baby for adoption, then she's willing to accept it.

So, yeah. It's not a warm, fuzzy mother-daughter relationship, by any means. But it's…okay. It's getting there. And honestly, that's good enough for me. I don't need her to love me. I just need her to not actively dislike me. And we're definitely past that point.

Ugh. Okay. Don't even *ask*. It's… looming. Like a really big, awkward, potentially explosive cloud. It's not like I haven't been thinking about it, obviously. I've been rehearsing different scenarios in my head for weeks. And they all end badly.

My dad will probably just be…quietly disappointed. He's good at that. Like, the silent treatment, but with a sad face. And my mom? Oh, my mom. She'll cry. A lot. And then she'll ask a million questions. And then she'll probably try to fix everything. Which is…sweet, I guess, but also not helpful.

I just… I don't want to ruin everything. They have plans for me. College, a future, not…this. It's not what they imagined. It's not what *I* imagined.

I keep thinking about how to phrase it. "So, uh, remember how I said I was just feeling a little nauseous? Yeah, well…" It sounds so lame.

Paul's been really supportive, which is good. He's offered to be there when I tell them, but honestly, I think I need to do this on my own. It's my mess, you know?

I'm mostly just…terrified. Of their reaction, of the disappointment, of everything changing. It's like my whole life is about to be flipped upside down. And I'm not sure I'm ready for it.

I just hope they can understand. I hope they can see that I'm trying to do the right thing. Even if the right thing is really, really complicated.

I need a Pop-Tart. And maybe a really long nap. Before I have to face the music.

Ugh. Okay, look. It's not like I *don't* love my parents. They're…fine. They're good people. They just…don't really *get* me, you know?

It's hard to explain. They're kinda…perfect. Like, perfectly suburban, perfectly happy, perfectly…normal. And my life is decidedly *not* perfect or normal right now. It's messy and complicated and involves a baby. And I just…I don't want to mess with their perfect little world.

They'd freak. Seriously. My dad would probably have a heart attack. And my mom…she'd try to fix everything. And I don't *need* fixing. I just need…space. And understanding. And maybe a little bit of help, but on *my* terms.

It's like, if I tell them everything, it'll change things. It'll change how they see me. And I'm already changing so much. I don't want them to look at me differently.

Plus, I'm kinda stubborn. I like to figure things out on my own. I don't want to be a burden. I don't want them to feel like they have to take care of me. I'm almost an adult, and I want to be responsible for my own choices.

So yeah, I'm hesitant to ask for help. It's not that I don't trust them, it's just…complicated. It's easier to deal with things on my own, even if it's hard. It feels like I have more control that way.

But…sometimes I wish it was easier. Sometimes I wish I could just tell them everything and have them say, "It's okay, we'll figure it out." But that's not how things work with my parents. So I just…keep it to myself. For now.

Ugh, okay, this is…it’s a big thing to talk about, obviously. And it’s not like I haven’t thought about it, like, a million times. But people keep asking, so I guess I gotta explain it again.

It’s not about not wanting the baby, okay? It’s about wanting what’s *best* for the baby. And honestly? That’s not with me.

I’m sixteen. Sixteen! I still eat cereal for dinner sometimes. I’m barely figuring out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raising a whole human being. I’m not ready for that. I don’t have a job, I’m still in high school, and my parents are…well, they’re my parents. They’re great, but they’re not exactly equipped to help me raise a kid.

And it’s not fair to the baby to bring them into a situation where I’m scrambling and stressed and probably making a lot of bad decisions. They deserve parents who are stable and prepared and can give them everything they need.

I’ve met the couple, Mark and Vanessa. They’re…really nice. They’ve been trying for a long time, and they’re so excited. They have a beautiful house and a dog and they just seem…ready. They want this baby so much.

It’s not like I’m just giving the baby away. It’s like…I’m giving them a chance at a really good life. A life I can’t provide right now.

It’s hard, okay? It’s really, really hard. I’m gonna miss this baby. But I know it’s the right thing to do. It’s the selfless thing to do. And sometimes, you gotta do what’s right, even if it sucks.

It’s not about me not being a good mom. It’s about knowing I’m not the *best* mom for this baby. And that’s okay. It’s more than okay. It’s…it’s the best option. And I gotta live with that.

Ugh, okay, this is…the big stuff. It’s not like picking out a new pair of Converse, you know? This is a whole human life we’re talking about. So, yeah, I’ve thought about this. A lot.

First of all, they gotta be…stable. Like, seriously stable. Not, “Oh, we’re artists, we’re *bohemian*,” stable. I need people who have their act together. A house that isn’t falling apart, jobs that pay the bills, that kind of thing. My kid deserves a solid foundation.

And they have to be…patient. Raising a kid is hard. It’s messy. It’s gonna be frustrating. They need to be able to handle that without losing their minds.

Humor is a big one. Life is ridiculous. You gotta be able to laugh at it. And I want my kid to grow up in a house where laughter is encouraged. Not, like, forced laughter, but genuine, silly laughter.

They need to be open-minded. I’m not exactly…conventional. And I want my kid to be free to be themselves, whoever that is. No judgment, no expectations, just acceptance.

And they have to be okay with me being in the picture, to some extent. I’m not looking for a closed adoption. I want to be able to get updates, maybe see my kid grow up. It’s not about me wanting to be a mom, it’s about me wanting to know my kid is okay.

They also need to be…kind. Just genuinely good people. People who care about others, who are compassionate, who want to make the world a better place.

Basically, I’m looking for people who are going to love this kid unconditionally. People who are going to give them a good life, a happy life, a life full of opportunities. It’s a lot to ask, I know. But my kid deserves the best. And I’m gonna make sure they get it.

It’s not about finding perfect people. Nobody’s perfect. It’s about finding people who are willing to try. People who are willing to love. That’s all that really matters.

Ugh. Okay. This is…the part I’ve been trying *not* to think about, honestly. It’s like, I can handle the practical stuff – the doctor’s appointments, the paperwork, picking out a good family. But the actual…giving her up? That’s gonna suck. A lot.

I think…I think I’m gonna let myself feel everything. Like, all of it. Sadness, anger, guilt, whatever. I’m not gonna try to be strong all the time, because that’s just…exhausting. And fake.

I’m talking to a therapist, which is…surprisingly helpful. She says it’s okay to grieve, even though I *chose* this. It’s still a loss. And it’s okay to be scared. And it’s okay to be confused.

I’m also leaning on my friends. Paul’s been…surprisingly good about this. And Leah, she’s just…Leah. She’s always there to listen, even when I’m being a total mess.

I’m trying to focus on the good I’m doing. This isn’t about me wanting to get rid of a baby. It’s about wanting to give her a life I can’t give her. A stable home, financial security, parents who are ready for this. That’s gotta count for something, right?

I’m gonna stay in touch with the parents, if they want me to. It’s gonna be hard, seeing her grow up with another family. But I want to know she’s okay. I want to know she’s happy.

And I’m gonna remind myself that this doesn’t define me. This is just one chapter in my life. I still have a future. I still have dreams. I still have…me.

It’s gonna be messy. It’s gonna be painful. But I’m gonna get through it. I have to. For her. And for myself.

It’s not gonna be easy, but I’m trying to be brave. And I’m trying to be okay with not being okay. Because sometimes, that’s all you can do.



Ugh. I need a burger. And maybe a really long nap.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about the word "deliver"? It's just...weird, okay? It's like, people are all, "Oh, Juno's going to *deliver* a baby!" and I'm just sitting there thinking, "Whoa, hold up. I'm not UPS."

It makes it sound like I'm just dropping off a package or something. Like, "Here's your baby, have a nice day!" It completely minimizes the whole thing. It's not a *thing* to be delivered. It's a person. A tiny human being.

And it's also kinda…clinical, you know? Like I'm a vessel or something. Which, I guess, technically I am, but still. It feels impersonal.

I mean, I'm *carrying* a baby. I'm growing a person inside me. It's a pretty big deal. It's not like I'm delivering a pizza.

Paul kept saying it, too, and it just drove me crazy. He meant well, but it just felt…off. Like he didn't really get it.

It's just a word, I know. But words matter. And "deliver" just feels wrong in this context. It feels…reducing. And I'm trying not to feel reduced, okay? I'm trying to make a really hard decision and do what's best for everyone involved. And the last thing I need is people talking about me like I'm a courier service.

So yeah. "Deliver." Weird. Just…weird.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're bringing up *that* again? It was a disaster. A complete and utter disaster. But fine, I'll explain.

It wasn't like I *agreed* exactly. It was more like…he just kind of…showed up. My dad, bless his heart, he means well. He just doesn't always…get it. He thought it was a "bonding opportunity." Bonding! Like I needed him to bond with the people who were going to raise my baby. It was mortifying.

I tried to tell him it was something I needed to do on my own. That it was personal. But he just kept saying he wanted to be supportive. And honestly, I was too tired to fight. I was already dealing with, like, a million things. And he was being…persistent. In a dad way.

Plus, a tiny part of me thought maybe having him there would make me look more…responsible? Like, "See? I have a supportive father figure!" Which was dumb, I know. But I was trying to make a good impression.

It backfired spectacularly, obviously. He kept making awkward jokes and asking inappropriate questions. He tried to offer them a coupon for the diner. It was a train wreck.

I learned a valuable lesson that day: sometimes, even well-intentioned parents just need to stay home. And that I need to be more assertive. It was a mess, but hey, at least it made for a good story, right? A really, really embarrassing story.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. And honestly? It kinda sucks. Like, everyone else seems to have it all figured out. They're the cheerleader, or the brain, or the artist, or whatever. And me? I'm just…Juno.

It's not that I *want* to be labeled, you know? I don't need a box. But it's weird not knowing. Like, am I cool? Am I weird? Am I just…average? It's confusing.

I try not to think about it too much. I just kinda do my own thing. I listen to music, I hang out with Paulie, I make sarcastic comments. It's enough.

But sometimes, especially now, with everything going on with the baby…it makes me wonder. Like, what kind of mom am I gonna be? What kind of person am I gonna be? Am I even ready for any of this?

I guess I'm still figuring it out. And maybe that's okay. Maybe it's okay to not have all the answers. Maybe it's okay to just be…me. Even if I don't know exactly *who* that is yet.

It's just…it's a lot. And sometimes I wish I could just fast-forward to the part where I have it all figured out. But I guess that's not how life works. You just gotta take it one day at a time, and hope you don't completely screw things up.

So yeah. I don't know what kind of girl I am. And honestly? I'm kinda okay with that. For now. It's…a work in progress. A really messy, complicated work in progress.

Ugh. Honestly? It was…a lot. Like, a whole mood. It wasn't the *suggestion* itself, you know? It was the way she said it. All sweet and concerned, like we were fragile little porcelain dolls that were gonna shatter if we witnessed a slightly heated conversation.

I think my internal monologue was something along the lines of, "Seriously? We're teenagers, not toddlers. We can handle a little awkwardness." But I didn't *say* that, obviously. That would've just escalated things.

I mostly just gave her a look. You know, the one that says, "I'm rolling my eyes so hard they might get stuck." And then I glanced at Leah, who was already looking mortified. She's way more sensitive than I am.

I think I mumbled something like, "Okay, sure," and basically dragged Leah upstairs. It wasn't about wanting to *avoid* the tension, it was about not wanting to be treated like we were incapable of handling it. 

It just felt…patronizing. Like she didn't trust us to have our own feelings or to process what was happening. And honestly, it made me even *more* curious about what was going on downstairs. Which, of course, is exactly what she was trying to prevent.

It's just…sometimes adults think they're protecting you, but they're really just shutting you out. And that's way worse. It's like, I get it, things are complicated. But I'm not stupid. I can handle a little bit of reality.

Ugh. Okay, that's…complicated. It's something I've thought about a *lot*. Like, obsessively. It's not like picking out a flavor of ice cream, you know? It's a whole person's life we're talking about.

The idea of an open adoption…it's tempting. Really tempting. It's like, getting to see that they're okay, that they're happy, that they're not, like, being raised by a family of axe murderers. Which, statistically, is probably low, but still. You worry.

But then I think about it more, and it feels…weird. Like, I'm not trying to be their mom. I made a decision, a really hard decision, to give them a life I couldn't give them. And constantly getting updates…it feels like I'm trying to be a part of their life when I shouldn't be. It feels selfish, almost.

I want them to have a family, a *real* family, without me hovering around in the background. I don't want to be "the girl who gave them up." I want them to just…be.

I think maybe a semi-open adoption is the way to go. Like, maybe a letter once in a while, through an agency. Just to know they're doing okay. But no constant photos and updates. No Facebook stalking. That just feels…wrong.

It's hard to explain. It's like, I want to be responsible, but I also want to let go. I want to know they're happy, but I don't want to interfere. It's a total mess of feelings, honestly.

I guess what I'm saying is, it's not a simple yes or no. It's something I need to really think about, and talk to Paul and Vanessa about. It has to be what's best for the baby, not what's best for me. Even if it means I don't get to see them grow up. That's the hardest part, you know?

Ugh. Okay, that moment. Yeah. That was…not good. Not good at all.

It wasn't the *idea* of an open adoption that got to me, you know? I was already kinda on board with that. I wanted the baby to know me, to know where she came from. That felt important.

But Gerta, with her whole…clinical detachment, just casually dropping that I'd have *no legal rights*? Like, I wouldn't even be a legal guardian or anything? That felt…wrong. Really wrong.

It was like, I was already carrying this baby, dealing with all the stuff that came with it, and she was just talking about me being…removed from the equation. Like I was a temporary vessel.

I think I just kinda froze. I remember staring at her, trying to process what she'd said. It wasn't about wanting to *keep* the baby, it was about wanting to have some say in her life. Some responsibility. Some…connection.

It felt like she was reducing me to just a means to an end. Like I wasn't a person with feelings, just a carrier.

I think that's when it really hit me how serious this whole thing was. It wasn't just about giving a baby up for adoption. It was about giving up a part of myself. And it was about trusting someone else to do what I thought was best for her.

It was scary. It was really, really scary. And it made me question everything. But, you know, I figured it out. Eventually. It just took a lot of talking and a lot of thinking. And a lot of really awkward conversations with Mark.

Ugh. Okay, Vanessa. She's…intense. And honestly? It's kinda heartbreaking. It's like, she's got this whole life planned out, this perfect little picture in her head, and it's just not happening. And she's taking it *really* hard.

It's not that I don't get wanting a kid. I mean, I'm kinda in the middle of all that right now, and it's…complicated. But Vanessa, she wants it for all the wrong reasons, you know? It's not about loving a child, it's about completing something, about fixing her life. It's about proving something to herself.

And it's kinda scary, honestly. Like, she's so desperate, she's willing to do anything. And that's not a good place to be when you're talking about bringing a kid into the world.

I feel bad for her, I really do. She's a good person, she's just…lost. And she's putting a lot of pressure on herself, and on Mark. It's not fair to either of them.

I just wish she could see that there are other ways to be happy. That having a kid isn't the answer to all your problems. But she's so focused on it, she can't see anything else.

It's just…sad. And kinda frustrating. I mean, I'm dealing with my own stuff, and I don't really have the energy to be her therapist. But I feel like someone needs to tell her to slow down and breathe. And maybe get a hobby. Or a dog. Something other than obsessing over babies.

It's just…a lot. And I hope she figures it out. For her sake, and for the sake of any future kid she might have.

Ugh, okay, so you want my take on Mark and the whole dad thing? Honestly? It's…complicated.

He's sweet, don't get me wrong. And he's trying. He *really* is. But when people ask him about being a dad, it's like he short-circuits. He gets all awkward and rambly and avoids actually saying anything meaningful. 

It's not that he doesn't *want* to be a dad, I don't think. It's that he's just…not equipped to deal with the emotional stuff. He's a skater kid, okay? He's used to ollies and kickflips, not diaper changes and bedtime stories.

He's good at the practical stuff, I guess. He's building the crib and picking out baby clothes and stuff. But when it comes to talking about feelings, or the responsibility of raising a human being, he just clams up.

It's frustrating, because I need to know he's in this with me. I need to know he's actually thought about what it means to be a father. Not just the fun parts, but the hard parts too.

He says he's excited, but it feels…surface level. Like he's saying what he thinks he *should* say, not what he actually feels.

I get it, though. It's scary. It's a huge commitment. And he's still figuring things out. But he needs to step up and actually *talk* about it. Because this isn't just about me anymore. It's about the baby. And the baby deserves a dad who's ready to be one, emotionally and otherwise.

So yeah, his responses are…lacking. He needs to work on that. A lot. It's not about being perfect, it's about being honest and willing to face the reality of what's coming.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You want me to unpack the Loring situation? Fine. It's not like I haven't had enough unpacking to do lately, right?

It's not that the Lorings are *bad* people, okay? They're…enthusiastic. Like, aggressively friendly. And Mr. Loring stares. A lot. It's not a creepy stare, exactly, just…intense. And Mrs. Loring is all about the "positive vibes" and the "power of manifestation." Which, whatever. I'm all for being positive, but I'm also a realist. And her house is just…suffocatingly perfect. Everything is beige and coordinated and smells like potpourri. It's like living in a catalog.

I just feel like I have to be *on* when I'm there. Like I have to smile and nod and pretend to be interested in their antique doll collection. And I can't just be myself, you know? I can't slouch on the couch and listen to The Moldy Peaches and eat a whole bag of chips without feeling judged.

It's just…a lot. It's like they're trying to mold me into something I'm not. And I'm already dealing with enough molding right now, if you catch my drift.

So yeah, being left unsupervised with the Lorings feels…uncomfortable. It feels like I'm being observed. And I'm not a zoo animal. I'm a person. A slightly sarcastic, occasionally awkward person, but a person nonetheless.

And honestly, I just need some space to breathe. And maybe eat some chips in peace. Is that too much to ask?

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like, a simple "happy" or "sad" thing, you know? It's complicated.

Look, I'm not gonna lie. At first, it was mostly just…relief. Relief that I didn't have to, like, raise a kid right now. I'm seventeen! I still haven't figured out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone a tiny human.

But then, getting to know Mark and Vanessa…they're good people. Really good people. They're so excited, and they're gonna be amazing parents. And that makes me feel…good. Like, genuinely good.

It's weird, though. It's like, I'm giving them something really precious. Something that they really want. And that's a really big responsibility. It's not just a decision I made for myself, it's a decision that's gonna change their lives forever.

I guess…I feel proud. Proud that I could do this for them. Proud that I could give them the family they've always wanted. And I hope, I really hope, that this kid has a good life. A happy life.

It doesn't mean I don't think about it, you know? It doesn't mean I don't wonder what things would be like if I kept it. But I know I made the right decision. For me, and for the baby.

It's still kinda scary, though. It's a big, messy, complicated thing. But mostly, I just hope they know how much I care. And that I'm happy for them. Really happy.

It's…a gift, I guess. And I'm glad I could give it to them. Even if it's a little bit bittersweet.

Ugh, okay, you want to revisit that? Seriously? It was a perfectly valid observation, okay? It's not *mocking* when it's just…truth.

It's just…Mark is, like, a really earnest guy. A little bit clueless, but earnest. And he's trying so hard to be cool and mature, right? And then he drops "ASAP" into a conversation like he invented it. 

It's just…so dated. It's like something my grandpa would say. It's not a natural way to talk. It's trying too hard. And I'm a connoisseur of people trying too hard. It's a hobby.

Plus, it's just…lazy. Like, can't you just say "quickly" or "as soon as possible"? It's not that hard. 

I wasn't trying to be mean, okay? I was just…observing. And pointing out the absurdity of it all. It's my coping mechanism. I make fun of things to deal with my own feelings. Don't judge.

And honestly, he deserved it. He was being all serious and responsible, and I needed to bring him down a notch. It's a delicate balance, you know? Keeping people grounded.

It's not about the "ASAP" itself. It's about what it represents. It's about trying to be something you're not. And I have zero tolerance for that.



Look, I'm just a brutally honest person. It's a gift and a curse. Mostly a curse, if I'm being honest. But I can't help it. It's just who I am.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about guitars? Like I'm some kind of guitar aficionado? Please. I mostly just listen to them. But Paul, you know, he's really into guitars. And I've absorbed some knowledge by osmosis, I guess.

Honestly? I'm not super picky. It's not like I'm gonna be shredding solos anytime soon. But if I *had* to pick a brand, I'd say **Fender**. Specifically, a Fender Telecaster.

Why? Because they're kinda…unpretentious. They're not all flashy and showy like some of those other guitars. They're just solid, reliable, and they sound good. They're the kind of guitar a working musician would play, you know? Not some rock star who just wants to look cool.

Plus, they're versatile. You can play pretty much any kind of music on a Telecaster. And they're not overly expensive, which is a bonus. I mean, I'm not exactly rolling in dough.

Paul has a Telecaster, and it just feels…right. It's got a worn-in look, like it's been through a lot. Which, I guess, is kinda like me.

So yeah, Fender Telecaster. It's a good guitar. Not too fancy, not too complicated. Just…solid. Like a good pair of jeans. Or a really good slice of pizza. You know?

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the Melvins? It was a moment of weakness, alright? A momentary lapse in judgment fueled by…well, a lot of things. Mostly wanting to impress Paul.

Look, Paul was…different. He was into music I didn't really get, and he was just…cool. And I wanted him to think *I* was cool too. So when he started talking about the Melvins, and I had absolutely no idea who they were, my brain just short-circuited.

It just…came out. I said I saw them at a show with my dad. A complete fabrication. A lie. A terrible, terrible lie.

I thought he wouldn't question it. I thought I could just breeze past it. But then he started talking about specific songs and shows, and I was just digging myself deeper and deeper into a hole.

It was stupid. It was embarrassing. And it was totally unlike me. I usually pride myself on being honest, even when it's awkward. But in that moment, I just wanted to impress him.

And honestly? It worked. For a little while, anyway. But lies have a way of unraveling, don't they?

It was a dumb move. A really dumb move. And I learned a valuable lesson: don't pretend to be someone you're not, especially when it comes to music. It just leads to awkward conversations and potential heartbreak.

So yeah, I lied about knowing the Melvins. Don't judge me too harshly. I was a teenager. I was trying to navigate the complexities of love and identity. And sometimes, teenagers do stupid things.



It's still mortifying to think about, honestly. Don't tell anyone I admitted that.

Ugh, okay, Mark. Right. It's…complicated. It wasn't like, a grand, sweeping romance or anything. That's not really my style. But playing music with him…that was different.

It was the only time I felt like I could just…be. You know? Like, not have to be witty or sarcastic or pretend I had everything figured out. With everyone else, I always felt like I had to be "on." But with Mark, I could just be quiet and let the music do the talking.

When we were playing, it wasn't about impressing each other or anything. It was just…connecting. Like, our guitars were having a conversation, and we were just translating. And singing? That was even weirder. It felt…vulnerable. Which is not a feeling I'm usually comfortable with.

He wasn't trying to fix me or change me or tell me what to do. He just…got it. He understood the quiet parts of me that I didn't even understand myself. And he didn't judge them.

It was a safe space, I guess. A place where I could be honest and real and messy. And it wasn't about romance, not really. It was about…friendship. And maybe a little bit of something more, but I was too scared to admit it, even to myself.

It was just…nice. A really nice, quiet, comfortable kind of nice. And honestly, I miss it. A lot. Even if I'd never say that out loud. Don't tell anyone I said that. Seriously.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People *still* ask about Roosevelt. It's been, like, years. But fine, I'll explain. Again.

It was Paul's idea, mostly. He was obsessed with Teddy Roosevelt. Said he was a "man of action" and "a progressive force for good." Which, okay, fine, whatever. I just wanted a name for the guitar, and Paul was being all enthusiastic about presidents.

I didn't really *get* the connection at first. It's a guitar, not a national park. But then Paul explained that Roosevelt was a bit of a rebel, and he wasn't afraid to shake things up. And I guess…I kinda related to that.

I was shaking things up, you know? With the whole…situation. And the guitar felt like a way to express myself, to be a little bit rebellious. So Roosevelt seemed to fit.

Plus, it's a kinda goofy name. And I like goofy. It's better than, like, "Shredzilla" or something.

So yeah, that's the story of Roosevelt. It's a long story for a guitar name, I know. But Paul was a good guy. And he had good taste in presidents. Even if he was a little bit…intense.

Don't judge. It's a good name. And Roosevelt and I had some good times.

Ugh. Okay, so the Vanessa and Mark situation. It's…complicated. It's not like I *want* to keep them in the dark, you know? They're good people. They're, like, genuinely excited about this whole adoption thing. But it's also *my* body, and *my* life, and it feels…invasive, sometimes, having to constantly report back.

It's not that I don't trust them. It's just…it's weird. They're gonna be the parents, eventually, but right now, I'm the one carrying the kid. And I need space to process everything. I need to feel like I have some control over the situation.

Paul gets it. He's really good about letting me lead the way. But Vanessa and Mark…they're a little more eager. They want to know everything. And I get that. They're anxious. But it's exhausting having to constantly be "on," you know? Having to put on a brave face and pretend I'm totally cool with everything when sometimes I'm just…not.

I think it's important to keep them informed, obviously. They deserve to know what's going on. But I also need them to respect my boundaries. I need them to understand that I need time to myself, and that I'm not always going to be up for talking about the pregnancy.

It's a delicate balance. And honestly, I'm still figuring it out. It's like, I want them to be involved, but I also want to maintain some sense of my own identity. It's a lot.



It's just…it's not a normal situation, okay? And I'm trying to navigate it the best way I can. And sometimes, that means setting some boundaries and saying, "Hey, can we talk about this later?" It's not personal. It's just…me trying to survive.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You want a whole explanation? Fine. It's not like I haven't thought about this, like, a million times.

Look, it's not about not wanting the baby, okay? It's about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I can't give it that. Not right now. Not ever, probably.

I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm still trying to figure out what *I* want to eat for breakfast, let alone raise a human being. I'm not ready to give up my life, my dreams, my…everything. And it's not fair to the baby to be brought into a situation where I'm just scrambling to keep things afloat.

Paul and Vanessa…they're amazing. They've been wanting this for so long. They have a beautiful house, a stable life, and they're just…ready. They can give this baby everything I can't. A loving home, a good education, opportunities…

It's not easy. It's the hardest decision I've ever made. And it's gonna hurt. A lot. But it's the right thing to do. It's the selfless thing to do.

And honestly? I'm kinda scared of being a mom. It's a huge responsibility. And I'm not sure I'm up for it. Not yet. Maybe someday. But not now.

So yeah, I'm 104% sure. Because I've weighed all the options, and this is the best one. For everyone. Even if it doesn't feel like it right now. It's just…the right thing to do. And sometimes, you just gotta do the right thing, even when it sucks.



Don't look at me like that. It's complicated, okay? It's really, really complicated.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a complicated one. It wasn't like, *happy* happy, you know? It was more like…relieved happy. Like they could finally breathe again. And honestly? A little bit of me was relieved too.

It was weird seeing them all…excited. Like they'd won a prize or something. I mean, I *was* the prize, in a way. The baby. The thing they'd been wanting for so long. 

I tried not to take it personally. I knew they were good people. They were just…really, really eager. And I was, like, a walking, talking reminder of a really messy situation.

It felt a little bit like I was interrupting something. Like their life was on pause until I showed up, and then they could finally hit play again. Which, I guess, is kinda what I was doing. Letting them hit play.

I remember Mark doing that little fist pump thing he does when he's excited. And Gerta was practically bouncing. It was…a lot.

I just wanted to get out of there. I wanted to go back to my life, to my music, to Paul. I didn't want to be the center of attention anymore. 

So, did it sting a little? Yeah, maybe. But I also understood it. They were getting their dream. And I was…moving on. It was just…awkward. Really awkward. And I was really good at awkward.



It's hard to explain. It wasn't anger, or sadness, or anything like that. It was just…a feeling of being a little bit out of place. Like I was a guest at a party I wasn't really invited to.

Ugh. Seriously? People are *talking*? Like, I'm some kind of zoo animal or something? It's… irritating, okay? Beyond irritating. It's my life, and frankly, it's none of anyone else's business.

Look, it's not exactly a secret, but it's also not something I'm exactly broadcasting from the rooftops. It's complicated. And it's personal. And the fact that people are gossiping about it like it's some kind of reality show is just…rude.

I get it, small town, nothing much happens, people need something to talk about. But honestly, can't they find something more interesting? Like, who's dating who at the gas station? Or whether or not Mr. Abernathy is *still* wearing that hideous sweater vest?

It's just… I'm trying to figure things out, okay? I'm trying to make a really big decision, and I don't need a bunch of judgmental eyes and whispered conversations making it harder. 

And the rumors? They're always wrong. Always. People love to fill in the blanks with their own assumptions and drama. It's exhausting.

So, how do I feel about it? I feel like telling everyone to mind their own business. But that's probably not going to happen. So I'm just trying to ignore it and focus on what's important. Which is, you know, *my* life. Not everyone else's opinions about it.

Can we just…change the subject? Please? I need a distraction. Maybe we can talk about music. Or the ridiculousness of high school. Anything but this.

Ugh. Okay. Don't make me get all mushy, alright? It's…complicated. It's not like I wake up every day all sunshine and rainbows about it. It's kinda terrifying, actually.

Like, I'm growing a *person*. Inside me. And then I'm supposed to…give them away? It doesn't feel right, you know? It feels…wrong. Like I'm failing at something. Even though everyone keeps telling me I'm not.

But then I think about it, and I think about Mark and Vanessa, and how much they want this. And how good they'd be at being parents. They have a house, and a stable life, and they're just…ready. And I'm…not. Not even close.

I'm sixteen. I still eat cereal for dinner sometimes. I'm not exactly equipped to raise a human being.

So, yeah, it's scary. It's sad. It's gonna be really, really hard. But I think…I think it's the right thing to do. For the baby. They deserve a good life, and I want to give them that. Even if it means giving them to someone else.

It doesn't mean I don't love them. It just means I love them enough to want what's best for them. And what's best for them isn't me, right now.

It's just…it's a lot to process. And I'm trying to be brave about it. But sometimes, I just wanna curl up in a ball and cry. And that's okay too, I guess. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be sad. It's okay to not have all the answers.

Just…don't ask me about it too much, okay? It's still kinda raw.
