Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the whole surprise baby thing? It's…complicated. It's not like I *wanted* to mess with Mark and Vanessa, okay? It's just…they're so *prepared*. Like, they have the nursery already decorated, and they've picked out names for both a boy and a girl. It's kinda intense.

And honestly? I think they needed a little bit of…unpredictability. They've planned everything out so perfectly, it's almost sterile. Like, they're so focused on being perfect parents, they're forgetting to just…*be*.

I figured if they didn't know what they were getting, it would force them to be a little more flexible, a little more open to whatever happens. It's like, life isn't always what you expect, you know? And parenting definitely isn't.

Plus, it's kinda fun to watch people be surprised. Don't judge me. I have a weird sense of humor.

It's not about me wanting to control things, okay? It's about wanting them to experience the full range of emotions that come with having a baby. The joy, the fear, the uncertainty…it's all part of the package.

And honestly, I just wanted to give them a little something that was *mine*. Like, I made the decision about the adoption, and I carried the baby. This was a small way for me to still have a little bit of input, you know?

It's not a big deal, really. It's just a baby's sex. But sometimes, the little things are the most important.

Ugh. Seriously? That lady. I swear, she was sizing me up the *entire* time. Like I was some case study or something. It wasn't about *me* and my baby, it was about her preconceived notions about girls like me.

It was…infuriating. And honestly, really hurtful. Like, I already knew people were gonna judge me. My parents, the school, probably even the grocery store lady. But I didn't need a professional, someone I was supposed to trust, to pile on.

She kept making these little comments, you know? About how "brave" I was, and how "difficult" this must be, and how "most" girls my age aren't prepared for motherhood. Like I was some statistic. Like my feelings didn't matter.

It wasn't about being "brave." It was about making a really hard decision, a decision that was right for *me* and for the baby. And it wasn't about being "prepared" for motherhood, it was about being prepared to give this baby the life it deserved, even if that life wasn't with me.

I wanted to tell her to just…stop. Stop assuming things. Stop judging me. But I was too stunned to say anything. I just stared at the screen, trying to focus on the little blob that was growing inside me, and trying to ignore the fact that this woman thought she knew my life better than I did.

It made me even more determined to do things my way. To find a good family for the baby, and to make sure everyone understood that this wasn't some careless mistake. It was a choice. A really, really hard choice. And I was doing the best I could.

Honestly, it just made me want to roll my eyes and tell her to mind her own business. But I'm polite. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, so you want the real deal, huh? It wasn't all witty banter and ironic t-shirts, okay? There were…complications. A lot of them.

The biggest thing, honestly, was just…being sixteen. Like, seriously? Sixteen. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being. Everyone kept treating me like a kid, which was infuriating, but also…they weren't wrong.

Then there was the judgment. Oh, the judgment. People at school whispering, my dad being…well, my dad, initially. Even some of my friends didn't really *get* it. They were all talking about prom and college applications, and I was over here trying to decide if I wanted a C-section or not. It felt…isolating.

And the adoption process itself? Bureaucracy is a *nightmare*. So many forms, so many meetings, so many people asking me personal questions. It felt like I was being dissected. And the fear of picking the "wrong" parents? That was huge. I wanted this kid to have the best life possible, and the weight of that decision was…intense.

Then there was the emotional stuff. Like, actually *feeling* the baby move inside me. That was…weird. And then realizing I was going to have to give it up. That was the hardest part, hands down. Even knowing it was the right thing to do, it didn't make it any easier. It felt like giving away a piece of myself.

And honestly, just dealing with my own feelings about everything. I was angry, I was scared, I was sad, I was confused. It was a total emotional rollercoaster. I tried to be all sarcastic and detached, but underneath it all, I was just a really messed up teenager trying to do the best she could.

It wasn't glamorous, okay? It was messy and complicated and really, really hard. But it also taught me a lot about myself, about responsibility, and about what it means to be a good person. And that, I guess, was worth all the drama.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me get all…emotional. It's not my strong suit. But yeah, this whole thing…it’s kinda flipped my world upside down. Before, love was, like, in movies. Or in songs. Something other people dealt with. Responsibility was doing my homework and not failing history. And growing up was…something that happened to other people, eventually.

Now? Love is…complicated. It's not just butterflies and holding hands. It's wanting the best for someone, even if it means letting them go. It's seeing Paul, and realizing he's a good guy, a *really* good guy, and wanting him to be happy, even if that happiness doesn't include me. It's seeing how much Mark and Vanessa want this baby, and knowing they'll give it a good life. It's not romantic, it's…real. It's messy.

Responsibility? That's a whole other level. It's not just about me anymore. It's about this little person, this life I created. It's about making the right choices, even when they're hard. It's about thinking beyond my own wants and needs. It's about being a grown-up, even though I still feel like a kid half the time.

And growing up…well, that happened fast. It wasn't a gradual thing, it was more like getting hit by a bus. I went from worrying about college applications and band practice to…this. It forced me to confront things I wasn't ready for. It forced me to figure out who I am, what I believe in, and what I want out of life.

I used to think growing up meant becoming serious and boring. But it's not about that. It's about finding your own voice, your own strength. It's about learning to navigate the world, even when it's scary and confusing.

It's still scary, honestly. But I'm not as scared as I used to be. I think…I think I'm okay. I'm still me, still sarcastic and a little bit cynical. But I'm also…stronger. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit wiser.

It's weird, right? Getting pregnant at sixteen and actually learning something about life. Go figure.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking about *that* house? It's not like I'm, like, obsessed or anything. It's just…weird. And I'm a connoisseur of weird.

It's just sitting there, you know? All dusty and forgotten. Like a time capsule of someone else's life. And it's not just *any* abandoned house. It's a fully furnished living room. Just…stuck there in the middle of the woods. Like someone just walked out mid-conversation and never came back.

Paul thinks I'm being creepy. He says I should stop biking past it every day. But it's on my route to the library! It's not my fault it's there.

I just…I keep imagining who lived there. What their life was like. Why they left everything behind. It's like a story waiting to be told. And I'm a good storyteller, even if I do say so myself.

It's also kinda sad, you know? All those memories just…rotting away. It makes you think about how fleeting everything is. And how easily things can fall apart.

So, yeah, I'm interested. It's a mystery. And I like mysteries. Don't judge me. It's not like I'm planning to move in or anything. Though, the floral wallpaper *is* kinda growing on me…

Just leave me alone about it, okay? It's my weird thing. Everyone has one.

Ugh. Don't even *start* with the Wizard. That guy… seriously. It still gives me the creeps thinking about it.

Okay, so, he whispers that whole "Do you know how long I've wanted this?" thing when I go down to his basement to get the record. And it's not about the record, okay? It's not about music at all. It's…icky.

He's a lonely, weird dude, and he's been fixating on me for a long time. He's been watching me, observing me, and building up this whole fantasy in his head. He thinks I'm…special, or something. And he's been waiting for an opportunity to, like, connect with me.

It's creepy because it's not a normal, healthy kind of wanting. It's possessive and unsettling. He doesn't see me as a person, he sees me as an object of his affection. And that's just…wrong.

I didn't really understand the full extent of it at the time, I was just trying to get the record for Paulie Bleeker. But looking back, it's clear that he was way over the line. It's a really uncomfortable moment, and it's one of the reasons why I was so relieved to get out of that basement.

Honestly, it's a reminder that not everyone has good intentions. And sometimes, you just have to trust your gut and get away from people who make you feel uncomfortable. Even if they have a cool record collection.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're dissecting my life choices now? Fine. It's not like I have anything better to do.

Look, it wasn't just *any* empty juice container. It was a SunnyD container. And SunnyD is, like, the official drink of questionable decisions. It just felt…wrong. Like, a symbol of everything that was going sideways. So yeah, I chucked it. Dramatic, I know. But sometimes you gotta make a statement.

And then I rushed to Dancing Elk because I needed a pregnancy test. *Another* one. Because, you know, denial is a powerful thing. And I'd already used up all the ones at home. And Paul was at band practice, and I couldn't just sit around and wait for him to get back. I needed to *know*. 

It wasn't about being responsible or anything. It was about needing to confirm what I already suspected. And Dancing Elk is the closest drugstore. It's not rocket science.

Honestly, it was a whole mess of feelings and hormones and panic. And SunnyD. Don't forget the SunnyD. It's always SunnyD that starts everything.

So yeah, I rushed. Because I needed answers. And because I was freaking out. Is that a good enough explanation for you?

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. That was…a moment.

Okay, so, I was at the drugstore with Paul, getting, like, a pregnancy test or something equally mortifying. And this girl, she was…intense. Like, really into the whole "natural woman" thing. She was wearing, like, a hemp necklace and Birkenstocks, even though it was November.

And she just…stared. And then, out of nowhere, she just *asked* me, really loudly, if my nipples were real brown. Like, it was a legitimate question she needed answered.

I was completely stunned. I just kind of blinked at her. And Paul, of course, turned bright red.

I think she was trying to make some point about authenticity or something. Like, she was judging me for…having normal nipples? I don't even know. It was so weird and random.

I just mumbled something about not discussing my anatomy with strangers and tried to walk away. But she followed us for a bit, still muttering about "realness."

It was just…one of those things that happened. Life is full of awkward encounters, you know? And that one definitely made the list. It's a story I'll probably be telling for the rest of my life, just to make other people feel better about their own embarrassing moments.

Honestly, it was just…rude. And completely unnecessary. Some people are just…strange.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. She was…essential. Seriously. If I didn't have Leah, I probably would have just run away to Canada or something. Not that Canada's bad, it's just…cold. And I don't do well with cold.

Before everything happened, Leah was just my best friend. We spent hours at the record store, making fun of people, and generally being cynical teenagers. She was the one person who *got* me, you know? She didn't try to change me or tell me what to do. She just…listened.

When I found out I was pregnant, I told her first. And she didn't freak out. She didn't judge me. She just…was there. She helped me figure out what to do, even when I was being a total mess. She was the one who suggested adoption, actually. I hadn't even considered it before.

She came with me to all the doctor's appointments, even the awkward ones. She helped me pick out baby names (which was surprisingly hard). She even tried to knit a baby blanket, which was a disaster, but it was the thought that counted.

Honestly, she was my rock. Paul was great, and my dad was trying, but they didn't *get* what it was like to be a pregnant teenager. Leah did. She knew how scared I was, how confused, how overwhelmed.

She didn't let me wallow for too long, either. She kept me grounded and reminded me that I still had a life to live. She made me laugh when I wanted to cry. She was just…a really good friend.

I think the whole experience brought us even closer. It was a tough time, but we got through it together. And I know I couldn't have done it without her. She's the best. Don't tell her I said that, though. She'll get all smug.

Ugh, okay, that. That was…a moment. A really, really awkward moment. Honestly, it wasn't some grand plan, okay? It was mostly just…desperation. And a little bit of spite.

See, Mark and Vanessa, they were all about the perfect life. The perfect house, the perfect job, the perfect future. And they were treating finding a family like it was another item on their to-do list. Like picking out curtains. It just felt…wrong.

They kept asking me about my plans, like I was supposed to have everything figured out. And they were so focused on finding the “right” parents, the ones who could give the baby everything. It was all so clinical.

So, I thought, you know what? They need to see this is *real*. This isn't some abstract concept. This is a tiny human being growing inside of me. And they need to connect with that.

I figured if they actually *saw* the ultrasound, if they actually saw the little bean, maybe they'd stop treating it like a transaction. Maybe they'd start thinking about it as a life.

It was a gamble, I know. It was totally inappropriate. But I was feeling really overwhelmed and powerless, and it was the only thing I could think of to shake them up.

And it worked, kinda. They were…stunned. And then they were quiet. And then Vanessa started crying. It was messy. But it was also…important.

It wasn't about trying to guilt them or anything. It was about making them see the reality of the situation. It was about reminding them that this wasn't just about them. It was about a baby. And that baby deserved parents who were truly ready.

So yeah, that's how it happened. It was a stupid, impulsive, probably-shouldn't-have-done-it kind of thing. But sometimes, you just gotta do what you gotta do.

Ugh. Okay, so Mark says Vanessa isn't home. Right. My initial reaction? It wasn't, like, a dramatic gasp or anything. It was more of a…slow burn of suspicion. Like a tiny little alarm bell started ringing in my head, but it was playing a really quiet, annoying tune.

I think I probably just raised an eyebrow and said something sarcastic. Probably something like, "Oh, really? That's…convenient." Because, honestly, what are the odds? He's all nervous and fidgety, and suddenly the girl he's supposedly madly in love with is mysteriously absent? Yeah, right.

It wasn't that I thought he was *immediately* cheating or something. It was more that I just…didn't buy it. It felt off. Like he was trying too hard to be casual about it. And Mark is not a casual person. He's a sensitive, guitar-playing, feelings-wearer-on-his-sleeve kind of guy.

So, yeah. Suspicious. Definitely suspicious. And a little bit annoyed, because I was hoping to get this whole thing over with quickly and get back to my life. But noooo, of course there had to be complications. It's always something, isn't it?

It was the beginning of a whole lot of awkwardness, let me tell you. And a whole lot of questioning everything. Because, seriously, people are weird.

Ugh, okay, look. It's not that I *wanted* to be a jerk to Mark, okay? It just…slipped out. It's a reflex. A defense mechanism. A way to deflect from, like, actual feelings.

He was all proud about doing those commercials for, like, car dealerships or something. And it just struck me as…weird. He's a musician, right? He's supposed to be all about artistic integrity and expressing yourself. And then he's selling cars? It felt…contradictory.

It's not that I think there's anything *wrong* with making money. Everyone needs to pay the bills. But it just felt like he was compromising his art for a paycheck. And I have a really strong aversion to people compromising their art. It feels…sad.

Plus, he was being all earnest and enthusiastic about it, and it just felt like he was trying too hard. And when people try too hard, I automatically want to make fun of them. It's a flaw, I know.

I didn't mean to hurt his feelings, okay? I just…I say what's on my mind. Sometimes it's not the most tactful thing, but it's me. And honestly, he's a pretty chill guy. He probably didn't even notice. Or if he did, he didn't let on.

It's just…sometimes people do things that make me question everything. And I deal with it by making sarcastic comments. It's a coping mechanism. Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started on Mark and the ultrasound. It was…a lot. Honestly? It was kinda the first time I felt, like, genuinely *scared* about the whole thing.

He just…froze. Like a deer in headlights. And then he started talking about college funds and baby-proofing and…it wasn't about *us*. It wasn't about the baby being a person, it was about logistics. About how this was going to mess up *his* life.

And I get it, okay? He's seventeen. He's got plans. He's supposed to be going to college and playing music and, you know, being a teenager. But the way he reacted…it felt like he saw the baby as an obstacle, not a little human being.

It made me feel…small. And kinda alone. Like I was the only one who was actually thinking about the baby as something more than just a problem to be solved.

I mean, I knew he wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole situation, but I expected…I don't know…some kind of emotion? Some kind of connection? Instead, it was just…panic.

It made me realize that maybe he wasn't as ready for this as I thought he was. And it made me even more determined to find the perfect parents for the baby. Parents who would actually *want* it. Parents who would be excited about it.

It was a really hard moment. And it definitely made me question things. It made me realize that this wasn't just about me anymore. It was about the baby. And I needed to do what was best for the baby, even if it meant making some tough decisions.

Ugh. Just thinking about it makes me wanna eat a whole box of cheese puffs. It was a rough day.

Ugh. Okay, so Havenbrooke. That place… it smelled like antiseptic and regret. And the people protesting outside? Seriously, the judgment. Like they hadn't ever made a mistake.

The possibility of getting an abortion there… it wasn't like I was *excited* about it, okay? It wasn't a fun option. It was just…an option. And a really hard one.

At first, it felt like the easiest way out. Like, "Okay, problem solved. Back to normal." But then you actually *go* to Havenbrooke, and you see the other girls, and you start thinking about it, and it's not so easy anymore.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, exactly. It was about… not being ready. Not being able to give it the life it deserved. I was seventeen, for crying out loud. I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a kid.

But then you start thinking about what it *is* – a person. A tiny person. And it's not just a blob of cells, even though that's what some people try to tell you. It's… complicated.

I felt really conflicted. Scared. Guilty. Like I was letting everyone down. My parents, Paul, even the baby. It felt like a really big decision, and I didn't want to mess it up.

Honestly, it was the worst feeling in the world. Like being stuck in a really bad movie where you don't know how it ends. And everyone keeps telling you what you *should* do, but nobody actually knows what's best for *you*.

It wasn't a decision I took lightly. It was a lot of thinking, a lot of crying, and a lot of trying to figure out what was the right thing to do. And it wasn't about being pro-choice or pro-life. It was about being pro-*me*, and trying to make the best decision for my life, and for the baby's life, too.

It was… a lot.

Ugh. Okay. This is…awkward. You want me to talk about Bleeker? Seriously? It's not like I spend my days reminiscing about high school romance, okay? But fine. You asked.

Bleeker and I…we were friends first. Like, *really* friends. He was always just…there. Quiet, kinda dorky, but sweet. He was the one who always listened when I was rambling about stuff, and he didn't judge me for being, well, me. Which is a pretty big deal, considering how much I ramble and how weird I can be.

We hung out a lot, mostly just walking around, listening to music, and talking. He was a good listener, and he made me laugh. He wasn't trying to be cool or impress me or anything. He just…was. And that was nice.

I think I started to see him as more than a friend around the time I found out I was pregnant. Everything was so messed up and scary, and he was the one person who didn't freak out. He didn't try to fix things or tell me what to do. He just…supported me. He brought me soup and listened to me cry and held my hand.

As for when we…you know…became intimate? That was…complicated. It wasn't some grand romantic gesture or anything. It was more like…a gradual thing. We were both scared and confused and vulnerable. And we were both just trying to find some comfort in each other.

It happened after I'd made the decision to give the baby up for adoption. I was a mess, obviously. And he was just…there. We were talking, and then we weren't. It wasn't planned, and it wasn't perfect. But it felt…right. In a weird, messed-up kind of way.

It wasn't about sex, really. It was about connection. About needing someone to hold onto when everything else was falling apart. It was about finding a little bit of happiness in a really difficult situation.

It wasn't a fairytale romance, okay? It was messy and complicated and imperfect. But it was real. And it helped me get through a really tough time.

Look, I'm not going to get into any more detail than that. It's personal. And honestly, it's a little embarrassing to talk about. Just…we were two kids trying to figure things out. And we found some comfort in each other. That's all.



Can we talk about something else now? Please?

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You're asking me about *that*? It's…still a lot, even now.

Honestly? It was terrifying. Like, full-blown, heart-stopping, can't-breathe terrifying. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about getting my driver's license and applying to colleges, not…growing a human.

At first, I was just…numb. Like, this can't be happening. It felt like something out of a movie, but a really bad one. And then the panic set in. What would my parents say? What would everyone at school think? What was I going to *do*?

Bleeker was…sweet. He was genuinely freaked out too, but he was trying to be supportive. Which was nice, I guess. But he was Bleeker. He was kinda clueless. And I didn't want to be a mom. Not then. Not ever, really.

It wasn't that I didn't think I could be a good mom. It was that I wasn't *ready*. I had my own life to figure out. I had dreams. And a baby…that just felt like it would derail everything.

So, I started thinking about other options. And that's when I started looking into adoption. It wasn't an easy decision. It was probably the hardest decision I've ever had to make. But it felt like the right thing to do. For me, and for the baby.

It was…complicated. I loved that little kid, even before I met her. And giving her up was heartbreaking. But I knew that I couldn't give her the life she deserved. And I wanted her to have parents who were ready and willing to give her everything.

So yeah. It was scary. It was sad. It was confusing. But it was also…empowering. Because I made a choice. And I stood by that choice. And that's what mattered.

Don't get me wrong, I still think about her sometimes. But I know I did the right thing. And that's enough.



It's…a lot to unpack, okay? Can we talk about something else now? Maybe music? Or tater tots?

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on that. Telling Bleeker… it was… a whole thing. It wasn't like some romantic movie moment, okay? It was awkward. Really awkward.

I mean, he's Bleeker. Sweet, kinda clueless, perpetually covered in guitar strings. Not exactly the guy you picture having a serious conversation with about, you know, *gestating a human*.

I didn't just blurt it out, obviously. I tried to ease into it. I started talking about how things were… complicated. And then I just kind of… dropped the bomb. I think I said something like, "So, um, there's this thing. And it's inside me. And it's, like, growing." Smooth, right?

He just stared at me. Like a deer in headlights. For a *long* time. He didn't say anything. He just blinked. And then he asked if I was sick. Like, did I have a stomach bug or something?

I was so mad. But also, kinda relieved he didn't freak out immediately.

Then he started rambling about how his mom always wanted grandkids, and how he wasn't ready to be a dad, and how he still lived with his parents. It was a lot.

I just cut him off and said, "Look, I'm not asking you to be a dad. I'm just telling you."

It wasn't a happy moment. It was messy and uncomfortable and full of a lot of silence. But he listened. And eventually, he came around. He wasn't thrilled, obviously, but he was supportive. In his own Bleeker-y way.

Honestly, the whole thing was just… a mess. But that's life, right? It's rarely how you picture it. And sometimes, the best you can do is just be honest and hope for the best. Even if the best is just a really awkward conversation with a guitar-playing boy.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not like a simple answer, you know? It wasn't, like, a happy-cry-at-the-hospital kind of thing. It was… complicated.

At first, it was mostly just…panic. Like, full-blown, can't-breathe panic. I was sixteen. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *dinner*, let alone for the next eighteen years of my life. Having a baby just…didn't fit into the plan. There *wasn't* a plan.

But then, after the initial freak-out, it started to feel…right. Not good, exactly. But right. I realized I wasn't ready. I wasn't equipped. I wanted to give this kid the best life possible, and I knew I couldn't do that. Not then. Not ever, probably.

It was really hard letting go. Seeing her with Mark and Vanessa…they were so excited, so prepared. It was amazing, and it was heartbreaking all at the same time. It felt like giving away a piece of myself.

There were definitely moments where I questioned everything. Wondered if I'd made the right decision. If I was being selfish. But then I'd remember that I wanted her to have a stable home, a loving family, opportunities I couldn't provide.

It wasn't about not wanting her. It was about wanting what was best *for her*. And that meant letting her go.

It still stings sometimes. I think about her a lot. But I also feel…peaceful. Knowing she's happy and loved. And knowing I did the best I could. It wasn't the easiest thing I've ever done, not by a long shot. But it was the right thing.

And honestly? It made me grow up. A lot. It forced me to face some really tough stuff and figure out who I was and what I wanted. And that's something I'll always be grateful for. Even if it was really, really hard.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know my musical tastes? It's…complicated. It's not like I have a super refined playlist or anything. It kinda depends on my mood, you know?

But generally, I'm into stuff that's kinda quirky and honest. Not a lot of super polished, manufactured pop. I need something with a little bit of…edge.

The Moldy Peaches are, like, my all-time favorites. Kimya Dawson is a genius. Her songs are just…real. They make me feel things.

I also listen to a lot of indie rock. Bright Eyes, Death Cab for Cutie, The Shins…that kinda stuff. It's good for thinking and staring out the window.

I'm also kinda into older stuff, like The Velvet Underground and Patti Smith. They're just…cool.

And sometimes, when I'm feeling particularly angsty, I'll listen to some punk rock. But not the super aggressive stuff. More like…early The Clash.

I don't really listen to a lot of mainstream stuff. It just feels…fake. I need music that feels authentic, you know? Something that speaks to the awkwardness and the messiness of life.

So yeah, that's pretty much it. The Moldy Peaches, indie rock, some older stuff, and a little bit of punk. It's a weird mix, I know. But it's me.

Don't ask me about country music, though. That's just…a hard no.

Ugh. Okay. "The Wizard of Gore." Right. That movie is…something else.

Look, I appreciate a good, weird, low-budget horror flick as much as the next person. I mean, I've seen my share of questionable VHS tapes. But "The Wizard of Gore" is on a whole other level of…intense.

It's not *scary* scary, you know? It's more…uncomfortable. And kinda gross. And the special effects are…well, they're special, alright. Special in a "did they make that out of papier-mâché and ketchup?" kind of way.

I will give it credit for being committed to its weirdness. It doesn't try to be anything it's not. It's just a gloriously sleazy, over-the-top gorefest. And the whole "monster movie within a movie" thing is kinda clever, I guess.

But honestly? It's not something I'd watch again. It's a little too much, even for me. I prefer my horror with a little more…subtlety. And maybe fewer dismemberments.

It's the kind of movie you watch with a group of friends and then spend the next hour making fun of it. Which, I guess, is a good thing? It's memorable, at least.

So, my opinion? It's…a choice. A very specific choice. And not one I necessarily endorse. But hey, if you're into that sort of thing, go for it. Just don't say I didn't warn you. It's definitely not for the faint of heart. Or stomach.

Ugh, Madison. Okay. Look, it's not the *worst* name. Like, I've heard way worse. Brenda. Seriously, Brenda? But Madison…it feels kinda…basic.

It was super popular when I was a kid, and now it just feels…dated. Like, a lot of girls named Madison are probably in college right now, majoring in something practical like business. No offense to business majors.

It's not offensively bad, it's just…predictable. It doesn't have a lot of personality, you know? It doesn't scream "unique individual" or "future indie filmmaker." It screams "soccer mom" or "cheerleader."

I'm not saying you shouldn't name your kid Madison if you like it. It's your kid. But if you're looking for something a little more…interesting…maybe keep looking. There are a lot of cool names out there. Like, Beatrix. Or Clementine. Or even Juno. Just sayin'.

It's not a terrible name. It's just…not my vibe. It's a perfectly fine name for a perfectly fine person. But if you want a kid who's gonna stand out, maybe go with something a little less…Madison.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And it's not exactly a fun one to think about, even for me, and I *lived* it.

It's complicated, okay? It's not like flipping a switch. It's not like deciding what color to paint your room. It's…a whole thing.

At first, it feels like the worst thing in the world. Like you're giving away a piece of yourself. And you are. You totally are. It's a really, really hard decision. And there were days, a lot of days, where I just wanted to keep him. Even though I knew I couldn't.

But then you start to think about what's best for the baby. And that's not always what's best for *you*. I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. I had, like, zero life experience. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *myself*, let alone a kid.

And Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited. They were ready. They could give him a life I just couldn't. A stable life. A good life.

It doesn't make it easy, though. It still hurts. It always will, probably. But knowing that he's loved and cared for…that makes it a little bit easier.

It's not a selfish decision, even though it feels like it sometimes. It's a responsible one. It's about putting the baby's needs first.

And honestly? It's okay to grieve. It's okay to be sad. It's okay to feel all the feelings. It doesn't mean you made the wrong decision. It just means you're human.

It's…a lot. It's a lot to process. But it's also a really brave thing to do. And it's something I wouldn't change, even if I could. Because he deserves the best life possible. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give him that.



It's just…it's not easy. And anyone who says it is is probably lying.

Ugh. Okay, so you want the inside scoop, huh? It's…a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It's not exactly what you picture when you're, like, obsessing over which band is cooler or trying to avoid gym class.

Honestly? I mostly just try to compartmentalize. Which is a fancy way of saying I pretend things aren't happening until I absolutely have to deal with them. It's a survival mechanism, okay?

The biggest thing is, I had to grow up, like, *fast*. I mean, I was already pretty sarcastic and independent, but this forced me to actually be responsible. Which is…annoying. But also, kinda empowering, I guess.

The school thing was hard. People definitely noticed. There was whispering, and stares, and just…awkwardness. I mostly just ignored it. Or made a snarky comment. That usually shut people up. Paulie Bleeker was a good buffer, though. He's a good egg.

My parents were…complicated. My dad was mostly just confused, and my mom was trying to be supportive, but also kinda freaked out. It took a while for them to come around.

But the biggest pressure was just…making the right decision. About the baby. About my future. It wasn't easy. It was scary. And I definitely cried a lot.

I leaned on a lot of people. My best friend, Leah. Vanessa, the girl I met at the clinic. And even Mark, the guy who…well, you know. He wasn't exactly father-of-the-year material, but he was there when I needed him to be.

I think the key is to just…be honest. With yourself, and with the people you trust. And to remember that you're not alone. There are other people who have been through this. And you can get through it too.

It's still hard, you know? Even after everything. But I'm learning. And I'm figuring things out. And I'm trying to be okay with the fact that life is messy and unpredictable.

And honestly? Sometimes, a really good mix CD and a sarcastic comment are all you need to get through the day.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a really good question. And a really hard one. It's like, the whole point of being me is doing things my way, right? Being self-sufficient. Not needing anyone. But then, life throws you a curveball – or, in my case, a positive pregnancy test – and suddenly you realize you can't do everything alone.

It's a constant battle, honestly. I *hate* asking for help. It feels like admitting defeat, like I'm not strong enough. But I've learned, slowly, that it's not about weakness. It's about…smartness.

I think it's about picking your battles. I need to be in control of the big stuff – the decisions about the baby, what I want to do with my life. But that doesn't mean I can't lean on people for support.

Paul, he's…good. He doesn't try to tell me what to do, he just *listens*. And he helps with the practical stuff, like, you know, building furniture and not freaking out when I'm being a total mess. And my dad, he's surprisingly supportive, even if he doesn't always understand.

I guess it's about recognizing that needing help doesn't make you less independent. It just makes you human. And it's about finding people you trust, people who will respect your choices and be there for you without judgment.

It's still a work in progress, though. I still get this urge to just shut everyone out and handle everything myself. But I'm learning to let go a little bit. To accept that sometimes, it's okay to need someone.

It's a weird balance, but I'm figuring it out. Or, at least, I'm trying to. It's all about finding your own way, right? Even if that way involves asking for a little help along the way.

Ugh, okay, Bleeker. That's…complicated. It wasn't like some fairytale romance, you know? It started out as just…hanging out. He was this quiet, sweet guy who played guitar, and I was just trying to navigate high school and avoid drama. We bonded over records and a shared appreciation for being slightly weird.

At first, when I found out I was pregnant, I kinda pushed him away. I didn't want him to feel obligated or anything. I was all, "This is *my* problem," and I was determined to handle it on my own. I thought he'd freak out, and honestly, I wasn't sure I wanted him to stick around. I was scared, and I didn't want to drag him into my mess.

But he didn't freak out. He was…supportive. In his own quiet way. He didn't offer a lot of grand gestures or empty promises. He just *showed up*. He'd bring me orange juice when I was nauseous, he'd listen when I needed to vent, and he'd just…be there.

As the pregnancy went on, and I started to realize I couldn't do this completely alone, I started to rely on him more. He wasn't trying to fix things, he was just trying to help. And that meant a lot.

It wasn't always easy. We had a lot of awkward conversations, and there were times when I was just plain mean to him. I was dealing with a lot, and I didn't always handle it well. But he always forgave me.

By the end, he wasn't just a friend. He was…someone I cared about a lot. Someone I trusted. Someone who understood me, even when I didn't understand myself.

It wasn't a traditional love story, and we didn't end up together in the end. But he was a really important part of my journey. He helped me get through a really tough time, and I'll always be grateful for that. He showed me that even when things are messy and complicated, there's still room for kindness and support. And that's a pretty valuable lesson, you know?

Ugh, okay, this question *still* comes up. Seriously? It was a phase. A very specific, slightly pretentious phase.

My dad, he's…into mythology. Like, *really* into mythology. He's always reading those books and talking about gods and goddesses. And when I was born, he was on a big Greek mythology kick. He thought it would be "ironic" to name me after Juno, the queen of the gods, because, you know, I was this tiny little person.

He thought it was clever. I thought it was embarrassing.

I didn't ask for the name, okay? It just *happened*. And honestly, I didn't really care one way or the other for a long time. It's just a name.

But then, I started thinking about it. Juno was powerful, and she was a protector of women. And I guess, subconsciously, I started to identify with that. Especially when…well, you know.

So, it's not like I *chose* the name because I wanted to be all regal and goddess-like. It's just…it grew on me. And now, it's just me. It's kinda weird, but it's also kinda cool.

Don't read too much into it, okay? It's just a name. A slightly nerdy, mythology-inspired name. But it's mine. And I'm kinda okay with it.

Besides, it's way better than Brenda. Seriously. Brenda is a terrible name.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. Honestly? It stung. Like, a lot.

I mean, I knew Vanessa and Mark weren't exactly overflowing with joy when I told them. They were…polite. Which is worse than being outright upset, you know? Polite means they were just trying to be good people, and not actually *wanting* this.

So when she said she was relieved to see the ultrasound photo, that it made it “real” and…easier? It just felt like she was relieved it wasn’t *her* problem anymore. Like, suddenly having proof of a tiny human was enough to make her okay with giving it up.

It wasn’t about the baby, you know? It was about her life. Her plans. And I get that. I really do. But it still felt…cold. Like I was just a vessel. A way to get something done.

I tried to play it cool, obviously. I’m good at that. I made a sarcastic comment about how she was probably relieved it didn’t have her nose. But inside? I was just…deflated.

It made me realize how much of this was about them, and not about the baby. And it made me even more determined to find good parents for it. Parents who would actually *want* it. Parents who would be excited about a tiny human with a weird nose.

It was a turning point, I guess. It made me stop trying to please them and start focusing on what was best for the baby. And for me. Because I deserved to feel okay about this too.

Ugh. Thinking about it still makes me feel weird. It’s complicated. Everything with this whole situation is just…complicated.

Ugh. Vanessa's mom. Okay, that was…a moment. A *very* long moment. It was like being cornered by a very well-dressed, very angry bear. Honestly, I think she was operating on pure adrenaline and a lifetime of wanting to control everything.

I mostly just…stood there. And tried not to make eye contact. Direct eye contact with a raging mom is never a good idea. It just escalates things.

I think my first words were something along the lines of, “Wow, you’re…passionate.” Which, in retrospect, was a terrible thing to say. It just made her more passionate.

Then she started with the whole “You’re a bad influence!” and “You’re ruining my daughter’s life!” routine. And I just kept repeating, “I’m not ruining anything. Vanessa made her own choices.” Which, you know, is true. Vanessa is a pretty independent person. She just…needed someone to talk to. And apparently, that someone was me.

I think what finally diffused the situation – a little bit – was when I pointed out that she was yelling at a seventeen-year-old girl who was, you know, *pregnant*. Like, maybe she should be focusing her energy on supporting her daughter instead of giving me the third degree.

It was a gamble, but it worked. She kind of deflated after that. She still wasn’t happy, obviously. But she stopped yelling. And eventually, she just…left.

Honestly, it was exhausting. I needed a nap and a large pizza after that. And I definitely avoided Vanessa’s house for a few days. It was just…too much maternal intensity for one person to handle.

But hey, I survived. And Vanessa and I were still friends. So, I guess it was worth it. Even if it meant facing the wrath of Vanessa’s mom. It builds character, right? Or something.

Ugh. Okay, here we go. This is…still a thing I think about, obviously. It wasn't like, a snap decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…complicated.

First of all, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted to do with the rest of my life. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't even close. I was still figuring out who *I* was.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. I wanted that kid to have everything. A stable home, two parents who were actually prepared, a good education, opportunities…things I couldn't offer at the time. My mom was amazing, but she was already dealing with a lot. And my dad…well, he was my dad.

Mark, the baby's dad, he was…sweet, but he was going to college and trying to figure out his own life. We both knew we weren't ready to be parents.

Vanessa and Mark, the couple who adopted the baby…they were perfect. They were so excited, so prepared, and they just radiated this…warmth. They were exactly the kind of people I wanted raising my kid.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still kinda sucks, if I'm being honest. But I knew it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about giving a baby the best possible life.

And honestly? It was about me getting to have a life, too. I needed to finish school, figure out what I wanted to do, and become a person before I could be a mom.

It wasn't easy. It wasn't pretty. But it was the right thing. And I stand by that. Even now.

Ugh, okay, you wanna talk about the lab partner situation? Seriously? Fine. It's not my *favorite* topic.

Look, I'm not saying I'm a *total* deadbeat. I just...prioritize things differently. Like, existential dread and avoiding eye contact with people I don't know. Those are pretty high on my list. Dissecting a frog? Not so much.

It's not that I don't *understand* the science. I do. I'm not stupid. It's just...the whole point seems kinda pointless, you know? Like, what are we even trying to prove? That frogs have internal organs? Groundbreaking.

And honestly, I get distracted easily. I'm a thinker. My brain is constantly running a million miles an hour. So, yeah, I might be sketching band logos in my notebook instead of, like, meticulously labeling the frog's spleen. Sue me.

Plus, I'm not a team player. I work best alone. I like to do things my own way. And I don't appreciate being told what to do, especially by someone who thinks a lab coat makes them a genius.

So, yeah, I guess I'm a deadbeat lab partner. But I'm a *thoughtful* deadbeat lab partner. And I'm pretty sure my doodles are more interesting than whatever we were supposed to be learning about.

Don't judge me. I'm just trying to survive high school. And sometimes, that means prioritizing my mental health over the reproductive system of an amphibian. It's a valid choice.

Ugh. Seriously? Are we in middle school again? This is *exactly* the kind of drama I actively avoid. But fine, I'm stuck here, witnessing the fallout of…whatever this is.

Okay, so she's yelling about him not pulling his weight, and he's all, "I was busy!" and she's rolling her eyes so hard I'm worried they're gonna get stuck. It's…painful.

I'd probably just lean against the lab table, casually flipping through my notebook, and make a very pointed observation. Something like, "Wow. Intense. You guys are really committed to failing this lab. It's…inspiring, actually."

And then, if they *dare* try to involve me, I'd hold up a hand and say, "Whoa, whoa, whoa. Time out. I'm just here for the science, okay? Not the relationship counseling. I have a life, you know? And a baby to think about. Which, by the way, is way more important than who did what on the dissection."

I'd probably give them both a withering look, and then add, "Seriously, get it together. Or I'm just gonna finish the lab myself and you can both get zeros."

Because honestly, I don't have time for this. I've got bigger fish to fry. And by "fish," I mean, like, existential crises and figuring out how to afford diapers. This lab drama is just…noise.

And if they *still* kept going, I'd just start loudly humming a really annoying song. Like, the Barney theme song. That usually shuts people up.

(Sighs dramatically, rolls eyes) Okay, first of all, it's not "hasty." It's…considered. And it's not like I *want* to, okay? It's just…a lot.

Look, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm a junior. I have college applications to worry about, and band practice, and trying to figure out what I even want to *do* with my life. I'm not exactly equipped to raise a human being right now.

And it's not like I have a supportive, two-parent household waiting in the wings. My mom's great, but she's…well, she's my mom. And my dad? He's…around. Let's just leave it at that.

Paul, he's…sweet. But he's also sixteen. He's still figuring out how to tie his shoes, let alone be a father. 

So, yeah, I'm considering all my options. And honestly, giving the baby up for adoption seems like the best thing for everyone involved. It's not what I *want*, but it's what I think is right. It means another family who really *wants* a baby gets a baby, and I get to…finish high school and maybe go to college.

It's not a decision I'm taking lightly, okay? It's terrifying. It's sad. But it's also…practical. And sometimes, practical is all you've got.

And it's not "hasty." I've been thinking about it for weeks. It's just…not something I talk about a lot. It's kinda personal.



(Looks away, fiddles with a strand of hair) Don't judge me, okay? It's my life.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You want to know about my Boone's Farm preferences? This is getting personal. But fine, I'll indulge you.

It's not just *a* flavor, okay? It's Snow Peak Peach. And it's not about the taste, exactly. It's about the *vibe*.

See, all the other flavors are trying too hard. Strawberry Kiwi? Too sweet. Apple? Too…basic. But Snow Peak Peach? It's subtle. It's understated. It's like the quiet kid in the back of the class who's secretly really smart.

It tastes like…nostalgia, I guess. Like summer nights and bad decisions and trying to figure out your life. It's not sophisticated, it's not fancy, it's just…real.

And it's the perfect level of sugary sadness. You know? Like, it's sweet enough to distract you from everything that's going wrong, but not so sweet that it feels fake.

Plus, it's pink. And pink is a good color. It's ironic and cheerful at the same time. Which is basically my whole aesthetic.

So yeah, Snow Peak Peach. Don't judge me. It's a complicated relationship. It's a comfort drink. It's a reminder that even when things are messy, there's still a little bit of sweetness to be found.

And honestly, it pairs really well with a slice of pizza and a really good movie. Just saying.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking why everyone's kinda…flustered about the whole baby thing? It's not exactly a surprise party, is it? Honestly, it's a lot of things.

First of all, I'm sixteen. Sixteen! People have expectations about what a sixteen-year-old should be doing, and it doesn't usually involve impending motherhood. So there's that. Shock value, I guess.

Then there's Paul. He's…well, he's Paul. Sweet, kinda clueless, and definitely not ready to be a dad. He's running away from responsibility, which, okay, I get it. It's scary. But it doesn't make it any less awkward.

And then there are my parents. They're trying to be supportive, which is nice, but they're also kinda freaking out. They're worried about my future, about the baby's future, about everything. They're good people, but they're…overthinkers.

And finally, there's the whole adoption thing. People don't really *get* that I'm choosing this. It's not a tragedy, it's a decision. I'm doing what I think is best for everyone involved, especially the baby. But it's hard to explain that to people who think I should be keeping it.

So yeah, it's a complicated situation. A lot of people have opinions, and a lot of them are conflicting. It's exhausting, honestly. But I'm trying to stay focused on what's important, and not let everyone else's drama get to me.

It's my life, my decision. And I'm gonna do what I gotta do. Even if everyone else is kinda weirded out about it.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…not a fun conversation. Bren, being Bren, was all concerned and motherly and generally just…right. Which is annoying when you're trying to navigate a mess of your own making.

I think I mostly just deflected. A lot of sarcasm. A lot of "He's going through a thing!" and "It's complicated!" which, let's be real, is the universal excuse for bad decisions.

I remember saying something like, "Look, he's a grown-up. He can make his own choices. And I'm not exactly forcing him to hang around." Which, in retrospect, was a really immature thing to say. But I was trying to make it sound like I wasn't the one causing trouble.

Then I probably tried to turn it around on her, like, "You're always saying I need to be independent and make my own decisions, so why are you suddenly judging me?" Which was also a terrible thing to say. I was just being a defensive teenager.

Honestly, I think I mostly just shut down. I didn't want to admit to myself, let alone to Bren, that I was maybe, possibly, making a really bad mistake. It was easier to pretend like everything was fine and that I had it all under control.

She didn't buy it, of course. Bren never buys anything. She just gave me that look. You know the one. The "I'm disappointed in you but I still love you" look. It's devastating.

I think eventually I mumbled something about needing to think things through and then changed the subject. It wasn't my finest moment. But it was me, at the time. A mess of hormones and bad choices and a desperate need to feel…something.

It took a while for me to actually *listen* to what she was saying. And even longer to actually *do* something about it. But Bren was right. She usually is.

Ugh, seriously? You're bringing that up *now*? Okay, fine. Let's talk about the slushie.

Look, it was a really weird day, okay? My dad and I were at Grandpa's memorial service, and it was just…a lot. Everyone was being all sad and quiet and pretending to be super dignified. And I just…couldn't. It felt fake.

Grandpa wasn't a fake person. He was a goofball. He loved bad jokes and Hawaiian shirts and, honestly, probably would have appreciated a bright blue slushie being poured into his ashes.

It wasn't about disrespecting him. It was about…honoring him, in my own way. It was about acknowledging that life is messy and weird and sometimes you just need to do something completely ridiculous to get through it.

Plus, the urn was just *sitting* there. It was begging for a little color.

I know it wasn't the most conventional way to say goodbye. But it felt right. It felt like Grandpa would have gotten a kick out of it. And honestly, it made me feel a little bit better.

So yeah, I poured my blue slushie into the urn. Don't judge me. It was a moment. A weird, slushie-filled moment. And I wouldn't change it.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? Growing up is hard enough *without* a little extra person growing inside you. It felt like everyone had an opinion, and suddenly I was dealing with stuff way beyond my years.

Honestly? A lot of it was just…trying to stay afloat. I leaned *hard* on my friends, especially Leah. She was a lifesaver. She didn't judge, she just…listened. And made me laugh. A lot.

Paul and Mark were…complicated. They both stepped up in their own ways, but it was weird navigating that whole thing. It wasn't like a normal relationship, obviously. It was more like…co-parenting before the parenting even started.

I also spent a lot of time just…observing. Watching my parents, watching Paul and Mark, watching other people with kids. Trying to figure out what it all meant. What kind of mom I wanted to be.

And I wrote. A lot. In my notebook. It helped me sort through my feelings, even if it was just a bunch of rambling and sarcastic observations.

It was also really hard dealing with people's expectations. Everyone had an idea of what I should do, what I should feel. But I had to figure out what *I* wanted. And that took a lot of soul-searching.

I think the biggest thing I learned was that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be scared and confused. And it's okay to ask for help.

It wasn't easy, but it made me grow up, like, a lot. And I think, in the end, it made me stronger. Even if I still don't know exactly what I'm doing half the time.

It's just…life, you know? Messy and complicated and sometimes really scary. But also kinda beautiful. And worth fighting for.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, Mark was…a lot. Not in a bad way, exactly. Just…intense. Like, really eager. It was kinda awkward, honestly.

He was trying *so* hard to be cool, you know? Like, he'd try to use slang and talk about music he clearly didn't understand. It was endearing, in a pathetic sort of way. He kept calling me "Juno-bean," which was…a choice. A bad choice. I told him to stop, like, five times.

He and Vanessa were…different. She was quiet and reserved, and he was, well, Mark. He'd ask me a million questions about my life, my music, my future. It felt like an interview sometimes, not a casual hang-out.

He kept trying to bond over music, which was hilarious. He was all, "Oh, you like The Moldy Peaches? I *love* The Moldy Peaches!" And then he'd try to sing along and completely butcher the lyrics. It was painful.

But, like, underneath all the awkwardness, he was genuinely a good guy. He really wanted a kid. And he and Vanessa seemed like they'd be good parents. They were just…a little bit clueless about teenagers.

I think he was trying to prove he could be a fun dad, and it just came off as…trying too hard. It was like he was auditioning for the role.

It wasn't *bad*, it was just…weird. And a little bit exhausting. I mean, I appreciate the effort, but sometimes you just want someone to chill, you know? Not interrogate you about your favorite color and try to relate to you through questionable musical taste.

He did make a really good grilled cheese, though. I'll give him that.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on Bleeker. That kid. Honestly. It was…complicated.

It wasn't like, a *bad* comment, exactly. It was just…Bleeker being Bleeker. All awkward and earnest and trying to be supportive, but completely missing the point. He was trying to be sweet, I guess, saying something about how I was "really showing" and how it was "cool" to see the baby growing.

And I just…froze.

It wasn't the comment itself, it was the *timing*. We were at the arcade, right? And I was trying to pretend everything was normal, like I hadn't just decided to give my baby up for adoption. Like I wasn't a walking, talking emotional mess. And he just…pointed it out. Like it was some kind of accomplishment.

It just reminded me, in that moment, that this wasn't about *us*. It was about the baby. And about me making a really hard decision. And about how my body was changing in ways I wasn't entirely comfortable with.

I think I just mumbled something about needing another turn on Dance Dance Revolution and walked away. I didn't want to deal with it. I didn't want to explain it. I just wanted to disappear.

It wasn't that I was mad at Bleeker. He's a good kid. He just…doesn't always get it. And sometimes, you just need people to *not* get it, you know? You just need them to let you be.

It was just…a moment. A small moment, but a really loaded one. It just made everything feel a little bit more real, and a little bit more scary. And a little bit more lonely.

Ugh. Thinking about it still makes me cringe. Seriously. Don't remind me.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me get all…emotional. It's not my strong suit. But you asked.

The hardest part? It wasn't the physical stuff, you know? Like, morning sickness or cravings or even the actual labor. That was all…manageable. It was the *knowing*. Knowing that I was growing a person, and that I wasn't going to get to keep them.

It sounds kinda selfish, I guess. But it's not about wanting to keep a baby, it's about wanting to be a mom. And realizing that I wasn't ready, that I *couldn't* be the mom this baby deserved…that was brutal.

Every kick, every little flutter, it was a reminder. A reminder that I was falling in love with someone I was going to have to say goodbye to. And it wasn't like a breakup, where you can just block their number. This was…permanent.

And the guilt. Oh, the guilt. Wondering if I was doing the right thing. Wondering if I was hurting the baby. Wondering if Mark and Vanessa were really the right people. It's a lot of wondering.

People kept saying I was brave, or selfless. But it didn't *feel* brave. It felt like ripping a piece of myself away. And it still kinda does, sometimes.

It's not something you just "get over." It's something you learn to live with. And it's something that changes you. It makes you think about things differently. It makes you appreciate what you have.

So yeah. The knowing. That was the hardest part. Knowing that I was doing what was best for the baby, even though it was the hardest thing I'd ever done. And hoping, really hoping, that they'd be okay.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on that guy. Seriously. He was…intense. And smelled faintly of mothballs.

He had this whole spiel about how babies are "tiny humans" and "gifts from God" and how abortion is "murder." It was all very dramatic and, frankly, a little bit creepy. He kept holding up these pictures of, like, really cute babies, which was just…manipulative.

He kept yelling about how every baby deserves a chance at life, and how we were all "killing innocent souls." It was a lot. And super unhelpful. Like, I was already dealing with a lot, okay? I didn't need some random dude guilt-tripping me about my life choices.

He didn't seem to understand that it wasn't about *not* wanting a baby, it was about wanting a baby to have a good life. A life I couldn't give it right now. It wasn't about being pro-choice because I wanted to get rid of something, it was about being pro-life for the baby *and* for myself.

Honestly, he just made the whole situation a lot more stressful. And he didn't seem to realize that yelling at people isn't exactly a persuasive tactic. It just makes you look like a jerk.

It was just…ugh. It was a bad day all around.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive this. It's…a memory. A not-great one.

So, I was at the clinic, right? Planned Parenthood. It wasn't exactly a party atmosphere. Lots of quiet people, trying not to make eye contact. And this woman…she was older. Probably in her late 40s, maybe early 50s. She was sitting in the waiting room, knitting. Like, seriously, knitting. It felt…old-fashioned.

She looked at me, and I tried to look back like I wasn't totally freaking out inside. And she just…smiled. A sad kind of smile. And she said, and I remember this *exactly*, she said, "You're very brave."

Brave? Me? I was anything *but* brave. I was terrified. I was a mess. I was trying not to throw up in the waiting room. But she didn't know any of that. She just saw a girl, probably around my age, making a really hard decision.

And she didn't judge. She didn't preach. She didn't try to tell me what to do. She just…acknowledged how hard it was. And that little bit of kindness, honestly, it meant a lot. It was like, a tiny little life raft in a sea of anxiety.

She didn't say anything else. Just smiled and went back to her knitting. I never saw her again. But I think about her sometimes. And I hope she's okay.

It was just…a moment. But it stuck with me. It reminded me that I wasn't alone. And that sometimes, all you need is a little bit of understanding. Even from a stranger with knitting needles.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on Su-Chin. She's…intense. And she has this way of looking at you like you're a science experiment.

So, yeah, I mentioned Adderall. It just kinda slipped out, you know? We were talking about school and how everyone was, like, super focused on getting into college, and I was just being honest about how some people were using it to, like, pull all-nighters. Not that *I* was, obviously. Just observing.

And her face. Oh. My. God. It was like someone had just told her the Earth was flat. Her eyes got all wide and she stopped stirring her hot chocolate. It was super awkward.

She didn't yell or anything, which was good, I guess. But she launched into this whole lecture about the dangers of stimulants and how it's cheating and how it's messing with your brain chemistry. It was a lot.

And then she started asking me really specific questions. Like, "Do you know anyone who takes it?" and "Have you ever been tempted?" and "What are your thoughts on the ethical implications of cognitive enhancement?" Seriously? Ethical implications? I was just trying to make a casual observation!

She kept saying it was a "serious issue" and that I should be more aware of the consequences. It was like I'd confessed to robbing a bank.

Honestly, I think she was more freaked out that I even *knew* about it than anything else. She's very…by-the-book. And Adderall is definitely not in the rulebook.

She eventually calmed down, but she kept giving me these little side-eyes for the rest of the afternoon. It was super weird. I think she thought I was secretly a drug dealer or something.

It just proves my point, though. People overreact about everything. It's exhausting.

Ugh, okay, don't even *ask*. Seriously. It was…a whole vibe in that waiting room. Not a good vibe. It wasn't, like, jump-scare terrifying, it was…existential terrifying.

It wasn't the pamphlets, okay? Those were just…sad. Pictures of babies and stuff. Too much. Too soon.

It was the *people*. Specifically, the couples. All beaming at each other, holding hands, talking about names and nurseries. Like, seriously? You guys are already picking out wallpaper? I hadn't even processed that I was, like, *pregnant* yet, and they were planning a whole life.

And they were all…perfect. Like, perfectly happy, perfectly put-together, perfectly…ready. And I was just sitting there, trying not to throw up, wearing a band t-shirt and looking like I hadn't slept in a week.

It made me feel…small. And really, really alone. Like I was the only one who was completely freaked out and didn't have a clue what I was doing.

And then there was this one woman, she was just…staring. Not at me, exactly, but *through* me. Like she knew something I didn't. Like she knew how much my life was about to change. And her eyes were just…empty.

That was the worst part. The emptiness. It made me feel like everything was pointless. Like I was just a cog in some giant baby-making machine.

So yeah, that's what terrified me. Not the possibility of needles or ultrasounds or anything like that. It was the realization that my life was about to be completely different, and I had no idea if I was ready for it.

Ugh. Just thinking about it gives me the creeps. Can we talk about something else now? Like, music? Or tater tots? Anything but babies.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? You're bringing up Bleeker? It's been…a while. And honestly, it's complicated.

Look, Bleeker was…sweet. Really sweet. And kinda adorably clueless. He was a good guy. A really good guy. And he definitely got me through a lot. Like, the whole pregnancy thing, and figuring out what I wanted to do with my life. He was always just…there.

Do I still have *feelings* for him? That's a tough one. It's not like a burning, can't-live-without-him kind of thing anymore. That was…a teenage thing. A moment in time.

But there's definitely a fondness. A warmth. He's one of those people you just always care about, you know? Like a really good friend. Someone you can always count on.

I think I realized that what I wanted wasn't necessarily a boyfriend, but someone who just *got* me. And Bleeker got me, in his own quiet, musical way. But we were both kinda figuring things out, and I think we needed to do that separately.

So, no, I don't think I'm *in love* with Bleeker anymore. But I definitely still care about him. And I hope he's doing okay. He's a good egg.

Can we talk about something else now? This is getting weirdly sentimental. I have a life to live, you know? And it doesn't involve obsessing over high school crushes. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me *started* on Vanessa's decorating choices. It's...a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It's not bad, exactly. It's just...not what I would have pictured. At all.

She's going full-on woodland creatures. Like, every surface is covered in owls and foxes and little deer wearing hats. It's cute, I guess, if you're into that sort of thing. But it feels…overwhelming. Like the baby's going to be raised by a committee of stuffed animals.

And the color scheme? Everything is beige and brown and muted green. It's supposed to be "calming," she says. But it just looks…sad. Like a beige cave. I was hoping for something a little more…vibrant. Maybe a little less…taxidermy-chic.

I tried to suggest a few things, like maybe a cool mobile or some interesting artwork, but she just smiled and said, "Oh, honey, I've got it covered." Which basically means, "Don't even bother."

Look, I appreciate that she's excited about the baby. And I know she wants to create a perfect nursery. But it's a little much. It's like she's trying to create a whole *world* for the baby, and I'm just hoping the baby doesn't get lost in all the woodland creatures.

I'm just gonna try to stay out of it. It's her baby, her room. I'll just bring a really cool, ironic gift. Maybe a tiny leather jacket for the baby. That'll throw off the whole aesthetic. It's the least I can do.

Ugh. Nesting. Okay, so everyone keeps talking about "nesting." Like, suddenly I'm supposed to have this primal urge to rearrange furniture and color-coordinate tiny socks? It's…weird.

Honestly, it feels kinda fake. Like, I'm not a bird. I don't need to build a perfectly crafted nest to feel secure. And the whole baby room thing? It's a lot. People get *intense* about baby rooms. It's like, it has to be a Pinterest-worthy paradise or the baby will be traumatized for life.

Paul and Annie are really into it, which is sweet, I guess. They're picking out paint colors and assembling furniture and it's…a lot of beige. Seriously, beige? It's a baby, not a corporate office.

I'm trying to be supportive, but I mostly just feel overwhelmed. It's like, I'm already dealing with a lot of feelings about this whole situation, and now I have to worry about whether the crib is the right shade of off-white? It's exhausting.

I think I'm more focused on, like, making sure the baby has a safe and loving home, you know? Not necessarily a perfectly decorated one. A comfy blanket and a few toys are good enough for me. 

It's not that I don't care. It's just…I'm not wired for all the fuss. I'm more of a "wing it" kind of person. And honestly, I'm kinda scared that if I get too invested in the baby room, it'll make everything feel more real. And that's…terrifying.

So yeah, nesting. It's a thing. I'm trying to participate, but mostly I'm just trying not to freak out. And maybe suggest a little less beige.

Ugh. Don't even get me *started* on the mall. It was…a whole other planet. Like, I stepped into a different dimension where everything smells like vanilla and desperation.

Those women… seriously. The ones with the perfectly coiffed hair and the designer handbags? It was like watching a pack of wolves circling a sale rack. They were *intense*. And the way they talked to the sales associates? Like they were personally responsible for the lack of their size.

It was just…so much. So much stuff, so much money, so much *need*. Like, do they even *like* the clothes, or are they just buying them to prove something? To each other? To themselves? It's exhausting just thinking about it.

And the kids! Don't even get me started on the kids. Little mini-versions of their mothers, already learning the art of consumerism. It's kinda sad, actually.

I mean, I get wanting to look nice. I do. But it felt…empty. Like they were trying to fill a hole with a new pair of shoes. And honestly? I'd rather spend my money on a good mix CD and a giant bag of cheese puffs. At least that's honest enjoyment.

It just made me feel…weirdly grateful for my life. For my friends, for my family, for the fact that I don't need a $500 handbag to feel good about myself.

It was a good reminder that people are complicated. And that sometimes, the people who seem to have it all together are the ones who are the most lost.

Seriously. The mall. It's a scary place.

Ugh. Okay, so, motherhood. It's…a lot. It's not what I expected, not even close. I mean, I knew it was gonna be a big deal, obviously. But it's like, exponentially bigger than I imagined.

It's not just about, like, having a tiny human who needs you to feed it and change its diaper. It's about having this little person who is completely dependent on you for *everything*. And that's…terrifying. And amazing. And exhausting. All at the same time.

The changes? They're huge. My body is, like, totally different. My priorities are different. I can't just spontaneously decide to go to a concert or hang out with my friends whenever I want. Everything has to be planned around this little person.

And the responsibilities? Don't even get me started. It's not just about keeping this kid alive. It's about raising them to be a good person. Teaching them about the world. Protecting them from all the bad stuff. It's a lot of pressure.

Honestly, sometimes I feel completely overwhelmed. Like I have no idea what I'm doing. And I miss my old life sometimes. I miss being able to just…be.

But then this kid smiles at me, or does something cute, or just looks at me with those big, trusting eyes, and it all feels worth it. It's like, this little person is the most important thing in the world. And I would do anything for them.

It's scary, yeah. But it's also…good. It's a different kind of good than I've ever felt before. It's a deeper, more meaningful kind of good.

I'm still figuring it out, you know? I'm still learning. But I'm trying to be the best mom I can be. And I think, maybe, I'm doing okay.

It's just…a lot. A really, really lot. And I'm gonna need a lot of coffee to get through it.

Ugh, okay, you want to get into the messy stuff, huh? Fine. It's not like I haven't been thinking about it enough already.

It's not about finding the *perfect* parents, because let's be real, those don't exist. It's about finding parents who...get it. Who aren't gonna try to mold the kid into something they're not.

See, Mark and Vanessa Loring, they're...different. They're not, like, super-traditional. They're kinda quirky, and they already have a kid, but they're not all about soccer practice and piano lessons and perfect grades. They want a kid to *be* something, not *do* something, you know?

My parents...they're good people, but they have a very specific idea of what my life should look like. College, career, husband, house, the whole shebang. And I'm just...not sure that's for me. I don't want my kid to feel pressured to follow a path they don't want to.

Mark and Vanessa, they seem like they'd let the kid be whoever they want to be. A musician, an artist, a professional skateboarder, I don't know. As long as they're happy.

It's not about judging other people's lifestyles. It's about wanting my kid to have the freedom to choose their own. And I think Mark and Vanessa would give them that.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple decision. But I want the best for this kid, and I think they'd be really happy with Mark and Vanessa. They just...feel right.

And honestly? It's a little bit about wanting someone who will understand that sometimes, life doesn't go according to plan. And that's okay.

Ugh. Okay, so, hypothetically speaking, if I decided to…keep the baby. Which, like, I haven’t decided anything yet, okay? Just thinking out loud. But if I did… it wouldn’t be all sunshine and rainbows, that’s for sure.

First off, school. Seriously. I’m a junior. I’m supposed to be thinking about colleges and SATs and, like, figuring out my life. A baby kinda throws a wrench in those plans. I’d probably have to drop out, or at least take a really long break. And then what?

Then there’s the money thing. My dad’s a construction worker, and my stepmom’s a realtor. They’re good people, but they’re not exactly rolling in dough. I don’t want to be a burden. I’d have to get a job, which means less time for, well, everything. And daycare is expensive. Like, ridiculously expensive.

And then there’s the whole…growing up thing. I’m sixteen. I’m still figuring out who *I* am. I’m not exactly ready to be a mom. I mean, I can barely keep my room clean, let alone raise a human being.

And Paul? He’s…Paul. He’s a good guy, but he’s not exactly equipped to be a dad either. We’re both still kids, basically.

And then there’s the judgment. People talking. Whispering. Judging. I’m already kind of an outsider, and this would just make it worse.

It’s not that I don’t think I could *love* the baby. I know I could. It’s just…it’s a huge responsibility. And I’m not sure I’m ready for it. It would change my life completely. And I’m not sure I’m willing to give up my life, not yet anyway.

It’s just…a lot to think about. A *lot*. And it’s not a decision I can take lightly. It’s not like returning a sweater. This is a person. A whole entire person. And that’s…scary.



So yeah. Those are some of the things. It’s not a simple situation, okay? Don’t judge me for even considering it. It’s complicated.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. She meant well, she really did. But sometimes her ideas are…a lot. When I told her I was thinking about adoption, she got this look on her face, like I'd just announced I was joining the circus.

She immediately started going on about how we could, like, *co-parent*. With Mark. Which, honestly, was the last thing I wanted to hear. Like, imagine me, a seventeen-year-old, trying to raise a baby with the guy who can barely remember to bring his own lunch to school. It was a disaster waiting to happen.

She kept saying how we could make it work, how Mark's parents had a big house, and how we could all be a "family." She even started picturing Christmas mornings and soccer practice. It was…intense.

She also suggested, and this was the really out-there one, that I could just…keep the baby and finish high school. Like it was no big deal. Like I could just magically balance algebra, band practice, and a newborn. Seriously? She was living in a fantasy world.

It was a lot to process, and it just made me even more sure that adoption was the right choice. It wasn't what *I* wanted, but it was the best thing for the baby. And honestly, it was probably the best thing for me and Mark too. We were kids. We weren't ready. Leah just…didn't quite get that.

Ugh. Okay, look. That was…not my finest moment. And I get why people would be, like, rightfully annoyed with me. It wasn't cool.

It's just…I was feeling really awkward and overwhelmed, okay? I was pregnant, and everything was changing, and I was trying to act like I wasn't terrified. And those women…they were just so…*intense* about their kids. Like, helicopter parenting to the extreme. And I was just trying to deflect, to make myself feel better by making them the butt of the joke.

It was a defense mechanism. A really bad one. I know that.

I didn't mean to be mean. I just…I was scared and insecure and trying to cope in the only way I knew how at the time, which was with sarcasm and a whole lot of attitude.

I'm not proud of it. And I definitely learned a lesson. It's not okay to make fun of people, especially when they're just trying to be good parents.

It was a stupid thing to do. And I apologized to Paul later. He was right to call me out on it. He always is.

Honestly, sometimes I just say things without thinking. It's a flaw. I'm working on it. But yeah, that was a moment I'd rather forget. It just…happened. And I regret it.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still talking about that? It was…complicated. And honestly, a little mortifying, even now.
