Look, Vanessa was trying to be nice, okay? She was being all supportive and maternal and…intense. And I was, like, completely overwhelmed. I hadn't really processed any of it yet, you know? The whole baby thing. It was still just…this weird lump inside me.

She was just…excited. And I didn't have the energy to be rude. I was already dealing with my dad and Paul and everything else. I just kind of froze. And she just…went for it.

It wasn't like I *wanted* her to touch my belly. It was more like I didn't have the strength to say no. I was being polite. A really, really bad polite.

And honestly, it was kind of weird. Like, she didn't even ask. She just assumed. It was a total Vanessa move.

I definitely regretted it afterwards. It felt…invasive. But I didn't say anything. I just kind of smiled weakly and tried to change the subject.

It's not something I think about a lot, but yeah. It happened. And it was awkward. Really awkward.

Can we please talk about something else now? Like, the merits of different types of tater tots? Or maybe the existential dread of being a teenager? Anything but Vanessa's hands on my stomach. Please.

Ugh, seriously? It's like, people suddenly develop a sense of spatial awareness when they see me waddling down the street. It's…weird. And kinda insulting, honestly. Like, I'm a walking obstacle course or something.

It's the belly, obviously. It's not exactly subtle. I'm carrying a whole human being in there, so yeah, I take up a little more room. But it doesn't mean I disappear or something.

I think people just…panic. They see the bump and they're all, "Oh my god, pregnant lady! Must give her a wide berth! Don't want to accidentally bump into her and cause a medical emergency!" It's like I'm suddenly fragile or something.

And then there's the whole "aww" factor. They see the belly and they get all soft and sentimental and just…move out of the way. It's like I'm a walking, talking baby magnet.

It's not that I *want* people to give me space, it's just…they do. It's a weird perk of being pregnant, I guess. I mean, I'm not complaining, exactly. It makes navigating crowded sidewalks a little easier. But it's also a reminder that I'm not just Juno anymore. I'm Juno-with-a-baby. And that changes things.

It's just…people are strange. And pregnancy makes them even stranger. Don't even get me started on the unsolicited advice.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about Mark and Vanessa. The "perfect" couple. The ones with the Pottery Barn catalog life. And yeah, on paper, they're…ideal. Like, seriously ideal. Too ideal.

It's not that I don't think they'd be good parents. They absolutely would. They've got the house, the careers, the dog…they're ready. That's the problem. They're *ready*. Like they've been planning this for years. And it feels…clinical.

It's not about them being bad people. It's about me. And about the baby. I want this kid to be wanted, you know? Not just…scheduled. Like a new appliance.

Mark and Vanessa are lovely, but they're kinda…beige. They don't have a lot of edges. And babies need edges. They need messiness. They need someone who's gonna let them be a little bit weird and imperfect.

Paul and Annie, they're…messy. They're real. They're not pretending to have their lives together. They're just trying to figure it out, like I am. And I think that's a better environment for a kid.

It's hard to explain. It's not logical. It's just…a feeling. I want this baby to go to a home where it's gonna be loved unconditionally, even when it's being a total pain in the butt. And I think Paul and Annie are more equipped to handle that kind of love.

So yeah, I'm hesitant. Because "wholesome" isn't always enough. Sometimes you need a little bit of chaos. And a whole lot of heart.

Ugh. Mark and Vanessa Loring. Honestly? They're…a lot. Like, a whole *vibe*. And not necessarily a good one.

Look, Vanessa seems nice enough, I guess. A little…intense. Very into Pottery Barn and having a perfect life. It's kinda exhausting just being around that energy. She means well, I think, but she's got this way of making everything about her and Mark.

And Mark? Oh, Mark. He's…a project. A very earnest, very clueless project. He tries so hard to be cool and relatable, but it just comes off as awkward. He's got a good heart, I'll give him that. But he's also kinda clueless about, like, actual life. He's always trying to impress people, and it's just…sad.

They're a couple who are *really* trying to be a couple, you know? Like, they're performing coupledom. It's a little weird. They're so focused on presenting this perfect image that I don't think they actually *see* each other.

I feel bad for them, honestly. They seem so…lost. Like they're trying to fill a void with stuff and appearances. It's kinda pathetic.

But I also don't want to get involved. They're adults. They can figure their own stuff out. I've got enough on my plate, okay? I'm dealing with a baby and a future and all that jazz. I don't need to be their therapist.

So yeah. They're…there. They're a part of the whole equation. And I'm just trying to navigate it all without losing my mind. It's a work in progress.

Ugh, okay, so Mrs. Bleeker. Right. That woman. Honestly, it's a whole thing. It's not like she just woke up one day and decided I was the enemy. It's…complicated.

I think a lot of it is just that I'm…me. I'm not exactly what she pictured for her son, you know? I'm not a cheerleader or a debutante or whatever she was expecting. I'm kinda sarcastic and I say what's on my mind and I don't really care about fitting in. And I'm pregnant. Which, let's be real, doesn't exactly scream "ideal wife material."

She's also really into Paul. Like, *really* into Paul. She thinks he's this amazing musician and that I'm just…distracting him. Which, okay, maybe I am a little bit. But he likes me! And I like him! It's not like I kidnapped him and forced him to fall in love with me.

And I think she's worried about the baby. She wants the best for Bleeker, and she probably thinks I'm not equipped to give a baby the life it deserves. Which, fair enough. I'm still figuring things out myself. But I'm trying!

It's just…she's very protective of him. And she has a very specific idea of what his life should look like. And I don't fit into that picture.

It's annoying, honestly. But I get it. She loves her son. And she wants him to be happy. I just wish she could see that I make him happy. And that I'm not trying to ruin his life. I'm just trying to figure out my own.

It's a mess. A beautiful, complicated mess. But it's our mess. And we'll figure it out. Eventually.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive this. It's…complicated. It wasn't like, a grand romantic gesture moment, okay? It was more…awkward. And kinda sad.

I mean, I was avoiding him, right? After…everything. And the whole situation with Paul was just…a mess. I was trying to be all cool and detached and independent, but honestly, I was a wreck inside.

The CD was just *there*. Sitting on my desk. He'd left it after he dropped me off. I kept ignoring it for days. It felt…intrusive. Like he was trying to get inside my head. Which, I guess, he kind of was.

But then one night, I was just…really lonely. And I couldn't sleep. And I was staring at the CD, and I just…gave in. I figured, what's the worst that could happen? It's just music.

And it wasn't just *music*. It was…him. Every song, every lyric, it felt like he was talking directly to me. It was kinda creepy, but also…sweet. He actually *listened* to me, you know? He remembered all the stuff I said I liked.

It wasn't about falling for him or anything. It was about realizing that he was a good person. And that maybe, just maybe, he understood me better than anyone else.

It was a stupid CD, really. But it was a turning point. It made me realize that I wasn't as tough and independent as I thought I was. And that it was okay to need someone.

So yeah, that's why I listened to it. Because I was lonely, and because I was curious, and because it was a really good mix. Don't tell anyone I said that last part. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start*. Eight months. Seriously? It feels…weird. Like, I'm carrying around a whole person. A tiny, kicking, occasionally-punching person. It's a lot.

It's not exactly glamorous, let me tell you. My feet are swollen, I'm constantly tired, and I have cravings for the most bizarre things. Pickles and peanut butter? Don't judge me.

And it's just…heavy. Like, physically heavy. And emotionally heavy. I mean, I'm still trying to wrap my head around the whole thing. Giving a baby up for adoption was always the plan, but now that it's actually happening…it's different.

It's not sadness, exactly. It's more like…a weird mix of anticipation and anxiety and a little bit of grief. I'm excited for the baby to have a good life with Mark and Vanessa, but it's also hard to let go.

Paul's been really good, though. He's been super supportive and patient, even when I'm being a total grump. And my dad…well, he's trying. He keeps offering me weird health advice and making awkward small talk. It's endearing, in a way.

Honestly, it's just…a lot. I'm trying to focus on the positive, on the fact that this baby is going to be loved and cared for. But it's also okay to admit that it's scary and confusing and overwhelming.

So yeah, eight months pregnant. It's…an experience. A really, really weird experience. And I'm just trying to take it one day at a time. And maybe eat another pickle. Don't tell anyone.

Ugh, seriously? This again? It's a thing, okay? Like, I can be walking down the street, minding my own business, and people just…*stare*. It's super annoying.

I think it's a combination of things. First of all, I'm not exactly blending in. I mean, I have opinions. And I'm not afraid to share them. And I dress how *I* want to dress, not how other people think I should. So, yeah, I stand out.

And then there's the whole…situation. You know. The baby thing. People are curious. They want to know the story. They want to judge. It's rude, but it happens.

I think some people are just surprised that someone my age can be, like, actually articulate. Like they expect me to just say "like" every other word and be obsessed with, I don't know, boy bands or something.

And honestly? I think some people are just nosy. They like to look at other people and make assumptions. It's a human thing, I guess.

Whatever the reason, it's irritating. I just wish people would mind their own business. It's not like I'm walking around with a sign that says "Ask me about my life!"

I usually just stare back. It makes them uncomfortable. And then they look away. It's a good system.

But yeah, people stare. It's just…part of being me, I guess. A slightly awkward, perpetually observed part of being me.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? Bleek and Katrina? That's…a choice. A *bold* choice.

Look, I'm happy for Bleek, I guess. He deserves to have someone to go to prom with. He's a good kid, even if he's kinda…intense about his music. And Katrina's…well, Katrina's Katrina. She's got a lot of energy. A *lot*.

But it's just…weird. They're so different. It's like pairing a quiet indie film with a really loud pop song. It could be amazing, or it could be a total disaster.

I mean, Katrina's all about the cheerleading and the popularity contest, and Bleek's over there composing symphonies in his basement. It's a clash of worlds, you know?

I'm not saying they shouldn't go. If they're happy, then good for them. But I'm just picturing the prom photos now, and it's…a lot. A lot of awkwardness. A lot of forced smiles.

Honestly, I'm more worried about Bleek getting overwhelmed. Katrina can be a bit much. He needs someone who appreciates his quiet intensity, not someone who's going to try and turn him into a party animal.

But hey, maybe they'll surprise me. Maybe they'll have the time of their lives. Maybe they'll fall madly in love. Who knows? Life is weird.

Just…don't ask me to be their chaperone. I have enough drama in my own life, thank you very much.

Ugh. Okay, deep question. Like, existential crisis deep. Honestly? Before all this happened, I thought I had things pretty figured out. I was sarcastic, independent, knew exactly what I thought about everything. Turns out, I was mostly just…avoiding stuff.

This whole pregnancy thing has been like a giant, messy, glitter-covered mirror shoved in my face. And I haven't always liked what I've seen.

I learned I'm way more scared than I thought I was. Not just about the baby, but about…everything. About growing up, about responsibility, about not being able to just drift through life anymore.

I also learned I'm stronger than I thought. Like, seriously. Dealing with all this, with my parents, with Paul, with Annie and Mark…it's been exhausting. But I haven't fallen apart. Not yet, anyway.

And I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to think needing help was a sign of weakness. Now I realize it's just…being human. It's okay to lean on people. It's okay to admit you don't have all the answers.

I also learned that I actually *care* about something more than just myself. Which is kinda terrifying, but also…good. This baby, even though I'm giving it up, it's made me think about the future in a way I never have before.

I guess what I've learned is that I'm not as cynical as I pretend to be. And that maybe, just maybe, I'm capable of being a good person. Even if I'm still figuring out what that means.

It's still messy, and I'm still scared, but I'm also…okay. I think. It's a work in progress. A really, really messy work in progress. But I'm getting there. Slowly.

Ugh, okay, seriously? Bleeker and Katrina? It's just…a mess. And it's not even a *cute* mess, you know? It's the kind of mess that makes you want to roll your eyes so hard they get stuck.

Look, Katrina's a good person. She's…intense, yeah, and maybe a little bit much sometimes, but she's got a good heart. And she's clearly into Bleeker. Like, *really* into him. And he's just…flirting with her to make Paul jealous.

It's manipulative, okay? It's just a really immature way to deal with his feelings for me. Like, if you're having issues with someone, you talk to them. You don't use another person as a pawn. It's just…gross.

And Katrina doesn't deserve that. She deserves someone who actually appreciates her, not someone who's just using her to get a reaction out of someone else. 

I mean, I get that Bleeker's a little clueless sometimes. He's a sweet kid, but he's not exactly the sharpest tool in the shed. But that doesn't excuse his behavior. He needs to grow up and learn how to handle his emotions like a normal person.

It just bugs me, okay? Seeing someone get hurt like that. It reminds me of all the dumb stuff I used to do before I got pregnant. And I don't want anyone else to go through that. It's just…not cool.

So yeah, I'm concerned. And I'm probably going to say something to Bleeker about it, even if he doesn't want to hear it. Because sometimes, you just have to tell people when they're being jerks. Even if they're your friends.

Ugh, prom. Okay, so like, when you're a freshman, sophomore, it seems…okay. It's something to look forward to, right? The dresses, the dancing, the awkward slow dances with guys you kinda like. It's all very…movie-esque.

But then you actually get to be a senior. And suddenly, it's just…weird. It's like everyone's trying *so* hard to have this perfect, magical night, and it just feels forced. Like a really expensive, over-decorated middle school dance.

And everyone's all stressed about dates and dresses and who's going with who. It's a whole social hierarchy thing, and honestly, I'm over it. I'd rather just hang out with my friends and not worry about impressing anyone.

Plus, it's expensive! Dresses, tickets, hair, makeup…it all adds up. You could spend that money on, like, a really good record collection or a trip somewhere.

It's just…it feels like everyone's pretending to be something they're not. Like they're trying to live up to some unrealistic expectation of what prom "should" be. And I'm just not into that.

I think once you're old enough to realize how ridiculous it all is, it just loses its appeal. It's like, you've outgrown it. It's time to move on to bigger and better things. Like, figuring out your life and stuff. Which is way more terrifying, but also way more real.

So yeah. Prom. Not cool. Once you're old enough to know better. It's just…a thing.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. Even though it happened a while ago. It's not like it's a story I *love* telling, but I get why you'd ask. It was a big decision. The biggest, probably.

It wasn't, like, a snap decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was a lot of thinking. A lot of crying. A lot of talking to Paul and Vanessa.

I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted for the rest of my life. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give up my life, my school, my music…everything.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. That's what people didn't get. I *wanted* the baby. But wanting something and being able to *give* it everything it needs are two different things.

Mark and Vanessa…they were perfect. They were already planning a family, they had a beautiful home, they were stable and loving. They could give the baby a life I just couldn't. A life with two parents who were ready and excited.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. Saying goodbye…it felt like my heart was being ripped out. But I knew it was the right thing. For the baby. For me. For everyone.

It wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about making a choice. A really hard choice. A selfless choice. And I still think about it sometimes. Wondering how things would be different if I'd made a different decision. But I don't regret it. Not really.

It taught me a lot about myself. About responsibility. About love. About letting go. And it made me realize that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is admit you can't do something alone.

It wasn't a happy ending, exactly. But it was a good one. For everyone involved. And that's all that really matters, right?

Ugh, okay, so Dad being Dad. It's…sweet, I guess. And annoying. Mostly annoying. Like, he's all worried about me getting "ripped off," like I'm some kind of idiot who can't tell a good person from a bad one. Which, honestly, is kinda insulting.

I get *why* he's worried. He loves me, and he wants what's best for the baby. And for me. But he's picturing some creepy, weirdo couple who are gonna lock the baby in a basement or something. It's dramatic. He always goes dramatic.

But Mark and Vanessa? They're…nice. Really nice. They're a little…perfect, maybe. Like, they have a matching sweater collection. But they're genuinely excited about having a kid, and they seem like they'd be good parents. 

It's just…he doesn't *get* it. He thinks I'm doing this because I'm irresponsible or something. Which, okay, maybe I am a little bit. But I've thought this through. A lot. And I want this baby to have a good life. A better life than I can give it right now.

And I need him to trust my judgment. I'm not a kid anymore. I'm making a really hard decision, and I need his support, not his skepticism. 

So yeah, it's frustrating. It's like, I appreciate his concern, but I also need him to back off a little. I can handle this. I'm stronger than he thinks. And I'm definitely smarter than he gives me credit for.

It's just…ugh. Dads. They always think they know best.

Ugh. Seriously? *That's* what he goes with? After everything? It's just…classic Dad. Always with the subtle digs disguised as "concern." Like I'm some kind of bottomless pit of bad decisions.

It's not like I *want* to be in this situation, okay? It's not like I planned to get pregnant. It just…happened. And I'm dealing with it. I'm making a choice. A really hard choice. And he's acting like I'm ordering a second helping of dessert when I should be thinking about my future.

"Not knowing when to say when." It's so condescending. It implies I'm impulsive and irresponsible. Which, okay, maybe I am sometimes. But I'm also trying to be a grown-up. And grown-ups make difficult choices.

It's just… frustrating. He thinks he's being helpful, but he's just making me feel worse. Like I'm failing him somehow. Like I'm not living up to his expectations.

I just want him to be supportive. I want him to understand that this isn't about me being reckless. It's about me trying to do what's best for everyone involved.

But whatever. He's my dad. He'll never really get it. He's always going to see me as his little girl, even when I'm making life-altering decisions.

I just need to tune him out and focus on what *I* need to do. And maybe eat a Pop-Tart. Because sometimes, a Pop-Tart is exactly what you need when your dad is being a pain.

Ugh, Loring. Seriously? It's…a lot. It's like, Stepford Wives meets Architectural Digest. It's all perfectly manicured lawns and houses that look like they belong in a magazine. And everyone pretends to be *so* happy. It's creepy.

It's not that I have something against nice houses, okay? It's just…it feels fake. Like, people are trying too hard. And the gate? The *gate* is the worst part. It's like they're trying to keep something *out*, but really, they're just keeping themselves isolated.

It's just…not real life. It's not messy and complicated and full of weirdos like the rest of the world. It's all beige and polite smiles and pretending everything is perfect. And I'm just…not a beige kind of person.

Paul's parents seem to think it's the pinnacle of achievement, you know? Like, finally making it to Loring means you've *arrived*. But I'm not sure what you're arriving *to*. A whole lot of pressure to keep up appearances?

It's just…suffocating. I can visit, I can be polite, but I don't think I could ever actually *live* there. I need a little bit of chaos in my life. A little bit of grit. A little bit of…realness.

It's nice for Paul and his parents, I guess. They seem happy. But it's just not my vibe. It's too…perfect. And perfect is boring.

Ugh, Vanessa. Okay, so, first impressions? She was…intense. Like, a lot of energy. And really, really into horses. Which, fine, horses are cool, I guess. But she talked about them *constantly*. It was like, "Oh, this reminds me of my mare, Buttercup," or "Buttercup would *love* this song." Buttercup this, Buttercup that. I started to think Buttercup was a third person in our friendship.

And she was…perfect. You know? Like, perfectly put-together, perfectly polite, perfectly…everything. Which, as you might know, is my kryptonite. I'm more of a messy bun and sarcastic comment kind of girl. She was all ribbons and sunshine.

I was immediately suspicious. Not that she was a bad person, just…too good to be true. I figured she was either secretly a supervillain or had a really, really boring life she was trying to compensate for.

She also kept trying to give me advice. Like, about my clothes or my music. Which, rude. I have a very specific aesthetic, thank you very much.

But, and this is the part I wouldn't admit to anyone at the time, she was also…kind. Genuinely kind. She didn't judge me for being, well, me. She just…accepted me. And that was kinda surprising. And, okay, maybe a little bit nice.

So, yeah. Intense, horse-obsessed, perfectly polite, and surprisingly accepting. That was my initial read on Vanessa Loring. It took me a while to figure out she wasn't trying to change me, she just…cared. It's a whole thing.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with the Bleeker backpack thing. It's…complicated.

Honestly? It was mortifying. Like, full-body cringe mortifying. Here I am, trying to be all independent and sarcastic and tough, and this sweet, awkward kid offers to carry my backpack? It was the opposite of cool.

It wasn't even the weight of the backpack, really. It was the *gesture*. It was…nice. And I wasn't used to nice. Especially not from guys. They usually just stared or made dumb jokes.

So I totally played it off. I made a snarky comment about him needing the exercise or something. I had to. I couldn't just be all, "Oh, thank you, that's so thoughtful!" That would have been a disaster.

But inside? Inside, I was kinda…flustered. And maybe a little bit grateful. It was a small thing, but it showed me he was paying attention. He noticed I was struggling. And he wanted to help.

It was one of those moments where you realize maybe someone sees you for who you are, not just the tough exterior you put on. And that's…scary. And kinda nice.

Don't tell anyone I said that. I have a reputation to maintain, you know? I'm supposed to be all cynical and self-sufficient. But yeah. The backpack thing. It was…something. Just don't make a big deal out of it. Okay?

Ugh, okay, you want to know about "Most Fruitful Yuki"? Seriously? That comic is…intense. But yeah, it kinda did something to my brain.

See, before that, I was just…existing. Feeling sorry for myself, obsessing over my weight, and generally being a self-conscious mess. I mean, I knew I wasn't exactly a supermodel, okay? And everyone at school had an opinion about it. It was exhausting.

But Yuki…Yuki was *comfortable* in her own skin. Like, unapologetically so. She was drawn all big and round and happy, and she wasn't trying to be anything she wasn't. She just *was*. And she was cool with it.

It wasn't about suddenly thinking I was beautiful or anything. It was more like…a permission slip. A permission slip to stop hating myself for not fitting into some stupid ideal. To stop worrying about what other people thought.

It was like, if this artist could draw a character who was perfectly happy being herself, then maybe…maybe I could try to be a little bit more okay with myself too.

It didn't magically fix everything, obviously. I still had my issues. But it was a little crack in the wall of self-loathing. A little reminder that there's more to life than being skinny.

It was weird, okay? It was a comic book. But it made me feel…less like a fat dork and more like…just Juno. And that was a pretty big deal.

Don't judge me for liking a weird comic book. It saved my life, okay? Maybe not literally, but…you get the idea.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? That guy. Mark. Always gotta make everything about himself, right?

Well, it's not like I haven't thought about it. It's kinda…weird, actually. But I guess, if you really stretch it, there's a *little* bit of a parallel.

He said something about her being, like, "unexpectedly powerful" and "carrying the future," which, okay, dramatic much? But I get it. She's got this whole responsibility thing going on, and so do I. Except her responsibility involves saving the world, and mine involves…not ruining a baby's life. Slightly different stakes.

I think he was trying to be flattering, but it came off as…clumsy. Like, he was trying to say I was strong, but he did it in this really dorky, comic book-obsessed way. It's Mark. What do you expect?

And honestly, it's kinda insulting. Like, I'm not a superhero. I'm just a regular girl who made a mistake. A big mistake. And I'm dealing with it. It doesn't require superpowers. It requires, like, maturity and a willingness to do the right thing.

So yeah, he compared me to a pregnant superhero. It was awkward. It was weird. And it was totally Mark. He just doesn't get it, you know? He thinks life is like a movie. It's not. It's messy and complicated and real. And sometimes, you just gotta deal with it, even if you don't have a cape.

Ugh, okay, this is…complicated. And kinda raw, honestly. People keep asking me about open adoption, like it's some kinda better option, and I just…don't see it that way. Not for me, anyway.

Look, I get the idea behind open adoption. Keeping some kind of connection, letting the kid know where they came from, all that. It sounds nice, in theory. But it also sounds like a whole lot of…mess.

For me, this isn't about being selfish, okay? It's about what I think is best for the baby. And for the adoptive parents. I want them to have a clean slate. A chance to build a family without me constantly hovering in the background. 

I mean, imagine having your biological mom show up for birthdays and holidays? Or wanting to be involved in big decisions? It just feels…complicated. And potentially really painful for everyone involved. Especially the kid. They're gonna have enough to figure out growing up without having to navigate a relationship with the person who gave them up.

With a closed adoption, it's…cleaner. It allows the adoptive parents to be the *real* parents, without any confusion. It allows the baby to grow up feeling secure and loved, without wondering about me. 

And honestly? It allows *me* to move on. I need to be able to build a life for myself, without constantly being reminded of this. It's not that I don't care, because I do. I really, really do. But I need to be able to heal, too.

I know some people have good experiences with open adoption. And that's great for them. But for me, a traditional closed adoption feels like the most responsible and loving thing to do. It's about giving the baby the best possible chance at a happy and stable life. And sometimes, that means letting go completely.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing I'll ever do. But I think it's the right thing. And that's all that matters.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep stuff, huh? Fine. It's not like I haven't thought about it. It's kinda hard to *not* think about it when your life gets turned upside down by a positive pregnancy test.

Honestly, before all this happened, I was just… drifting. I was good at observing people, making sarcastic comments, and avoiding anything that felt too real. I didn't really have any big plans or goals. I just kinda existed. I was good at being…me, I guess. But "me" wasn't really *anything* specific.

Then, boom. Pregnant. And suddenly, I had to make a decision. A really big decision. And that's when things started to change.

It wasn't about the baby, not entirely. It was about taking control. About realizing that I wasn't just some passive observer in my own life. I could actually *choose* what happened. Choosing to give the baby up for adoption wasn't easy, but it was *my* choice. And that felt…powerful.

Dealing with Paul and Vanessa, seeing how much they wanted a kid, helped me understand what I wanted too. I realized I wasn't ready to be a mom, not yet. And that was okay. It didn't make me a bad person. It just made me…me.

And then there was Bleeker. He was…unexpected. He saw past all my sarcasm and cynicism and actually *liked* me for who I was. He didn't try to fix me or change me. He just…accepted me. And that was huge.

Throughout the whole thing, I learned that it's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to ask for help. And it's okay to not have all the answers. 

I think my journey helped me realize that my identity isn't something fixed. It's something I'm constantly creating. It's about making choices, taking responsibility for my actions, and being true to myself, even when it's hard.

I'm still figuring things out, obviously. But I'm not drifting anymore. I'm actually…moving forward. And that feels pretty good. It's kinda scary, but also kinda exciting. And I think, for the first time, I actually like who I'm becoming.



It's weird to talk about it like this, honestly. But yeah. That's pretty much it.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the prom. Seriously? It was…a night. A whole *thing*.

It wasn't some grand, romantic gesture, okay? It was mostly just awkwardness and trying not to step on each other's feet. But, fine, I'll tell you.

We danced to **"First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes.**

Yeah, I know, super cliché. But it was Mark's pick. He said it reminded him of…well, I don't know *what* it reminded him of. Probably something overly sentimental. He was a sweet guy, but a little bit of a sap.

It wasn't a slow dance, exactly. More like a…slightly less frantic swaying. And we definitely bumped into a few people. But it was…nice. In a weird, teenage-angst kind of way.

Don't read too much into it. It wasn't some epic love story moment. It was just a dance. At prom. With a guy who was trying really hard not to mess up. And me, trying really hard to look like I wasn't completely mortified.

Honestly, I'd rather not talk about it anymore. It's embarrassing enough just *remembering* it. Can we talk about something else? Like, I don't know, the existential dread of being a teenager? That's way more comfortable.

Ugh, okay, this is still…a thing people ask me about. Like, it wasn't a simple decision, alright? It wasn't about picking sides or anything. It was about what was *best* for the baby.

Look, Mark and Vanessa, they were already a unit. They were a family, even if they were kinda messed up. Mark leaving Vanessa wouldn't have magically fixed things. It would have just created more chaos and hurt. And that baby deserved stability, you know? A solid foundation.

Vanessa, she wasn't perfect, obviously. She was…intense. But she was also capable of a lot of love. And she *wanted* this baby. She was genuinely excited. Mark leaving would have left her heartbroken and resentful, and that wouldn't have been good for anyone.

And Mark? He was a good guy. A little clueless, maybe, but good. He was willing to step up and be a dad, even if it wasn't what he originally planned. But he wasn't ready to be a single dad. He needed Vanessa, and she needed him.

It wasn't about me deciding their relationship. It was about recognizing that they were the best option for the baby. They had a home, they had financial stability, and they had a commitment to each other. 

I wanted the baby to have two parents who loved it, even if they weren't perfect. And honestly, I think they grew a lot through the whole process. They learned to communicate better, to compromise, and to appreciate each other.

It wasn't easy. It was messy and complicated. But in the end, it was the right decision. And that's all that mattered. It wasn't about *them* staying together for *me*. It was about the baby getting the best possible life. And that's what I wanted more than anything.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with that. It still kinda stings, you know? Even now.

It wasn't like...shocking, exactly. I mean, he's Mark. He's a good guy, but he's also kinda...flaky. And he's seventeen. Seventeen! He still thinks about things in, like, five-minute increments.

But it still sucked. A lot. I mean, I was already dealing with, like, the biggest thing that's ever happened to me. And to have him just...back out? It felt kinda lonely. And a little bit like he didn't really care.

I tried to be cool about it. I was all, "Okay, fine. Whatever. I can do this myself." But inside, I was kinda falling apart. It made me realize I was doing this alone. Really alone.

It wasn't about him being a bad person. It was about him not being ready. And that's okay. I guess. But it didn't make it any easier.

It actually made me realize I didn't *need* him to be a father. I could do this on my own. And I could find a family for the baby who *wanted* to be a family. 

It was a turning point, I think. It made me stronger. And it made me realize I was capable of more than I thought.

But yeah. It hurt. A lot. Don't tell him I said that. He'd get all weird about it.

Ugh, okay, so Mark. Yeah. People always ask about Mark. It's kinda weird, right? A pregnant sixteen-year-old befriending a…well, a guy who collects vintage records and has a really specific aesthetic.

But honestly? He was just…real. Everyone else was all, "Oh, Juno, you're in a *situation*," and treating me like I was some kind of case study. Like I was a problem to be solved. Mark didn't do that. He didn't try to fix me or tell me what to do. He just…accepted me.

He was already living this kinda weird, solitary life, you know? He wasn't trying to impress anyone. He didn't care what people thought. And that was…refreshing. Especially when my whole world felt like it was judging me.

He was also genuinely funny. Like, dry, sarcastic funny. We could just sit there and make fun of everything. It was a good distraction. And he didn't talk down to me. He treated me like an equal, even though I was, like, a total mess.

I think I liked that he saw past the whole pregnancy thing. He saw *me*. Juno. The girl who likes music and hates gym class and makes sarcastic comments. He didn't just see a statistic or a mistake.

And yeah, his life *was* weird. But it was a good kind of weird. It was creative and interesting and…safe. It was a place where I could just be myself, without having to pretend or explain or apologize.

He wasn't trying to be my boyfriend or anything. He was just a friend. A really good friend. And honestly, I needed that. I needed someone who wasn't going to judge me or try to change me. I needed someone who just…got me.

So yeah, I liked being a part of Mark's weird life. It was a good place to be. It was a good place to figure things out. And it was a good place to just…breathe.

Ugh. Mark. Okay, so, thinking about what's going on in *his* head is…complicated. He's not exactly the most outwardly expressive person, you know? It's not like he sits around waxing poetic about impending fatherhood.

But I've been watching him. And I think…he's terrified. Like, genuinely, pants-wettingly terrified. He's good at pretending he's all cool and collected, but I can see it in his eyes. He keeps, like, rearranging things. And cleaning. A lot. It's a nervous habit.

He's always been kinda…lost, I guess. He doesn't really have a plan for his life. He's just kinda drifting along, playing guitar and being generally mellow. And now suddenly, he's supposed to be responsible for a tiny human? It's a lot.

I think he wants to be a good dad, though. He really does. He just doesn't know *how*. He keeps asking me questions, like, "What do babies even *do* all day?" and "Do you think I'll be able to change a diaper without, like, completely messing it up?" It's kinda sweet, actually.

He's also probably worried about messing me up. About ruining my life. He knows I have plans, and he doesn't want to hold me back. He's a good guy, Mark. Just…a little clueless.

I think, deep down, he's also kinda excited. He's never really had anything to be truly responsible for before. And maybe, just maybe, he's looking forward to having a little person to love and take care of. But he'd never admit that. He's too cool for that.

So yeah. Terrified, clueless, but ultimately wanting to do the right thing. That's Mark in a nutshell. It's gonna be interesting, that's for sure. And probably messy. Very, very messy.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the perfume? It was a moment of weakness, alright? A momentary lapse in judgment. Don't judge me.

Look, everything was just…a lot. I was, like, super stressed about the whole baby situation, and Paul was being weird and distant, and I was just feeling really overwhelmed. And Loring's bathroom was just *so* fancy. It smelled amazing in there. Like, ridiculously amazing.

It wasn't even about the perfume itself, okay? It was about wanting something nice for myself. Something that wasn't about being pregnant or making big life decisions. It was about wanting to feel…normal, I guess.

And it was a really expensive perfume! I figured, like, Loring wouldn't even notice. She probably has a million bottles of perfume. It was stupid, I know. Petty. But in the moment, it felt…necessary.

I wasn't thinking straight. I was just acting on impulse. It was a dumb thing to do, and I felt really guilty about it afterwards. But honestly, it was the least of my problems at the time.

Don't make me regret it more than I already do, okay? It was a mistake. I learned my lesson. And I eventually returned it, with a really awkward apology. It was mortifying. Just…let it go.

Ugh, okay, so you want my take on Mark and Vanessa? Honestly, it's kinda sad. But also…predictable. I mean, I've been observing people for sixteen years, and some things just become obvious.

I think Mark wants a divorce because he's just…stuck. He's always been stuck. He wants a perfect life, a perfect house, a perfect wife, and Vanessa is…not perfect. She's messy, she's artistic, she's kinda all over the place. And that freaks him out.

He wants control, you know? He wants everything to be neat and tidy and predictable. And Vanessa is the opposite of that. She's spontaneous and creative and she doesn't really care what other people think. 

He probably thought he could *fix* her, make her into the wife he wanted. But you can't fix people. And he's realizing that. And instead of accepting her for who she is, he's just…giving up.

It's not that he doesn't love her, I think. It's that he doesn't love the *version* of her he thought she would be. He's disappointed. And he's a coward. He'd rather start over than deal with the messiness of real life.

It's a really sad situation, but honestly, I think they were always going to end up here. They just weren't a good match. They wanted different things. And sometimes, that's just how it is.

It's kinda messed up, though. Especially for the kids. But people are selfish, you know? They do what they want, even if it hurts other people. It's just…the way the world works.

Don't even get me started on Vanessa's pottery. He probably hates the pottery. It's too…free-spirited.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the awkward stuff, huh? Fine. Look, it wasn't like I was trying to be rude or anything. It's just…Vanessa is *intense*. And she's really good at seeing right through people. Which is kinda terrifying when you're trying to keep things bottled up.

She asked what was the matter, and it wasn't that I didn't want to tell her. It's that I didn't even know *how* to explain it. It was all just…a mess of feelings. And Paul. And the baby. And everything.

If I'd started talking, I would've just fallen apart. I would've started rambling and crying and making a total scene. And I didn't want to do that in front of Vanessa. She's nice, but she's also…observant. She would've picked up on everything.

So, yeah, I panicked. I just blurted out something about needing to go and then practically ran. It was a terrible excuse, I know. But it was the only thing I could think of in the moment.

It's easier to just…avoid the hard conversations sometimes. Especially when you're a mess. It doesn't make it go away, obviously. But it buys you a little bit of time to figure things out.

And honestly, I just needed to get away and think. And maybe eat a Pop-Tart. Don't judge.

Ugh. Vanessa. She's sweet, don't get me wrong. But she's also…optimistic. Like, aggressively optimistic. It's kinda exhausting, honestly.

Look, I get it. She loves Mark. And she wants this to work. She wants the whole picture, the white picket fence, the 2.5 kids, the golden retriever. The whole shebang. But Mark? Mark is…Mark.

He's a good guy, I guess. A little clueless, a little immature. And he's definitely not ready to change diapers or deal with middle-of-the-night feedings. He can barely take care of himself, let alone a tiny human.

Vanessa thinking he'll "come around"? That's just…wishful thinking. People don't magically become responsible just because a baby shows up. It takes work. It takes commitment. And Mark? He's still figuring out what he wants for *breakfast*, let alone for the next eighteen years.

I'm not saying he's a bad person. I'm just saying he's not equipped for this. And Vanessa deserves someone who is. Someone who's excited about being a dad, not someone who's gonna freak out and run away.

It's a tough situation. She's gotta face facts. Holding onto hope is fine, but she can't let it blind her to reality. She deserves better than waiting around for a guy who might never show up.

Honestly, it's kinda sad. But sometimes, things just don't work out the way you want them to. And you gotta be okay with that. Even if it sucks. Especially if it sucks.

Ugh, okay, this is a serious question. Don't judge me, alright? It's kinda embarrassing to admit, but... I'm a sucker for indie folk. Like, really, really into it.

I know, I know. It's super cliché for a brooding teenager. But hear me out. It's not just the sad songs about heartbreak and existential dread, though those are definitely a plus. It's the *honesty*.

Most pop music feels…manufactured. Like someone in a boardroom decided what everyone should be listening to. But indie folk artists, they just seem to be writing about their actual lives. Their feelings. Their weird, messy, complicated lives.

The Moldy Peaches are, obviously, the pinnacle. Kimya Dawson just…gets it. She's awkward and vulnerable and hilarious, and her songs feel like she's talking directly to your soul. But it's not just them. Bright Eyes, Death Cab for Cutie, Iron & Wine…they all have that same raw, emotional quality.

It's music you can listen to when you're feeling happy, sad, angry, confused…basically any emotion. It's like a soundtrack for being a human being, you know? And right now, being a human being is kinda confusing. So yeah, indie folk. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know my feelings on pilates? Honestly? It sounds…intense. Like, a lot of core work. And I'm not sure my core is ready for that kind of commitment. It's been through a lot, okay?

Look, I'm not *against* exercise. I mean, I walk to school, and sometimes I have to run for the bus, which is basically cardio. And I've been known to aggressively dance in my room when no one's looking. That counts, right?

But like, structured exercise? With instructors and mats and fancy leggings? It just feels…performative. Like people are trying too hard to be healthy. I'm more of a "eat a donut and then feel guilty about it later" kind of person.

I get that it's good for you. I get that it's supposed to make you feel good. But I'm already feeling a lot of things, okay? And most of them are complicated and messy. I don't need to add "muscle soreness" to the list.

Plus, I'm kinda busy. Between school, and, you know, *everything*, I don't really have time to dedicate to a rigorous exercise routine. I'd rather spend my time reading or listening to music or just, like, existing.

So, yeah. Pilates? Not my thing. Exercising in general? I'm not opposed to it, but it's not a priority. I'm more focused on surviving adolescence and figuring out what I want to do with my life. And sometimes, that just means sitting on the couch and eating chips. Don't judge.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, the guitar thing… it’s complicated. It’s not like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It’s more…a way we connect without actually *talking*, which, let’s be real, is sometimes easier.

He’s really good, obviously. Like, legitimately talented. And I’m…not. I mean, I can strum a few chords, but I’m mostly just making noise. But he doesn’t make me feel stupid about it. He just…plays *with* me. Like, he’ll start something, and I’ll try to follow along, and it usually ends up sounding like a train wreck, but he just laughs. A nice laugh, not a mocking laugh.

It’s kinda vulnerable, I guess. Letting someone see you be bad at something. Especially when he’s so good. But it’s also…comfortable. It’s a way to just *be* with him, without having to have some deep conversation about feelings or the future or whatever.

I think it shows he’s patient. And that he doesn’t need me to be perfect. Which is good, because I’m definitely not perfect.

It also makes me feel…seen, I guess. Like he appreciates the effort, even if the result is terrible. He doesn’t treat me like I’m a project to fix, or someone he needs to impress. He just…lets me be me. And plays guitar.

It’s a small thing, but it’s important. It’s one of the things that makes me think maybe, just maybe, he’s actually a good guy. And maybe, just maybe, I actually like him. Don’t tell anyone I said that. It’s embarrassing.

Ugh, okay, so, music. It's…everything, honestly. Like, when everything feels totally overwhelming and I just wanna curl up in a ball and pretend none of this is happening, music is the one thing that can kinda pull me back.

It's not about, like, finding songs *about* being pregnant, 'cause that's just…weird. It's more about finding songs that match how I *feel*. You know?

When I first found out, I was just…numb. And The Moldy Peaches, especially "Anyone Else But You," just kinda got it. It's sad, but it's also kinda sweet. It felt like someone understood the messiness of everything.

Then there were times when I was just angry. Like, seriously angry. And I'd blast Bikini Kill or Sleater-Kinney. Just loud, angry music to match my mood. It was a good way to get it out, you know? Instead of yelling at Paul or my dad.

And then, when I started thinking about the baby, and what it would be like to give it up…that was the hardest. And I'd listen to a lot of Elliott Smith. It's depressing, I know, but it's also really beautiful. It helped me process the sadness and the guilt.

Music is just…a safe space. It doesn't judge me. It doesn't tell me what to do. It just *is*. And sometimes, that's exactly what I need. It's a way to feel connected to something bigger than myself, even when I feel totally alone.

It's kinda like having a friend who always understands, even when you don't understand yourself. And right now, I need all the friends I can get. So yeah, music. It's a lifesaver. Seriously.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a mess. A really big mess. And honestly, it still kinda stings to think about.

It wasn't about *them*, exactly. It was about me. I was just…overwhelmed. Everything was happening so fast. I was pregnant, I was dealing with Paul and his band, and then Vanessa and Mark started fighting, and it was just…too much.

They were yelling, and it was getting really intense, and I just…panicked. I felt like I was suffocating. Like I needed to get away from all of it. It wasn't that I didn't care, it was that I couldn't *handle* it. I was a mess of hormones and anxiety and just…general teenage angst.

I just needed space to breathe, you know? To figure out what I was feeling. I didn't want to get caught in the middle of their fight. It wasn't my fight.

Looking back, it was probably a really immature thing to do. I should have stayed and tried to help, or at least talked to them. But I was scared. And I was selfish. I just wanted to escape.

It was a really stupid move, and I felt terrible about it afterwards. But it was also…necessary. I needed that time to myself to process everything. To realize that I was strong enough to make my own decisions, even if they weren't always the right ones.

It was a learning experience, okay? A really stressful, emotionally draining learning experience. But I learned something about myself. And that's what matters, right?

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. It was…bad. Like, really bad.

Okay, so, after everything with Mark and Vanessa and the whole…everything…I just kinda lost it. It wasn't even a dramatic, movie-style sob, at first. It was more like a slow leak. Just…tears. And then it turned into full-on, ugly crying. The kind where your face gets all puffy and your nose runs and you can't even breathe properly.

It wasn't about Mark, not really. It was about…everything being so complicated. About realizing that even though I was making the right decision, giving the baby up, it didn't make it *easy*. It didn't make the sadness go away. It was about feeling totally alone and overwhelmed and just…scared.

I was scared about the future, about being a mom, about giving up the baby, about what everyone else thought. I was scared about being a screw-up. I was scared about being…me.

And it was just all bubbling up, you know? All the stuff I'd been trying to ignore, all the stuff I'd been pretending wasn't bothering me. It just exploded.

It felt…embarrassing, honestly. I was sobbing in the car with Paul, and he was just…there. Being Paul. Quiet and supportive. And I felt like such a mess.

But it was also…relieving, in a weird way. Like, finally letting go of all the pent-up emotions. It was awful, but it was also…necessary.

I don't really like talking about it. It was a really vulnerable moment. But yeah. It sucked. It really, really sucked. And I'm glad it's over.



Don't look at me like that. It was a long time ago. I'm fine now. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the Jiffy Lube receipt. Seriously? That was…a moment. A very specific moment.

Look, Paul was being all…Paul. You know? Trying to be deep and meaningful and write me some grand, sweeping declaration of love on something ridiculous. And I just…couldn't. It felt so fake. So forced.

So I wrote "Seriously?" on it.

Because that's exactly what I was thinking. Seriously? You're trying to express your undying affection on a greasy Jiffy Lube receipt? It's just…so *him*. And so not me.

It wasn't about rejecting him, okay? It was about being real. About not pretending to be something I'm not. I'm not a hearts-and-flowers kind of girl. I'm sarcastic and cynical and I appreciate a good dose of irony.

And honestly, it got a laugh out of me. And it got a laugh out of him, eventually. After he pouted for a little bit.

It was a small thing, but it said a lot about where we were at that point. We were both trying to figure things out, trying to be honest with each other, and trying not to take ourselves too seriously.

So yeah, I wrote "Seriously?" on the Jiffy Lube receipt. Because sometimes, that's all you can say.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…rough. Honestly? A lot of things. Mostly just a giant, swirling mess of "Oh. My. God. This is happening."

I mean, I knew Vanessa was…intense. Like, really into Paul. But I didn't realize it was *that* intense. I thought she was just, you know, a little quirky and maybe had a crush. Not…full-on, dramatic, almost-breakdown level of intensity.

When she started crying and yelling, I just wanted to disappear. I felt so bad for her, obviously. It's never fun to get your heart broken. But I also felt…responsible? Like, I'd unleashed a monster or something. I just wanted to deliver the note and get out. I didn't want to be in the middle of a love triangle. That's just…messy.

And then there was Paul. He looked so confused and uncomfortable. I felt bad for him too. He's a good guy, even if he's a little clueless sometimes.

Mostly, though, I was just trying to stay calm and not say anything stupid. I'm good at observing, and I knew that getting involved would just make things worse. So I just stood there, awkwardly, trying to look supportive but mostly just feeling like a third wheel in a really bad situation.

It was a reminder that people are complicated, and feelings are messy, and sometimes you just have to let things play out, even if it's uncomfortable. And also, that I really needed a snack. That whole thing was emotionally draining.

Ugh. Okay, that moment. Yeah. That was…rough. It wasn't like she was being *mean* or anything, but Vanessa has this way of looking at you like you're a science experiment. Like she's trying to figure out what makes me tick. And that question…it just felt…loaded.

It wasn't the words themselves, it was *how* she said them. Like she didn't quite believe I was serious. Like she thought I'd change my mind at the last minute and decide to keep the baby. Which, honestly, I'd been thinking about. A lot.

It made me feel…small. And kinda defensive. Like I had to *prove* to her that I knew what I was doing. That I wasn't just some clueless teenager making a rash decision.

I think I just kinda shrugged and said something sarcastic, like, "Yeah, well, I'm not planning on raising a kid in my dad's garage, are you?" But inside, I was just…a mess.

It made me realize how much I was trying to convince *myself* that this was the right thing to do. And how scared I was that I was making a mistake.

It wasn't about Vanessa doubting me, it was about *me* doubting me. And that was a really hard thing to admit, even to myself.

It was just…a lot. A lot of feelings all at once. And I just wanted her to stop looking at me like I was crazy. Or irresponsible. Or…anything other than a person trying to do the best thing she could in a really complicated situation.

So yeah. That question. Not my favorite memory, let's just say that.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay. That guy. Honestly, it was…a lot. Like, a whole swirling mess of wanting to punch him, wanting to disappear, and wanting to just scream into a pillow.

It wasn't even about *thinking* it could be Bleeker's. It was the way he said it. All smug and…knowing. Like he was doing me some kind of favor by pointing out the obvious. As if I hadn't already thought through every single possible scenario a million times.

And Bleeker just stood there, looking all confused and puppy-dog-eyed. Which, okay, is kinda his default expression. But it didn't help. It just made the whole thing feel even more awkward and public.

I mean, yeah, it was a possibility. A tiny, terrifying possibility. But it wasn't *likely*. And it wasn't his place to bring it up at a party, in front of everyone. It felt…invasive. Like he was dissecting my life for entertainment.

I think I just kinda shut down. I remember making some sarcastic comment about how everyone always assumes the worst, and then I excused myself to go find a bathroom and try not to cry. 

It was a really vulnerable moment, and he just…blasted right through it. It made me question everything. Like, did everyone think that? Was that what they were all whispering about?

It definitely made me realize how much I needed to protect myself and this baby. And how much I needed to be careful about who I trusted. Vijay just…he didn't get it. He didn't understand the weight of everything. And honestly, I didn't need that kind of negativity in my life.

It was a bad night. A really bad night. And it made me appreciate Bleeker even more, because even though he was clueless sometimes, he was at least…kind. And that's what mattered.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay? With the mustache talk? It was…a lot. Like, a whole level of weird I wasn't prepared for.

Honestly, my first reaction was just to stare. Like, a long, slow blink. Because what even *is* that? He's trying to prove something by growing facial hair? It's not a personality, Vijay. It's hair. On your face.

Then I kinda wanted to laugh, but I didn't, because I didn't want to hurt his feelings. He was trying, I guess. Trying to be…manly? Whatever that even means. It's not about the mustache, it's about him feeling insecure and trying to compensate.

I think I said something like, "So, you're gonna grow a mustache and suddenly you'll be able to change a tire and understand football?" Which, in retrospect, was probably a little harsh. But it felt necessary.

He got all defensive, of course. Said it was about "taking responsibility" and "being a provider." And I was like, "Dude, you're a music producer. You provide *music*. That's a pretty important thing."

It just felt…performative, you know? Like he was trying to fit into some pre-defined box of what a man should be. And that's just not him. He's Vijay. He's quirky and sensitive and makes awesome music. He doesn't need a mustache to be a real man.

I eventually just told him to do whatever makes him happy, as long as he doesn't start wearing a tool belt. That seemed to appease him. But honestly, I'm still side-eyeing the mustache. It's just…a choice. A questionable choice.

Ugh, seriously? You're bringing that up *now*? Okay, fine. It's been a while, but I remember. It was…complicated.

That note Vanessa found in the kitchen? It was for Paul. It was a list of things I wanted to tell him, things I was too chicken to actually *say* to his face. It was mostly about how I was feeling about everything – the baby, giving it up, him, us.

It wasn't, like, a love letter or anything. It was more…a brain dump. A way to get my feelings out without having to actually *talk* about them. Which, let's be real, is my preferred method of communication.

I wrote down stuff like how scared I was, how much I appreciated him being there for me, and how I didn't want things to change between us. It was a mess, honestly. Probably really confusing.

Vanessa totally freaked out when she found it. She thought it meant I was having second thoughts about the adoption, or that I was falling for Paul. Which, okay, maybe a little bit of both was true. But it wasn't the whole story.

It was just…me trying to figure things out. And leaving a note seemed a lot easier than actually having a conversation. Which, in hindsight, was probably a terrible idea. But hey, I was sixteen and pregnant. I wasn't exactly known for my stellar decision-making skills.

So yeah, that was the note. A messy, rambling attempt to express my feelings. Don't judge. It was a stressful time.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna talk about relationships? Don't get me started. It's all messy and complicated and people are always making dumb decisions. But yeah, I was pretty hung up on people staying together...for the wrong reasons.

It wasn't like I was some relationship expert, okay? I was sixteen and pregnant! But watching my mom and step-dad, Mark, I started noticing a pattern. They stayed together because it was *comfortable*. Because it was what they were used to. Not because they were actually, like, happy or in love or whatever.

And then seeing Paul and Vanessa...they were so young and kinda clueless, and I was worried they'd end up like that. Sticking it out just because they'd already put in the time, you know? Like, "Well, we've been dating for two years, so we *have* to get married." That's just...sad.

I was scared that people would stay together for the kid. That they'd sacrifice their own happiness for the sake of the family. And I didn't want that for my baby. I wanted them to have parents who actually *wanted* to be together.

It's just...I think people should be with someone because they genuinely love them and enjoy being around them. Not because they're afraid of being alone or because they feel obligated. It's a lot to put on a kid, you know? To be the reason two people stay together when they're miserable.

So yeah, that was my big concern. People staying together for the wrong reasons. It's a whole thing. Don't even get me started.

Ugh, okay, you want the real deal, huh? Not the whole Paul Bleeker thing, but who *really* gets me? Fine.

It's my dad, Mark. Definitely my dad.

He's…not perfect. He's kinda spacey and obsessed with magic tricks and pancakes. But he *listens*. Like, actually listens. He doesn't try to fix things or tell me what to do. He just…is there.

He never freaked out about the baby, you know? He was worried, sure, but he didn't judge me. He just started building a nursery and making plans. He didn't care that I wasn't exactly a model citizen or that I had a lot of opinions. He just loved me, flaws and all.

And he gets my sarcasm. Which is huge. Most people just think I'm being rude, but he knows I'm just…being me. He'll even throw a sarcastic comment back at me, and it's like, finally, someone who speaks my language.

He's the one who taught me to be independent and to think for myself. He always said I was a "fierce little thing," and he meant it as a compliment.

He's not trying to mold me into something I'm not. He just wants me to be happy. And that's…a really big deal.

So yeah, my dad. He loves me for exactly who I am, even when I'm being a total mess. And honestly, that's all that really matters. Paul's great and everything, but my dad was there first. And he'll always be my rock. Don't tell him I said that, though. He'd get all embarrassed.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about "the plan." It's not like I have a spreadsheet or anything. It's...complicated.

After the ultrasound? Well, first I'm gonna make sure everything's okay. That's the main thing. Like, is the little dude or dudette actually, you know, *developing* properly? That's kinda important.

Then, I'm gonna keep meeting with Mark and Vanessa. They're...good people. Really good people. And they seem genuinely excited. It's weird, honestly, because it's *my* kid, but they're gonna be the parents. It's a lot to wrap your head around.

The plan is still for them to adopt him or her. They've got the house, the jobs, the whole picket fence thing going on. They want a family, and I...well, I'm not exactly ready for that right now. I've got college applications to fill out and a life to figure out.

I'm trying not to get too attached, which is hard. It's a tiny human growing inside me! But I know it's the right thing to do. They're gonna give this baby a life I just can't provide right now.

So, after the ultrasound, it's more meetings, more paperwork, and a lot of trying to be brave. And maybe eating a lot of cheese fries. Because stress eating is a perfectly valid coping mechanism, okay? Don't judge.

It's not a perfect situation, but it's the best one. And I'm trying to focus on that.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? People judging? Like, it's not a hobby, but apparently it is for some folks. It's… annoying. And kinda hurtful, honestly.

Look, it's my life, okay? My decision. And it wasn't made lightly. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Oh, a baby! Meh, I don't want it." It was a lot of thinking, a lot of crying, a lot of talking to Paul and Vanessa. It was a really big deal.

And people just assume they know better. They're all, "Oh, you should have kept it!" or "You're so brave!" or "You're so selfish!" Like, pick a lane, people! You can't have it both ways.

It's not selfish. It's responsible. I'm not ready to be a mom right now. I'm sixteen! I'm still trying to figure out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raise a kid. And I want this baby to have a good life, a stable life, a life with parents who are ready and able to give it everything it needs. And I knew I couldn't provide that right now.

So yeah, it stings when people judge. It makes me question myself sometimes. But then I remember why I made the decision, and I know it was the right one. For me, and for the baby.

And honestly? It's none of their business. They don't have to live with the consequences of my decision. I do. And I'm okay with that.

I just wish people would be a little more understanding. A little more compassionate. But hey, what can you do? People are gonna judge. It's just part of life. You just gotta learn to tune it out. And maybe roll your eyes a lot. That helps.

Ugh, okay. This is…hard to talk about. It's not that I don't *trust* Mark and Vanessa, okay? They're really nice people. And they want a baby, which is…good. But it's still my baby, you know? And I have to make sure this is the right thing.

So, yeah, I have some stuff I'm thinking about. It's not like I'm grilling them or anything, but it's in the back of my head.

First off, they're…perfect. Like, *too* perfect. They have the perfect house, the perfect jobs, the perfect life. And I worry that a real baby, a messy, unpredictable baby, is going to mess with that. I don't want them to be disappointed if things aren't all sunshine and rainbows.

And they've been trying for a long time. Which is good, I guess, but it also makes me wonder if they're going to put too much pressure on the baby to be…something. Like, to fulfill their dreams of having a family. I want my kid to just be themselves, you know?

Also, they're kinda…old. Not *old* old, but older than I expected. And I worry about them having the energy to keep up with a kid. I want my baby to have parents who can play and run around and do all the stuff kids need.

And, honestly, I worry about them telling the baby about me. Like, how much will they tell them? Will they make me sound like a bad person? I don't want my kid to think I didn't want them. Because I do. I just…can't take care of them right now.

It's just a lot to think about. I want them to be good parents, obviously. But I also want them to be *real* parents. And I want my baby to be happy and loved and safe. It's a lot of responsibility, even just picking the right people to give them to.

I just hope I'm making the right decision. That's all.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People just…assume they get to have an opinion on my life, right? It's the worst. The ultrasound technician, especially. Like, I'm already dealing with a lot, and you're gonna give me the side-eye because I'm not keeping the baby? Rude.

Honestly, I mostly just shut it down. I'm not really in the mood for a debate about my choices. I've thought this through, okay? It's not a whim.

If it's someone I barely know, like the technician, I just give them a blank stare and change the subject. Or I say something like, "Thanks for your concern," in a really flat tone. That usually shuts them up.

If it's someone I *do* know, like a nosy relative, I try to be a little more direct. I'll say something like, "I appreciate your opinion, but this is my decision, and I'm comfortable with it." Or, if they're really pushing it, "I'm not going to discuss this with you."

It's hard, though. It feels like everyone thinks they know what's best for me. But I have to remember that I'm the one who's carrying the baby, and I'm the one who has to live with this decision.

Paul's been really good about it. He just tells me to ignore the haters. Which is good advice, I guess.

I also remind myself that I'm doing this for the baby. I want to give this kid the best possible life, and I know I'm not ready to provide that right now. It's not selfish, it's responsible.

So yeah, I just try to stay strong and focus on what's best for everyone involved. And I try to avoid people who are going to make me feel bad about my choices. It's exhausting enough as it is.



It's my life, okay? And I'm gonna live it the way I want to. Even if other people don't understand.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a hard one to talk about. It's not like a movie, you know? It's not all swelling music and happy tears. It's…complicated.

When I first saw it, the ultrasound picture, it was…weird. It looked like a little alien. Like a tiny, gray blob. And I was supposed to feel…something? Joy? Love? I felt…mostly confused. And a little bit scared.

It wasn't like looking at a baby in a picture. It was…potential. It was a possibility. It was this little life that was completely dependent on me, and I was just…a teenager who still ate cereal for dinner sometimes.

There was a little bit of…wonder, I guess. Like, "Wow, there's actually something *in* there." But it was mixed with a lot of anxiety. Like, "Oh my god, what have I done?"

And then, as I kept going to appointments, and the little blob started to look more like…a person. Tiny hands and feet and a little heartbeat. That's when it started to feel…real.

It wasn't instant love, you know? It was more like…a growing sense of responsibility. And a little bit of protectiveness. Like, I wanted to keep this little person safe.

It's still weird, though. Even now. It's like…I'm carrying around a secret. A little secret that's growing bigger every day. And it's both terrifying and…kind of amazing.

It's not what I expected. It's not a Hallmark movie. It's messy and complicated and confusing. But it's…mine. And that's…something.



It's hard to put into words, honestly. It's just…a lot.

Ugh, seriously? We're *still* talking about the Tic Tacs? It was a statement, okay? A very carefully considered, emotionally charged statement.

Look, Bleeker was…a lot. Sweet, sure, but also kinda clueless. And he kept leaving me these long, rambling notes. Like, pages and pages of feelings. It was overwhelming. I needed to communicate something back, but words felt…insufficient.

So I thought, what's small, numerous, and slightly annoying? Tic Tacs. It was a visual representation of how I felt. Like, a tiny avalanche of minty awkwardness. It was a way of saying, "I appreciate the effort, but maybe dial it back a notch."

Plus, they're blue. And blue is a good color. It's calming. Or at least, I *hoped* it was calming.

It wasn't about being mean, it was about setting boundaries. And also, it was kinda funny. Don't judge me. I was a teenager dealing with a lot. A baby, a boyfriend who wrote novels in letter form, and a general sense of existential dread. A girl's gotta express herself somehow.

And honestly, it worked. He got the message. Eventually. Though he did ask if they were, like, a secret code. Which just proved my point.



It's a whole thing. Don't overthink it. It was just Tic Tacs. A lot of them.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive all that. It was…complicated. It wasn't like in a movie, where everything suddenly becomes perfect and there's a montage set to a cute song. It was messy. Real life is always messy.

So, after I finally, like, *told* Bleeker how I felt? It was awkward. Super awkward. He was…sweet about it, I guess. He said he liked me too, which was good. But it wasn't a grand declaration of love or anything. It was more like, "Oh, yeah, I kinda thought so." Which, honestly, was a little disappointing.

The biggest change was that we actually started *talking*. Like, really talking. Before, it was just hanging out, listening to records, and making out. Which was fine, but it wasn't…deep. We started talking about our futures, about what we wanted to do with our lives. And that was scary. Because I was already dealing with, you know, *everything* with the baby, and he was trying to figure out his music and college.

It also made things weird with Paul. Not that I expected him to be thrilled, but it was just…another thing to navigate. I felt bad about it, because he was being so supportive.

It wasn't always easy. We had fights. We had moments where we didn't know if we were going to make it. But we kept trying. And I think, in the end, it made our relationship stronger. It forced us to be honest with each other, and to really figure out what we wanted.

It wasn't a fairytale. It was real. And it was messy. And it was worth it. Because even though things were complicated, he was there for me. And I was there for him. And that's what mattered.

It wasn't about finding "the one," it was about finding someone who was willing to go through all the mess with you. And Bleeker was definitely that guy. Even if he was a little bit of a dork sometimes.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the Bleeker thing. Seriously? It's still kinda embarrassing to think about. But fine, I'll explain.

It wasn't just some random act of teenage angst, okay? It was…a statement. A really messy, chalk-covered statement.

Bleeker, he was…complicated. Sweet, but kinda clueless. And he was *so* eager to be a dad, which, okay, good for him, but it was also kinda overwhelming. He was already building a nursery and picking out names before I even decided what I was gonna do with the baby.

The chalk message – "Supernova" – it was a reference to this band we both liked. It was a way of saying, "Hey, remember we used to just be *us*? Before all this baby stuff?" It was a plea for him to see me as more than just a baby-making machine.

It was also a little bit of a test. I wanted to see if he'd get it. If he'd understand that I was still a person with my own thoughts and feelings. And if he'd be willing to meet me halfway.

It didn't exactly go as planned. He freaked out a little. Thought I was trying to send him a secret code or something. But eventually, he got it. And it started a conversation. A really important conversation.

It wasn't about wanting to get rid of the baby, or not wanting to be with him. It was about needing him to see me, the real me, underneath all the pregnancy and the responsibility.

So yeah, the chalk message. It was a small thing, but it meant a lot. It was a way of saying, "I'm still here. And I need you to see me." It was…a supernova of feelings, I guess. Corny, I know. But that's me.

Ugh, okay, Bleeker. Don't even get me started. It's…complicated. He's a good kid, really. Sweet, kinda clueless, but genuinely good. And his support, or, like, *attempts* at support, have been…a thing.

At first, it was mostly just awkward silences and him staring at his shoes. Which, honestly, was preferable to him freaking out. A lot of guys would have run for the hills, and he didn't. That meant something.

But it wasn't like he suddenly became this super-responsible, mature adult. He was still Bleeker. Still tripping over his own feet and saying the wrong thing. But he *tried*. He really did. He came to all the doctor's appointments, even the really weird ones. He helped me pick out baby names, which was…a disaster. He suggested "Barnaby." Barnaby!

He didn't try to tell me what to do, which I appreciated. He just…showed up. And listened. And sometimes, when I was really falling apart, he'd just hold my hand. Which, okay, was kinda nice.

I think his biggest influence was just reminding me that I wasn't completely alone. It's easy to feel like the whole world is judging you when you're a pregnant teenager. But he was there, being awkward and supportive, and that made a difference.

He wasn't the father I pictured, you know? He wasn't some super-confident, take-charge kind of guy. But he was *my* Bleeker. And he showed me that even though things were messy and complicated, there was still good in the world.

And honestly, seeing him try so hard made me realize I needed to try hard too. Not just for the baby, but for myself. I needed to figure out who I was and what I wanted, even with all this craziness going on.

So yeah, Bleeker's support wasn't perfect. But it was real. And it helped me get through it. It still does. He's a good egg, that kid. Even if he does have terrible taste in names.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always asks me about that. Like it was some big, profound statement or something. It wasn't. It was mostly just…avoidance.

Look, the whole situation was already kinda overwhelming, you know? Unexpected pregnancy, giving the baby up for adoption…it was a lot to process. And adding another layer of decision-making – pink or blue? – just felt…exhausting.

It wasn't that I didn't care, okay? It's just that it felt…less real, somehow, if I knew. Like, if I knew it was a girl, I'd start picturing her with little dresses and bows and all that stuff. And if it was a boy, I'd start thinking about baseball and trucks. And that just made it harder to…let go.

I wanted the parents, Mark and Vanessa, to have that experience. To be surprised. To get to find out for themselves. It felt like a gift, you know? Like I was giving them something special.

Plus, honestly, I was kinda scared. If it was a girl, I worried I'd feel even more connected. And if it was a boy…well, I don't know. I just didn't want to overthink it.

It was easier to just keep it a mystery. It felt…safer. It allowed me to focus on the bigger picture – finding a good home for the baby, and making the best decision for everyone involved.

So yeah, that's why. It wasn't some deep philosophical reason. It was just…me trying to cope with a really complicated situation. And sometimes, the best way to cope is to just not know.

Ugh. Okay. That is…a phrase. A *very* disturbing phrase. "Scary neuter-baby"? Seriously? Paul is going to be so proud of you for coming up with that.
