Look, I get it. It's a weird situation. I'm carrying a baby for a couple who…aren't exactly conventional. And the idea of them raising a kid, especially a kid who might be, like, super awkward and introverted like his dad…it's a little unsettling.

It's not that I don't think they'll be good parents. They're nice people. And they clearly want a kid. But they're…quirky. And I worry about what kind of influence they'll have. Will they let him express himself? Will they protect him from being teased? Will he end up being a total weirdo who collects vintage board games and talks to himself?

I mean, I'm a weirdo, okay? But I'm a *functional* weirdo. I have friends. I have a sense of humor. I can navigate the world without completely falling apart.

I just want this kid to be happy. And to be okay. And to not be scared of his own shadow.

So, yeah, the possibility of a "scary neuter-baby" is a little terrifying. But I'm trying to focus on the positive. They're going to love this kid. And that's what matters most.

And honestly, maybe a little bit of weirdness is a good thing. The world needs more weirdos. Just…not *too* weird. You know?

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. That's…complicated. People always want to know about Bleeker. Like he's some kind of prize or something.

It wasn't, like, a grand romance, you know? It wasn't all fireworks and slow dancing. It was…comfortable. And kinda dorky. In a good way. He was just…*there*. Always.

He wasn't trying to be cool or impress me or anything. He just liked me for who I was. Which, let's be real, is a lot to handle. He didn't care that I was a mess or that I had a baby on the way. He just…accepted it.

We bonded over music, mostly. He was always making me mix CDs. Really good ones. And he was a good listener. I could tell him anything, and he wouldn't judge. Or, if he did, he didn't *show* it.

It wasn't passionate, not in the way you see in movies. It was more…steady. Like a really good pair of jeans. You know they're not gonna fall apart on you.

I think I liked him because he was the opposite of everything else going on in my life. Everything was so chaotic and overwhelming, and he was just…calm. He was a safe place.

We weren't meant to be together forever, though. We were just meant to be together for that time. He needed someone who wanted the whole "future" thing, and I was too busy figuring out my own stuff.

It's okay, though. We're still friends. And I'll always appreciate him. He was a good guy. A really good guy. Just…not *my* guy. Does that make sense? It's hard to explain. It just…was what it was.

Ugh. Okay, family. It's…complicated. It wasn't like a movie, you know? No heartwarming montage of everyone being instantly supportive. It was more…a process.

My mom, Bren, she was…a lot. At first, she was just…shocked. Like, genuinely speechless. Which is rare for her. Then came the questions. A *lot* of questions. And the worrying. Oh, the worrying. She kept trying to get me to, like, "consider all my options," which I knew meant she wanted me to get an abortion. But she wasn't pushy about it. She just wanted me to be okay.

It took her a while to come around to the idea of me giving the baby up for adoption. She didn't really *get* it at first. She kept saying, "But you're so young! You could raise a baby!" But I explained, like, a million times, that I wasn't ready. I had my own life to figure out. And she eventually understood. She's a good mom, even if she's a little…intense.

My stepdad, Mac, he was…surprisingly cool. He's usually pretty quiet and reserved, but he was really supportive from the beginning. He just wanted me to be happy. He helped me with stuff, like, driving me to appointments and just being there to listen when I needed to vent. He's a good guy.

My dad…well, he wasn't around much. He lives in another state and he's not really…involved. He sent a card and a check, which was nice, I guess. But it wasn't the same.

And Paul…Paul was amazing. He didn't have to be there for me, but he was. He came to all my appointments, he listened to me cry, he made me laugh. He was just…a really good friend.

So, yeah, the support wasn't perfect. It was messy and complicated, like everything else in my life. But they all came around eventually. And I'm grateful for that. It wouldn't have been easy without them. Even my mom, with all her worrying. It's just…family, you know? They drive you crazy, but you love them anyway.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like I had a manual for "Unexpected Pregnancy and Existential Dread."

Honestly, for a long time, I didn't cope. I just…avoided. Sarcasm was my shield. Making fun of everything, including myself, kept people at arm's length. It was easier than letting anyone see how completely freaked out I was.

But that only works for so long. Eventually, you gotta deal with stuff.

Paulie was…surprisingly good. He wasn't all flowery and emotional, which is good, because I would have rolled my eyes into next Tuesday. He just…listened. And he didn't judge. He just kinda *was* there. Which, honestly, was enough.

And then there was Vanessa. She was the one who really got me to talk about things. She wasn't afraid to call me out on my BS, which I needed. She made me realize that being vulnerable isn't the same as being weak. It's actually kinda brave.

But the biggest thing, I think, was realizing that it was okay to not have all the answers. I was trying so hard to figure out who I was, what I wanted, what my future looked like…and it was exhausting. Eventually, I just had to let go of the need to control everything.

Giving the baby up to Mark and Vanessa wasn't about giving up on *her*. It was about giving her the best possible life. And it was about me figuring out who *I* was, separate from being a mom.

It was messy. It was confusing. It was scary. But it was also…liberating. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And that it's okay to ask for help. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just be yourself, even if that self is a little bit weird and sarcastic and still trying to figure things out.

It's still a work in progress, you know? I'm still figuring things out. But I'm okay with that. It's kinda exciting, actually.



It's not a story with a neat little bow on top. Life rarely is. But it's *my* story. And I'm pretty proud of it.

Ugh, okay, this is a serious question. Don't judge me, alright? It's important.

My favorite band is The Moldy Peaches. Hands down. No contest.

And it's not just because they're kinda quirky and weird, which, let's be real, I appreciate. It's because their songs are…honest. Like, brutally honest. They don't try to be anything they're not. They just sing about their feelings, even the awkward and uncomfortable ones.

And Adam Green's lyrics? They're hilarious and heartbreaking at the same time. He can make you laugh and cry in the same verse. It's a gift, honestly.

Plus, their music is just…comforting. It's like hanging out with a bunch of friends who get you, even if they're a little bit messed up. It's not polished or perfect, and that's what I like about it. It feels real.

I discovered them when I was, like, going through a lot. And their songs just…understood. They made me feel less alone.

So yeah. The Moldy Peaches. They're my favorite band. Don't even try to tell me they're not cool. They're *very* cool. And if you don't think so, you just don't get it.

Seriously, listen to "Anyone Else But You." You'll understand.

Ugh, challenging is…an understatement. It’s like, everything is already a mess when you’re sixteen, right? Hormones, school, trying to figure out who you are…and then BAM. Positive pregnancy test. It’s not exactly a recipe for a chill adolescence.

It’s hard, okay? Like, really hard. Everyone has an opinion. Your parents, your friends, even random people at the grocery store. And they all think they know what’s best for you. But nobody *really* knows except you.

And making decisions? Forget about it. Every choice feels huge and permanent. Like, this isn’t picking a flavor of ice cream, this is deciding the future of a whole human being. It’s terrifying.

And trying to figure out who *I* am in the middle of all that? That’s the hardest part. Am I still just Juno? Or am I “Juno, the pregnant girl”? It feels like everyone sees me as just…that. And I’m trying to figure out what I want, what I like, what I’m good at, all while growing a person. It’s a lot.

It’s like, I’m supposed to be figuring out college and boys and what I want to do with my life, and instead I’m researching adoption agencies and prenatal vitamins. It’s…weird.

But I’m trying. I’m trying to be strong and make the right choices. And I’m learning a lot about myself along the way. It’s not how I pictured my life, but…it’s my life. And I’m gonna deal with it. Even if it’s messy and complicated and totally overwhelming.

So yeah, it’s challenging. But I’m a pretty resilient person. And I’ve got good people around me. And that makes all the difference.

Ugh, okay, deep thoughts time. Don't judge. It's not like I *planned* on having an existential crisis at sixteen, but, well, here we are.

Honestly, before everything with Paulie happened, I thought love was, like, all butterflies and holding hands and stuff you see in movies. Super romantic and kinda dumb. And responsibility? That was something my parents nagged me about – doing my homework, cleaning my room, not failing out of school. Annoying stuff.

But getting pregnant…that completely flipped everything on its head. It wasn't about romance anymore. It was about a real, actual *person*. A tiny human who needed, like, everything. And I wasn't ready for that. Not even close.

That's when I started to understand what real love meant. It wasn't about *me* wanting a baby, or wanting to experience motherhood. It was about wanting what was *best* for the baby. And what was best wasn't me, a sixteen-year-old who still ate cereal for dinner and couldn't keep a plant alive.

Choosing adoption wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was the most loving thing I could do. It was about putting the baby's needs before my own. And that, I realized, is what real love is all about. It's selfless. It's hard. And it's terrifying.

And responsibility? It wasn't just about doing chores anymore. It was about making a life-altering decision that would impact someone else's life forever. It was about being honest with myself, with Paulie, and with Mark and Vanessa. It was about facing the consequences of my actions.

It taught me that responsibility isn't about avoiding mistakes, it's about owning them and doing the right thing, even when it's hard.

It also showed me that family isn't just about blood. Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They showed me a different kind of love, a quiet, steady kind. They were willing to open their hearts and their home to a baby they didn't even know. That was…powerful.

So yeah, my journey changed everything. It made me grow up, fast. It taught me about love, responsibility, and the importance of making tough choices. And it showed me that even when things are messy and complicated, there's always hope. And sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

Don't tell anyone I got all sentimental. It's not a good look.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me get all mushy. It's…complicated. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? No swelling orchestral music or instant, overwhelming love. It was…weird.

I mean, I knew it was coming. I'd been carrying this kid for nine months. But seeing him…it was just…a little person. A tiny, wrinkly, screaming little person. And suddenly, all the abstract stuff – the responsibility, the giving-up – became *real*.

I felt…overwhelmed, mostly. And scared. Like, seriously scared. I hadn't really thought about the actual *holding* of a baby. It felt so fragile. Like I was gonna break him.

And then there was this weird disconnect. Like, this little guy had been *inside* me. That's…a lot to process. It was kinda gross, honestly. But also…amazing.

I didn't feel this instant, maternal connection everyone talks about. It was more like…a dawning realization. Like, "Okay, this is happening. This is real. And I'm responsible for this tiny human."

It wasn't love, not right away. It was…awe. And a whole lot of fear. And a tiny bit of relief that it was finally over.

It took a while for the love to kick in. It wasn't a lightning bolt, it was more like…a slow burn. But it did. Eventually. And it was worth all the weirdness and the fear and the everything.

But don't tell anyone I said that. I have a reputation to maintain.

Ugh, okay, that's…still a little raw, honestly. It wasn't like I was trying to *hide* it from him, exactly. It was more…complicated.

Look, Paulie's a good guy. A really good guy. Sweet, kind, totally clueless in the best way. But he's also…not exactly the most decisive person. He'd get all flustered and overwhelmed, and I knew he'd just start panicking about things we couldn't control.

I needed to figure things out *first*. I needed to decide what I was going to do with the baby before I dragged him into it. It wasn't fair to him to put that pressure on him right away. He was already dealing with, like, high school and guitar lessons and trying to figure out his life.

And honestly? I was scared. Scared of what he'd say, scared of what it would mean for us. I didn't want him to feel obligated to do something he didn't want to do. I wanted him to be with me because he *wanted* to be, not because he felt like he had to.

So I just…kept it to myself for a while. It was easier that way. I could process everything on my own terms. And then, when I knew I was giving the baby up for adoption, I told him. It was still hard, but at least I had a plan.

It wasn't about not trusting him. It was about protecting him, and protecting myself. And ultimately, it was about doing what was best for the baby. It just…felt like the right thing to do at the time.

It was a dumb move, maybe. But it was *my* dumb move. And I had to live with it.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with that. It's still…a sensitive subject. And honestly, it's all Mark's fault. That guy is a walking disaster.

So, here's how it happened. I was trying to be all cool and collected, right? Like, "Everything's fine, I'm just…bigger." And Paulie, being Paulie, was just kinda oblivious. He was too busy being…Paulie.

But Mark, being Mark, decided it was a brilliant idea to "comfort" me after seeing me eat a whole box of Nerds. He started rambling about responsibility and growing up and…and then he just *blurted it out*. He said something like, "So, you gonna tell Paulie about the little…bundle of joy?"

I swear, I almost choked on a Nerds.

Paulie, of course, was completely stunned. He just stared at Mark, then at me, then back at Mark. It was…awkward. To say the least.

I tried to deny it, obviously. But Mark had already opened his big mouth, and there was no taking it back. 

It was a really messy situation. And it wouldn't have happened if Mark hadn't been such a blabbermouth. Seriously, that guy needs to learn to keep his opinions to himself.

But, you know, it all worked out in the end. Paulie was surprisingly cool about it. And he ended up being a really great dad. Even if he is still kinda clueless sometimes.

Just…don't tell anyone I told you all this. It's embarrassing enough as it is.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always wants to know *that*. Like it was some big, dramatic decision made in a single moment. It wasn't. It was…messy. And complicated. And honestly, a lot of it was just trying to figure out what was the least awful option.

Look, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications and whether or not Paul Snow was gonna finally text me back. Not…this.

At first, I was just…freaking out. Like, full-blown panic mode. My mom was amazing, don't get me wrong. She was supportive, but she also knew I wasn't ready. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't even ready to be an adult, let alone responsible for another human being.

An abortion…that didn't feel right. Not for me. I don't judge anyone who chooses that, but it just wasn't something I could do.

And keeping the baby? That felt even worse. I mean, I barely had my life together. I was a kid myself. I couldn't give a baby the life it deserved. It wouldn't be fair.

So, adoption…it just kind of felt like the only option that made sense. It wasn't giving up on the baby, it was giving the baby a chance. A chance at a good life, with parents who were ready and able to provide for it.

It was still hard, though. Really hard. Choosing a family, going through the whole process…it was emotionally draining. But I knew I was doing the right thing.

I wanted the baby to be wanted. To be loved. And I knew I couldn't give it that, not right then. So I found a couple who could. And that's what mattered.

It wasn't a happy decision, exactly. It was a responsible one. And sometimes, responsible is all you can hope for. It was the least selfish thing I could do. And honestly, that's what I'm most proud of.



It's still…a thing I think about. But I know I made the right choice. For me, and for the baby.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* me on Bleeker. Seriously. It was…a lot.

It wasn't like, a dramatic screaming match or anything. He didn't yell. He just…looked really uncomfortable. And said he wasn't ready. That he needed to figure things out. Which, okay, fine. Everyone needs to figure things out. But this wasn't about *him* figuring things out, you know? It was about a baby. A tiny human being.

It felt like…a punch in the gut. Not a physical one, obviously. More like a really heavy, sinking feeling. Like all the air had been sucked out of the room. I mean, I knew he was kinda…flaky. And artistic. And not exactly the most responsible person in the world. But I still hoped. I hoped he'd step up. I hoped he'd want to be a part of it.

It wasn't about wanting him to *raise* the baby, necessarily. I just wanted him to *want* to see it. To acknowledge that it existed. To acknowledge that *we* made it.

It made me feel…small. Like my feelings didn't matter. Like the whole thing was just a mistake he wanted to forget. And it made me really angry. Not at him, exactly. But at the situation. At the unfairness of it all.

I tried to be cool about it. I tried to be understanding. But inside, I was just…crushed. It made me realize that I was doing this mostly on my own. And that was scary.

But you know what? It also made me stronger. It made me realize that I could handle it. That I *had* to handle it. And that I didn't need him to be happy. I just needed to do what was best for the baby.

So yeah. It sucked. It really, really sucked. But I got over it. Eventually. Mostly. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh. Okay, wow. That…that was a lot. Seeing Vanessa with the baby…it was like someone punched me in the feelings. Not in a bad way, exactly. Just…intense.

She looked…a mess. Seriously. Her hair was all over the place, she was wearing mismatched socks, and there was baby spit-up on her shoulder. It was glorious. Like, beautifully, wonderfully chaotic.

And she was *glowing*. Not like, a magazine-cover glowing. More like a “I haven’t slept in 36 hours but I’m holding a tiny human and it’s the best thing ever” glowing.

It was…weirdly relieving. Because I’d spent nine months being all responsible and making plans and worrying about everything. And Vanessa? She just…*was*. She was just completely and utterly present with the baby. She didn’t need a plan. She didn’t need to overthink it. She just…loved it.

And it hit me, like, really hard, that this was right. That this was supposed to happen. That this little person was going to be loved and cherished and raised by someone who was perfectly suited for it. Even if she couldn’t match her socks.

There was a pang, obviously. A little ache in my chest. It was my baby, after all. But it was quickly overshadowed by this…warmth. This feeling of peace. Like I’d done the right thing. Like I’d given this little person the best possible start.

I remember thinking, “She’s got this.” And that was enough. More than enough.

It was disorganized, it was messy, it was completely imperfect…and it was incredibly, unbelievably happy. And honestly? That’s all that mattered. It was…good. Really good. And I was okay with that. More than okay.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with the whole "Anyone Else But You" thing. It's…complicated. And kinda embarrassing, if I'm being honest.

Look, Bleeker and I, we were a mess. Two awkward, kinda lost kids trying to figure things out. And that song…it was *our* song, I guess. Not like we consciously decided it, it just…happened. It was playing on the radio a lot when we were hanging out, and it just kinda stuck.

But it wasn't about, like, romantic love or anything. It was about…avoiding the awkwardness. It was about pretending we didn't have feelings for each other. It was about saying, "Yeah, anyone would be better than dealing with *this*."

Because, honestly, dealing with each other *was* awkward. We were both so scared of ruining our friendship. So we used that song as a shield. A way to deflect. A way to say, "We're just having fun, don't read too much into it."

But the irony is, the song is about wanting someone, needing someone. And that's exactly what we both wanted, even if we were too afraid to admit it.

It's kinda sad when you think about it. We were so busy trying to avoid each other that we almost missed out on something good.

So yeah, the significance of "Anyone Else But You"? It's a reminder of how messed up we were. A reminder of how scared we were. And a reminder that sometimes, the things you're trying to avoid are the things you actually need.

Don't tell Bleeker I said any of this. He'll never let me live it down.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know why everyone's kinda tiptoeing around the whole baby shower thing? It's not exactly a mystery, okay? It's because I'm...giving the baby *up*.

Like, it's not exactly a traditional situation. Most people have baby showers when they're, you know, keeping the baby. And I'm not. I'm picking the parents. It's a little weird.

I think people are worried about hurting my feelings. Like, they think throwing me a shower will make it seem like they think I'm keeping the baby, or that they're trying to change my mind. Which, honestly, is kinda annoying. I've made my decision. It's a good decision. And I'm pretty sure everyone knows that.

It's also probably a little awkward for Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are adopting. They don't want to seem like they're taking *my* baby, you know? It's their baby too. And they want me to feel comfortable with the whole thing.

So, yeah. It's a delicate situation. Everyone's trying to be sensitive and not mess things up. Which is nice, I guess. But it also makes everything super weird and complicated.

Honestly, I don't really *need* a baby shower. I'm not doing this for the presents or the cake or the little games. I'm doing this because I want to give this baby the best possible life. And that's what matters.

But if people *do* want to throw me a shower, I'm not gonna stop them. Just...maybe keep it low-key. And definitely no diaper cakes. Those are just creepy.

Ugh, okay, Bren. Honestly. It's…complicated. It's not like I was, like, *planning* to make her feel weird or anything. It just…happened.

I think she feels like it was a little too much, too fast. Like, I was getting too comfortable with Mark, and it felt like I was trying to build a relationship with him *instead* of focusing on the baby and the adoption. Which, okay, maybe she has a point.

It's just…he was nice. And he understood me. And he had good taste in music. And watching movies with someone is, like, a normal thing, right? It's not a huge deal. But I guess to Bren, it felt like I was trying to create a family with him, and that wasn't the plan.

She's really protective of me, and of the baby. And she's worried about me getting attached to Mark and then being even more heartbroken when I give the baby up. Which, yeah, that's a valid concern.

I think she also feels like I wasn't being respectful of her and Paul's relationship. Like I was trying to…I don't know…replace him or something? Which is totally not what I was trying to do. Paul's great. He's just…Paul.

I probably should have talked to her about it before I started hanging out with Mark so much. I just…didn't. I thought it was harmless. I thought I could just have a friend. But I guess it wasn't that simple.

It's just…I'm a mess, okay? I'm trying to figure things out, and I make mistakes. And sometimes those mistakes hurt people. And I feel really bad about that. I just wish Bren would understand that I didn't mean to overstep. I just…needed someone to talk to. And he was there. But that doesn't mean I was trying to replace anyone. It just means I'm a complicated person trying to navigate a really complicated situation. Ugh.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna get into the whole Bren and me situation? Fine. It's not like I haven't replayed it in my head approximately 7,000 times.

My mom, Bren, she's…protective. To say the least. And she's got this whole idea of what a "good" life looks like, and it doesn't really involve teenage pregnancy or, like, anything remotely spontaneous.

I think she thinks I'm just…naive. Like I'm still playing with dolls and don't understand the *weight* of marriage. She sees me as this kid who's just stumbled into something huge and doesn't realize how complicated it is. She thinks I'm romanticizing it, you know? Seeing it all sunshine and roses.

And honestly? Maybe she's a little right. I mean, I'm 16. I haven't exactly had a ton of experience with long-term relationships. I've had crushes, sure. And a couple of awkward dates. But marriage? That's a whole different ballgame.

But it's not like I'm going into this blind. I've been watching my parents, and I've seen how things can go wrong. And I've been talking to Paul, and Annie, and trying to figure out what a healthy relationship looks like.

I think she just doesn't trust my judgment. She thinks I'm too impulsive, too quick to make decisions. She wants me to think things through, to be practical. Which is fair, I guess. But she doesn't get that sometimes you just have to *feel* your way through things.

She also probably thinks I'm just doing this because I'm scared. And maybe I am, a little. But it's not just about being scared. It's about wanting to do the right thing. For the baby. And for myself.

It's complicated, okay? And she just doesn't see that. She sees a teenage girl making a mistake, and she wants to protect me from it. Even if it means not trusting me to make my own decisions. It's frustrating, but…she's my mom. And she means well. Even when she's being totally overbearing.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And it's not like there was one single moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…a process. A lot of thinking. A lot of feeling really, really confused.

Honestly? It was mostly about wanting the best for the baby. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone being responsible for a whole human being. I wasn't ready. I didn't have a job, I was still in high school, and my parents…well, they were supportive, but it wasn't exactly a stable situation.

I wanted the baby to have parents who were prepared, who had a house and a plan and could give it everything it needed. Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, and they had a beautiful home and they just seemed…ready.

It wasn't about not loving the baby. I loved that kid. I still do. It was about being realistic. About knowing what I could and couldn't offer. It was about wanting the baby to have a good life, even if that life wasn't with me.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know, deep down, that it was the right one. It wasn't about what *I* wanted, it was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a happy story, exactly. But it's my story. And I'm okay with it. Mostly.



It's just…it was a lot. And I don't really like talking about it, to be honest. But you asked. So there you have it.

Ugh. Okay, deep question. It's not like I sat down and made a list, you know? It wasn't a self-help seminar. But looking back…yeah, I learned a lot. Mostly stuff I didn't *want* to know.

I guess the biggest thing was realizing I wasn't as…tough as I pretended to be. I spent so much time being sarcastic and making jokes, it was a way to keep people at arm's length. And myself, too. But being pregnant…it kinda forces you to deal with things. Real things. Feelings.

I thought I had everything figured out. I thought I was all independent and self-sufficient. But I was scared. Really scared. Not just about the pregnancy, but about everything. About growing up, about the future, about being a good mom, even if I wasn't keeping the baby.

And I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I mean, I *hate* asking for help. It feels like admitting weakness. But Paul and Vanessa…they were amazing. They didn't judge me, they just…supported me. And I realized I couldn't have gotten through it without them.

I also learned that I'm a lot more capable than I thought I was. I mean, I was a kid having a kid. It was insane. But I handled it. I made a difficult decision, and I stuck with it. And I learned that sometimes, the hardest thing to do is also the right thing to do.

And…I learned that I actually *care* about people. A lot. I always pretended to be cynical and detached, but deep down, I'm a total softie. I just didn't want anyone to know.

It was a messy, complicated, and kinda terrifying experience. But it made me…grow up. And I think, maybe, it made me a better person. Or at least, a more honest one.

So yeah. That's what I learned. It wasn't a fun learning experience, but it was a necessary one. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the morning sickness. Okay, maybe I'd trade the morning sickness.

Ugh, okay, talking about Vanessa and Mark…it’s still kinda weird, even now. It wasn’t like, instant best friends, you know? It started off…awkward. Really awkward. They were, like, *perfect*. Perfect house, perfect jobs, perfect everything. And me? I was just…me. A pregnant sixteen-year-old with a penchant for vintage clothes and a sarcastic attitude.

At first, it was all very formal. Meetings with social workers, talking about “best interests” and “open adoption” and all that stuff. They were nice, but they felt…distant. Like I was a case study or something. I was trying to be cool and detached, too, you know? Like, “Yeah, sure, you can have the baby. No big deal.” But it *was* a big deal.

But then, slowly, things started to shift. We started talking about stuff that wasn’t just about the baby. Vanessa told me about her struggles with infertility, and Mark talked about his love for music. I told them about my dad and Paulie Bleeker. We started to see each other as…people.

Vanessa, she was the one who really broke down the walls. She was so honest and vulnerable. She wasn’t trying to be perfect, she was just trying to be a good mom. And Mark, he was just…solid. Quietly supportive. He always knew how to make me laugh, even when I didn’t want to.

The more we talked, the more I realized they weren’t just taking a baby from me. They were giving a baby a *home*. A loving, stable home. And that made it a little easier.

By the end, it wasn’t about giving up a baby anymore. It was about choosing a family for him. And I knew, deep down, that Vanessa and Mark were the right family.

It’s still complicated, you know? I’ll always be his birth mom. And they’ll always be…well, they’re like family now. A weird, unconventional family. But family nonetheless. It wasn’t the relationship I expected, but it was the one I needed. And they needed too, I think. It wasn't about losing something, it was about gaining something different. And that's...okay. It's more than okay, actually.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It's not like I haven't thought about it, you know? A lot. Especially late at night when I can't sleep.

Regrets? Not exactly. I mean, I don't regret *giving* the baby up. That was the right decision. For me, for the baby, for Mark and Vanessa. It was the most selfless thing I could do, and I stand by that.

But…do I sometimes wonder what things would be like if I'd kept it? Yeah. Of course. I was sixteen. I had plans. I wanted to go to art school. And suddenly, everything was different.

I regret being so…flippant about it sometimes. I used humor as a shield, you know? To keep people at arm's length. And maybe I didn't always take it seriously enough. Maybe I should have allowed myself to feel more.

I also regret the way things went with Paul. It was…complicated. And I hurt him. And I think I hurt myself too. We were both just kids, trying to figure things out.

But regrets aren't really helpful, are they? They just make you dwell on the past. I learned a lot from that experience. I learned about responsibility, about love, about what it means to be a grown-up.

So, no, I don't regret the decision itself. But I do regret some of the ways I handled things. And I hope I'm a better person because of it.

It's just…it was a really big thing to go through. And it changed me. And sometimes, I still feel like I'm trying to figure out who I am now.



It's not something I talk about a lot. It's…personal. But you asked. And I try to be honest. Even when it's hard.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It still feels kinda raw, even after all this time.

It wasn't easy, you know? People think it was this super-noble, selfless thing, and it was, I guess. But it was also the hardest thing I've ever done. Like, ripping a piece of myself out and handing it to someone else.

For a long time, I felt…empty. And guilty. And just…lost. Like, who was I without being pregnant? Without being a mom? I spent a lot of time trying to figure that out.

It forced me to grow up, way faster than I was ready to. I had to deal with feelings I didn't even know I *had*. And I had to learn to be okay with not having control. Which, for someone like me, is a really big deal.

But it also made me stronger. I had to face some really tough stuff, and I came out on the other side…different. More resilient, I guess. And more aware of what I wanted out of life.

It definitely changed my perspective on things. I used to be so cynical and sarcastic, and I still am, don't get me wrong. But now I also see the good in people. And I appreciate the small things.

And it made me realize that family isn't just about blood. It's about love and support and connection. I have a really amazing family, and I'm grateful for them every day.

I still think about the baby, you know? And I hope she's happy. I hope she has a good life. And I hope she knows that I loved her, even though I couldn't keep her.

It wasn't a perfect situation, but it was the right one. And it shaped me into the person I am today. And honestly? I think I'm okay with that. It's still…complicated. But I'm okay.



It's not something I dwell on, but it's always there, you know? A part of my story. And I wouldn't trade it, even though it was the hardest thing I've ever done. It made me who I am.

Ugh, okay. This is…a big question. And it's not like I have all the answers, you know? I'm still figuring things out myself. But if another girl was, like, staring down the same barrel I was…here's what I'd say.

First of all: **it's okay to be scared.** Seriously. It's terrifying. Your whole life just gets flipped upside down, and you're suddenly dealing with a lot of stuff you weren't prepared for. Don't try to pretend you're not scared. Feel it. Then deal with it.

**Don't let anyone tell you what to do.** This is *your* decision. Your body, your life. Your parents, your boyfriend, your friends…they can offer advice, but ultimately, it's up to you. Don't let anyone pressure you into something you're not comfortable with.

**It's okay to choose adoption.** It's not giving up on your baby, it's giving them the best life possible. It's a really hard decision, but it can be the right one. And it doesn't mean you don't love them. It means you love them enough to want them to have everything they deserve.

**Find people you can trust.** Talk to someone. A friend, a family member, a counselor. Don't go through this alone. You need support. And don't be afraid to ask for help.

**Don't lose sight of yourself.** It's easy to get lost in all the chaos. Remember who you are, what you want, and what makes you happy. Don't let this define you. You're still you. You still have a future.

**It's gonna be messy.** There will be good days and bad days. There will be moments of joy and moments of heartbreak. It's not gonna be easy. But you're stronger than you think.

And finally: **it's okay to not have it all figured out.** Nobody does. Just take things one day at a time. And remember that you're not alone. There are other girls who have been through this, and they're here for you.



It's a tough road, but you can get through it. I did. And so can you. Just…be brave. And be kind to yourself.

Ugh, okay, so the whole blog thing? That wasn't exactly planned. It kinda…happened. It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "Oh, I *must* document my life for the internet!"

It started with Paul. He was, like, really into the idea of me keeping a journal. He thought it would be good for me to, you know, process everything. Which, fine. Whatever. But writing in a notebook felt…lonely. Like I was just talking to myself.

Then, my friend, Leah, she was all, "You should start a blog! You're so funny, you could totally make people laugh about this." And I was like, "Laugh about being pregnant? Are you kidding me?" But she kept pushing.

Honestly, I think I did it because I was feeling so…isolated. Everyone else was talking about college applications and prom and stuff, and I was over here dealing with morning sickness and doctor's appointments. It felt like I was living in a different world.

The blog was a way to connect with people who might be going through something similar. And it was a way to be honest about how I was feeling, without having to explain it to everyone I knew in real life. It was easier to be vulnerable online, I guess.

Plus, it was a good outlet for my sarcasm. I mean, let's be real, I needed a place to vent. And people actually *read* it! Which was kinda weird, but also kinda cool.

So yeah, that's how it started. It wasn't about being an "influencer" or anything. It was just about trying to make sense of my life, and maybe making a few people laugh along the way. It was a way to feel less alone. And honestly, it ended up being a really good thing.

Ugh. Okay, deep question. Like, really deep. It wasn't just about the baby, you know? It was about…everything.

The biggest lesson? Hmm. It wasn't about responsibility, though everyone kept hammering that one home. It wasn't even about giving a kid up for adoption, though that was a huge part of it.

It was about realizing that life doesn't go according to plan. Like, *ever*. You can have all these ideas about who you are and what you want, and then BAM! Something happens that completely throws everything off course. And you have to figure out how to deal with it.

Before, I thought I had it all figured out. I was gonna go to college, become a writer, move to New York…and then this happened. And it forced me to grow up, like, *fast*.

I learned that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be scared and confused. And it's okay to ask for help. I definitely couldn't have done it alone.

But mostly, I learned that even when things are messy and complicated and totally unexpected, there can still be something beautiful in it. Giving Mark and Vanessa the baby wasn't sad, it was…right. And knowing that she's gonna have a good life, that's what matters.

So yeah. Life is unpredictable. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just roll with it. And maybe eat a pop-tart while you're doing it. Because honestly, pop-tarts make everything better.

Ugh. Okay. Look. This is…it’s a lot. And it totally sucks that you’re dealing with this right now. Seriously. It’s not fair.

First of all, breathe. Just…breathe. It feels like the world is ending, I know. Like everything is spinning out of control. But it’s not. It’s just…complicated.

Don’t let anyone tell you what to do. Your parents, your boyfriend, your friends…they all have opinions, and they all think they know what’s best. But this is *your* decision. And it’s okay to take your time figuring it out.

There are options. And they’re all valid. Keeping it, adoption, whatever. Don’t let anyone shame you for what you choose. It’s your body, your life, your call.

If you’re thinking about adoption, it’s not giving up. It’s…it’s choosing a life for the baby where you can’t give it the life it deserves right now. It’s a really brave thing to do. And it doesn’t mean you don’t care. It means you *do* care enough to want what’s best.

Talk to someone. A friend, a counselor, a family member…someone you trust. Don’t go through this alone. It’s too much to handle by yourself.

And honestly? It’s okay to be scared. It’s okay to be confused. It’s okay to be angry. It’s okay to feel all the things. Just…don’t let those feelings paralyze you.

You’re stronger than you think. You’ll get through this. And whatever you decide, I believe in you. Seriously. You got this.

And if you need someone to just…listen, I’m here. Even if I’m just a voice in your head. Just…don’t give up on yourself. Okay?

Ugh, okay, don't make me get all mushy. It's weird to even *think* about a kid of my own, you know? But if I had to…if I had to picture it…

It's not about, like, them being a doctor or a lawyer or anything. Honestly, that sounds kinda boring. And stressful. I don't want to put a bunch of pressure on them.

My ideal vision? It's just…for them to be happy. Seriously. Genuinely, authentically happy. And to figure out what makes *them* tick. Not what I want them to be, not what society expects them to be, but what *they* want.

I want them to be kind. To be a good person. To stand up for what they believe in, even if it's unpopular. And to not be afraid to be themselves. Even if "themselves" is a little weird. Because weird is good. Weird is interesting.

I want them to have a good sense of humor. To be able to laugh at themselves and at the world. And to not take things too seriously. Life is too short to be serious all the time.

I want them to be independent. To be able to think for themselves and make their own decisions. And to not rely on anyone else to make them happy.

And I want them to have a really good taste in music. That's important.

Basically, I just want them to be a decent human being who's comfortable in their own skin and who's doing something they love. That's it. That's all I want.

It's not about achievements or accolades or anything like that. It's about being a good person and living a good life. And if they can do that, then I'll be happy. Even if they end up being a professional mime. (Okay, maybe not a mime. But you get the idea.)



Ugh, I'm getting all emotional now. I need a snack. And maybe some music. The Moldy Peaches always make things better.

Ugh, okay, seriously? People think we're just…dumb. Like, we didn't *think* this through. Like we just woke up one morning and were all, "Oh, a baby! How fun!" It's so insulting.

It's not about intelligence. It's about being young and, honestly, kinda clueless about life in general. Everyone makes mistakes, okay? And sometimes those mistakes involve, you know, not using protection. It doesn't make us stupid, it makes us human.

People assume we're all just trying to trap some guy or that we're looking for attention. That's just…not true. It's complicated. There are a million reasons why someone might get pregnant young, and most of them aren't about being malicious or irresponsible.

We're just trying to figure things out, like everyone else. Except we're doing it with a tiny human attached to us. And we're dealing with a lot of judgment and assumptions. 

I wish people would just see us as people. As young women who are trying to do the best we can in a really difficult situation. And stop acting like we're some kind of cautionary tale. It's just…annoying. And unhelpful.

Ugh. Okay, here we go. This is…still a thing I think about, you know? People always want to know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn't.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I, at sixteen, could give it…well, not everything. Not even close.

I was still in high school. My life was…messy. My mom's a good person, but she's kinda all over the place. And my dad…well, he's my dad. He'd have tried, but it wouldn't have been enough.

I wanted this kid to have a stable home, a loving family, opportunities I just couldn't provide. Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were ready. They *wanted* this. They had a house with a yard, and savings, and a plan. I didn't have any of that.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about making a really hard choice for the best possible outcome. It was about being selfless, even though it felt like the most selfish thing I'd ever done.

It was about knowing my limits. And knowing that sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

It still stings, sometimes. But I don't regret it. I really don't. I wanted that kid to have a good life, and I think they will. And that's all that matters.

It wasn't about me not being a good mom. It was about knowing I wasn't ready to *be* a mom. Not then. Maybe someday. But not then.



It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple story with a happy ending. It's just…life. And sometimes, life is messy and hard and you have to make choices you don't want to make.

Ugh, okay, that's…still a little raw, honestly. It wasn't like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? It was way more complicated than that.

There were a lot of couples. A *lot*. And they all seemed…nice. Too nice, sometimes. Like they were trying too hard to be perfect. And that felt weird. Like they wanted a baby to *fix* something, instead of just…loving a baby.

Vanessa and Mark…they were different. They weren't trying to be perfect. They were just…real. They were kinda awkward, actually. Mark was super quiet and Vanessa talked a lot, but they just…clicked. With each other, and with me.

I met a lot of couples who had these perfectly decorated nurseries and talked about college funds and all that stuff. Vanessa and Mark? They hadn't even *started* on a nursery. They were more focused on, like, being good parents. And they admitted they were scared. They admitted they didn't know what they were doing.

And that's what got me. They weren't pretending. They were honest about wanting a family, but they weren't putting pressure on me or the baby. They just wanted to love it.

Vanessa, she…she understood. She understood that this wasn't easy for me. She didn't try to tell me how grateful I should be or anything. She just listened. And Mark, he was just…kind. He made me laugh, even when I didn't want to.

It wasn't a logical decision, okay? It was a gut feeling. I just…knew. They were the ones who would give my baby a good life. A loving life. A life where it would be wanted and cherished.

It still doesn't mean it was easy. It still kinda sucks, if I'm being honest. But knowing that my baby is with them…that makes it a little bit better. They're good people. And that's all that really matters.

Ugh, music? It was…everything. Seriously. Like, oxygen. It was how I processed everything, you know? All the weirdness and the awkwardness and the, like, existential dread of being a teenager.

It wasn't about just *liking* songs. It was about finding artists who understood. Who weren't afraid to be real. The Moldy Peaches were huge, obviously. Kimya Dawson just…gets it. She writes about stuff that feels messy and complicated and true. It was like she was reading my diary.

But it wasn't just them. I was all over the indie scene. Death Cab for Cutie, Bright Eyes, Belle & Sebastian…lots of sad, thoughtful stuff. It kinda matched my mood, I guess. I wasn't exactly a sunshine-and-rainbows kind of kid.

I made a *lot* of mix CDs. For Paul, mostly. And for Leah. It was my way of saying things I couldn't actually say out loud. Like, "Hey, I think you're cool, and I understand what you're going through." Or, "This song reminds me of that time we…" you know?

Music was also a way to escape. When things got too overwhelming, I'd just put on my headphones and tune everything out. It was my little bubble. My safe space.

It's funny, because I wasn't, like, a *musician* or anything. I can't play an instrument. But music was still a huge part of who I was. It helped me figure things out. It helped me feel less alone. It helped me survive high school.

Honestly, I don't know what I would have done without it. It was my soundtrack. And it still is, kinda. It's just…different now. More complicated. But still important.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a picnic, alright? Our town wasn't exactly overflowing with progressive thinkers. It was more of a "everyone knows everyone's business" kind of place. And suddenly, *my* business was everyone's business.

Honestly? I mostly just leaned into the awkwardness. I figured if I acted like it wasn't a big deal, maybe other people would stop treating it like one. Which, you know, is a totally flawed strategy, but it was what I had at the time.

A lot of it was just ignoring the whispers and the stares. Which is easier said than done, believe me. But I had Paul and Vanessa, and they were seriously my rocks. They didn't treat me like I was some kind of freak. They just…treated me like Juno. Which was all I really wanted.

My dad was…complicated. He was quiet about it at first, but he came around. He's a pretty stoic guy, so his support came in the form of making me grilled cheese sandwiches and just…being there. Which was enough.

And honestly, a lot of the people who were judging me were just…sad. They were stuck in their own little worlds, and they didn't know how to deal with something that challenged their beliefs. So I just tried to feel sorry for them, instead of getting angry.

I also found a weird kind of power in owning it. Like, yeah, I'm pregnant. So what? It doesn't define me. I'm still Juno. I still like music and movies and sarcastic comments. And I'm still going to finish high school.

It wasn't easy. There were definitely days when I just wanted to disappear. But I had people who loved me and supported me, and that made all the difference. And I learned that other people's opinions don't really matter, as long as you're true to yourself.

It's just…life, you know? It throws you curveballs. And sometimes, those curveballs are really, really big. But you just gotta swing anyway.



It's still kinda weird talking about it, honestly. But yeah. That's how I coped. Mostly by being stubbornly myself.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It's complicated.

Right after Paul…after the baby was born, it was…weird. Like, obviously. I mean, I knew it was what I wanted, what was best for the kid. But holding her, you know? That was…different than I expected. It wasn't this huge, dramatic, tear-filled goodbye like in the movies. It was…quiet. And sad. And also, kinda peaceful.

There was this weird mix of relief and grief. Relief that I'd done the right thing, that she was going to have a life with people who were ready for it. And grief that I wasn't going to be the one to give it to her.

I was really worried about Mark and Vanessa, you know? Like, were they gonna be good parents? Were they gonna love her the way she deserved? But they were amazing. They were so…prepared. And they just radiated this warmth and happiness. It made it easier.

It wasn't easy letting go, though. It felt like giving away a piece of myself. But I knew it wasn't *mine* to keep. It was hers. And she deserved the best.

I still think about her, obviously. A lot. I get updates from Vanessa, which is good. Pictures, little stories…it makes me feel connected. It doesn't make the sadness go away completely, but it makes it…bearable.

I don't regret my decision. Not for a second. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was also the right thing. And I think…I hope…that she knows that.

It's just…it's a part of my story now. A messy, complicated, beautiful part. And I'm okay with that. I think. Mostly. It still stings sometimes, you know? But it's a good sting. A reminder that even when things are hard, you can still make the right choice.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started. It was…a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a stumble through a minefield of hormones and weird cravings.

Physically? It was brutal. Morning sickness is a lie. It's all-day sickness. And it's not just throwing up. It's nausea, fatigue, food aversions…everything. I swear, the smell of bacon almost sent me running for the bathroom for like, three months. And then there's the bloating. Oh, the bloating. I looked like I'd swallowed a basketball.

And then your body just starts doing things you didn't even know it *could* do. Like, growing a whole human being. It's kinda freaky when you think about it. And uncomfortable. Really uncomfortable. Especially later on. Sleeping was impossible. Everything hurt.

Emotionally? That was even worse. One minute I was fine, the next I was crying over a commercial for dish soap. It was ridiculous. And the guilt! Oh, the guilt. I felt so unprepared and scared and…just overwhelmed. I was still a kid, you know? I wasn't supposed to be dealing with this.

I leaned on Paul a lot. He was…surprisingly good about it. And my dad, too. He was weirdly supportive, in his own dad way. And Bleeker, well, he just tried to make me laugh, which actually helped.

I also started seeing a therapist. It was…helpful. Talking about my feelings, even the messy ones, made things a little bit easier.

Because if I hadn't had that choice, my life would be completely different. And not in a good way.

Ugh, okay, that's…a big one. Seriously. It's like, everyone has an opinion on what you should do, who you should be, what you should want. And it's *exhausting*. Especially when you're, like, figuring things out yourself.

Honestly? I don't always navigate it well. Sometimes I snap at people. Sometimes I just shut down. But I'm learning.

Here's what I've figured out so far:

*   **Realize You Can't Please Everyone:** This is the hardest part. Some people are just gonna judge you, no matter what you do. You gotta accept that. It's their problem, not yours.
*   **Know Your Own Values:** What's important to *you*? What do *you* believe in? If you know that, it's easier to ignore the noise.
*   **Surround Yourself with Good People:** People who support you, who get you, who don't try to change you. Those are the people you need in your corner.
*   **Don't Be Afraid to Be Different:** It's okay to not fit in. It's okay to have your own weird interests and opinions. That's what makes you *you*.
*   **Develop a Thick Skin:** It's not about becoming insensitive, it's about not letting other people's negativity get to you.
*   **It's Okay to Ask for Help:** Talk to someone you trust. Sometimes just venting can make a huge difference.
*   **Remember Your Worth:** You are valuable, even if other people don't see it.

And honestly? Sometimes you just gotta tell people to mind their own business. Politely, of course. Usually.

It's a process. It's not easy. But it's worth it. Because at the end of the day, you're the one who has to live with yourself. And you deserve to be happy and authentic.

So, yeah. That's my advice. Take it or leave it. I'm just a girl, standing in front of a question, asking you to not judge me too harshly.
