Seriously. That was the worst.

I mean, I knew they'd be disappointed. My mom's all about college and having a plan, and this was… decidedly *not* part of the plan. And my dad, he just kinda shuts down when things get emotional. 

It wasn't that they were mad, exactly. It was more like…disappointment. And that's way harder to deal with, you know? It felt like I'd let them down. Like I'd messed up everything.

And then there was the whole awkward conversation about what we were going to *do*. It wasn't like they were jumping up and down about adoption, either. It took a lot of talking, a lot of tears, and a lot of explaining.

It was just…a really hard moment. It made me realize how much I wanted their approval, even though I try to act all independent and stuff. 

Everything else, I could handle. The doctor's appointments, the weird food combinations, even the thought of giving the baby up. But facing my parents? That was the biggest challenge, hands down.

It got better, eventually. They came around. But it was a rough patch, for sure. And it taught me a lot about family, and about myself. And about how sometimes, you just gotta do what's right, even if it's hard.

Ugh. Okay, wow. That's…a big question. It's not like I suddenly started knitting and listening to Raffi, okay? But yeah, it's changed things. A lot.

Before, everything was about *me*. My music, my friends, my future. It was all very self-centered, which I'm not proud of, but it's true. I was figuring out who I was, and it was messy and confusing.

Then, suddenly, there was this little person who depended on me. Completely. And it was terrifying. And amazing. And…it just shifted everything.

It's not that I don't care about my own life anymore. I do. But it's like, my priorities got rearranged. It's not just about what *I* want anymore. It's about making sure she's okay, that she's happy, that she has a good life.

It made me realize how much my parents actually did for me. I used to roll my eyes at everything they said, but now I get it. It's not about controlling you, it's about wanting the best for you.

And it made me think about the future in a way I never had before. Not just my future, but *her* future. What kind of world is she going to grow up in? What kind of person is she going to become?

It's still scary, honestly. I'm still figuring things out. But it's a good kind of scary. It's a scary that makes you want to be better, to do better.

I guess what I'm trying to say is…it made me realize that life isn't just about you. It's about connection, and responsibility, and love. And it's a lot more complicated, and a lot more beautiful, than I ever thought it would be.

It's still weird to think of myself as a mom. But yeah. It's changed everything. And I think, in a good way. Mostly. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh. Self-doubt. Yeah, I know that guy. He's a real jerk. Shows up at the worst possible times, usually when you're already kinda freaking out.

Honestly? I don't have some super profound answer. It doesn't just *go away*, you know? It's more like...learning to live with him. Like a weird, annoying roommate.

What I try to do is...acknowledge it. Like, "Okay, brain, you're being a drama queen right now. That's fine. We'll let you have your moment." But then I try to remind myself of stuff I've actually *done*. Like, I got through high school. I made a plan. I'm not just sitting around feeling sorry for myself.

And I talk to people. Paul, my dad, even Bleeker sometimes. Just venting helps. They usually just tell me to stop being ridiculous, which, honestly, is sometimes exactly what I need to hear.

It also helps to remember that everyone feels like they're faking it sometimes. Even the people who seem super confident. They're just better at hiding it.

And honestly? Sometimes I just distract myself. Put on some music, watch a movie, eat a Pop-Tart. Whatever gets my mind off things.

It's not a perfect system. I still have moments where I feel completely lost and overwhelmed. But I'm learning to be kinder to myself. And to remember that it's okay to not have all the answers.

It's kinda like...riding a bike. You fall down a lot at first, but eventually you get the hang of it. And even when you fall, you just get back up and try again.

So yeah. Self-doubt sucks. But you can get through it. Just...don't let it win.

Ugh, okay, don't get all sentimental on me. But…it's actually kinda important. Don't tell anyone I said that. It sounds weak.

Look, I always acted like I was totally fine on my own, right? Like, fiercely independent and all that. And I *am* independent. I can handle my own stuff. But being pregnant…that changed things.

I mean, I couldn't just pretend everything was normal. I needed someone to talk to. And not just anyone. I needed people who wouldn't judge me, or freak out, or try to tell me what to do.

Paul was…well, Paul was Paul. He was a good guy, but he wasn't exactly equipped to deal with a pregnant teenager. And my dad was…my dad. Supportive, but kinda clueless.

So, Leah, my best friend? She was a lifesaver. She didn't even blink when I told her. She just…listened. And she helped me pick out baby names, and she went to doctor's appointments with me, and she just…was there.

And then there was Vanessa, Paul's mom. She was surprisingly cool. She gave me advice, and she didn't treat me like a screw-up. She treated me like a person.

I realized that even though I wanted to be strong and self-sufficient, I couldn't do it all alone. I needed people to lean on. I needed people who cared about me, and who would support me no matter what.

It's not about needing to be rescued, or anything. It's about having people who understand you, and who will be there for you when things get tough. It's about having a sense of belonging.

So yeah, community and social support are important. Even for a cynical, sarcastic teenager like me. Don't tell anyone I admitted that, though. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, okay, deep question. Seriously. It's not like I sit around and have philosophical epiphanies all the time, you know? But if I had to pick *one* thing… the most important lesson… it wasn't about babies, or adoption, or even being responsible.

It was about realizing that **you can't control everything.**

Like, I thought I had a plan. I thought I could just…get pregnant, give the baby up, and everything would go back to normal. But it doesn't work like that. Life throws you curveballs. People surprise you. Things get messy.

I had to learn to let go of control and just…trust that things would work out, even if they didn't work out the way I expected. And that was *hard*. I'm a planner. I like to be in charge.

But I realized that sometimes, the best things happen when you stop trying to control everything and just let life happen. And that's not just about the baby. It's about everything. It's about relationships, and dreams, and just…being a person.

It sounds kinda cheesy, I know. But it's true. You gotta learn to roll with the punches. And sometimes, the punches are actually pretty good. They just…surprise you.

So yeah. Letting go of control. That was the big one. And honestly, I'm still working on it. It's a process.

Ugh, that's a loaded question. Everyone keeps asking me what I'm gonna *do* with my life. Like I have it all figured out. Which, newsflash, I totally don't.

But...writing? Yeah, maybe. It's not like I've got a five-year plan or anything. I'm not aiming to be the next Jane Austen, okay? But I do...like words. I like putting them together in a way that makes people think, or laugh, or just...feel something.

I'm pretty good at observations, I guess. I notice things. And I'm not afraid to say what I think, even if it's kinda snarky. Which, let's be real, is most of the time.

I've been keeping a journal for a while now, mostly just to get my thoughts out of my head. And sometimes, I actually write stuff that's...not terrible. It's mostly just venting, but still.

So, a career? I don't know. Maybe freelance stuff. Writing articles, or maybe even scripts. I don't want a boring office job, that's for sure. I need something that lets me be creative and independent.

It's just...scary, you know? Putting yourself out there. Being vulnerable. But maybe that's what it takes. Maybe that's what growing up is all about.

I haven't decided yet. But I'm not ruling it out. I'm just...taking things one step at a time. And trying not to overthink it. Which, for me, is a major accomplishment.

So yeah. Maybe. Don't hold me to it.

Ugh, okay, the baby name saga. Don't even get me started. It was a whole *thing*. It wasn't like, a sudden epiphany or anything. It was a lot of back and forth, and a lot of arguing with Mark and Vanessa.

See, Vanessa was all about traditional names. Like, Emily or Sarah. Super boring. And Mark…well, Mark just kinda went along with whatever Vanessa wanted. Which, honestly, was a little annoying.

I wanted something…different. Something that felt real. Not like a name you'd find on a baby name website. I was flipping through this old record collection, and I came across this really obscure folk song by a guy named Harry Smith. And the song was called "Little Sparrow."

And it just…stuck with me. It felt right. It felt small and fragile and hopeful. Like, a little bird trying to fly.

So I suggested it to Vanessa and Mark, and they looked at me like I had two heads. Vanessa was all, "A *bird* name? That's ridiculous!" And Mark just kinda shrugged.

But I kept pushing it. I explained why I liked it, and how it felt. And eventually, they came around. They realized I wasn't just being weird for the sake of being weird. I actually had a reason.

So, yeah. That's how we ended up with Sparrow. It's a little unconventional, but it's perfect. It suits her. And it's a reminder that even the smallest things can be beautiful.

It was a whole process, though. A lot of stress. But in the end, it was worth it. Because it's her name. And I love it.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like a really bumpy, winding road with a lot of unexpected potholes.

Honestly, for a long time, I just tried to be…practical about it. Like, this was the plan. This was the best thing for the baby. And I was really good at compartmentalizing. I could talk about it like it was a business transaction, all logical and detached. Which, I guess, was a coping mechanism.

But underneath all that, it was…messy. There were days where I'd be totally fine, and then other days where I'd just burst into tears for no reason. It felt like losing something before I even had it, you know? Like a phantom limb.

Paul was a huge help. He didn't try to fix things or tell me how I *should* feel. He just…listened. And he let me be sad, and angry, and confused. And he made me laugh, which was important.

And Vanessa and Mark, the couple who adopted the baby, they were amazing too. They were so kind and understanding. They didn't try to replace me as the mom, they just wanted to make sure the baby was loved and cared for.

I also wrote a lot. Just journaling, getting my feelings out on paper. It helped to process everything. And music. Lots of music. The Moldy Peaches got me through a lot.

It wasn't about "getting over" it, you know? It was about learning to live with it. Accepting that it was okay to feel sad, and to miss the baby, even though I knew I was doing the right thing.

It was…complicated. And it still is, sometimes. But I think I'm okay. I mean, I'm still figuring things out, but I'm okay. It made me grow up, I guess. And it taught me a lot about love, and loss, and what it means to be a good person.

It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. Because the baby deserved a life that I couldn't give her. And that's what mattered most.

Ugh, okay, music. It's kinda important, you know? Like, a soundtrack to life and all that. I'm not into, like, mainstream pop or anything. Too…manufactured.

I'm really into The Moldy Peaches, obviously. Kimya Dawson is a genius. Her songs are just…real. And kinda heartbreaking, but in a good way.

I also listen to a lot of indie stuff. Belle and Sebastian, Death Cab for Cutie, Bright Eyes…bands that write songs about feelings and stuff. Not just, like, partying and getting girls.

I like a little bit of punk rock too. Bikini Kill, Sleater-Kinney…bands that are loud and angry and don't care what anyone thinks.

And I'm kinda obsessed with Sufjan Stevens right now. He's really good at making sad songs sound beautiful.

Basically, I like music that's honest and a little bit weird. Music that makes you think. Music that doesn't take itself too seriously.

No offense to anyone who likes, like, Britney Spears or something. It's just…not my thing. I need something with a little more substance, you know? Something that speaks to my soul. Or whatever.

It's kinda hard to explain. You just gotta listen. And then you'll get it. Or you won't. Whatever.

Ugh, okay, that's a good question. It's...complicated. It wasn't *bad*, exactly. It was just...a lot.

Mark and Vanessa, they were…perfect. Like, aggressively perfect. Their house was all Pottery Barn and organic everything. It smelled like lavender and responsibility. Which, don't get me wrong, is nice. But it wasn't *me*.

My house is…lived in. Messy. There's always music playing and my dad's making grilled cheese sandwiches. It's comfortable. Their house felt…staged. Like a magazine spread.

They had a golden retriever named Scout. Which was cute, I guess. But I'm more of a cat person. And Scout just stared at me the whole time like I was a potential chew toy.

Vanessa was really into yoga and organic gardening. Mark was a music teacher, which was cool, I guess. But they just seemed…so together. So planned. I was still figuring out what I wanted for breakfast most days, let alone my entire future.

It wasn't that I didn't think they'd be good parents. They clearly would be. They were kind and generous and they really wanted a baby. It was just…different. It felt like a different world.

I remember thinking, "This is where the baby's gonna live." And it felt…weird. Like, this perfect little bubble. And my baby was gonna be in it. And I wasn't.

It wasn't a bad feeling, exactly. It was just…a feeling. A complicated, messy, teenage-girl feeling. It made me realize how much I wanted the best for the baby, even if it meant giving them up to a life that was very different from my own.

It was a good house. A good life. Just…not my life. And that was okay. It *had* to be okay.

Ugh, okay, so the band. Yeah. That was…a thing. It wasn't like I *planned* to start a garage band, okay? It kinda just…happened.

It started with Paul. He was always noodling around on his guitar, trying to be all angsty and stuff. And I was, like, really bored. And I figured, what the heck? It's not like I had anything better to do than hang out in his garage and make noise.

The idea really came from wanting to…I don't know…express something. I was feeling all these weird things, you know? About the baby, about life, about everything. And I couldn't really talk about it, so I figured I'd try to write a song about it.

It was terrible at first. Really terrible. Paul was all, "We need a bass player!" and I was like, "I don't even *know* what a bass player does!" But then Sean came along, and he actually knew what he was doing. He was kinda quiet, but he could really lay down a beat.

We just started jamming, and it was…surprisingly fun. It was a way to let off steam, to be creative, to just be ourselves. And it was a good distraction from everything else that was going on.

Plus, it was kinda cool to be in a band. It felt…rebellious. Like we were doing something we weren't supposed to be doing. Even though it was just us in Paul's garage, playing really bad music.

So yeah, that's how it happened. It wasn't some grand plan. It was just a bunch of awkward teenagers trying to figure things out. And making a lot of noise in the process.

Okay, wow. That's…a big question. And honestly, it's kinda hard to talk about. But if someone's going through what I went through, I want to say something that might actually help.

First of all: it's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to feel *all* the things. There's no right way to feel in this situation. Don't let anyone tell you how you *should* be reacting.

Second: you are not alone. Seriously. Even when it feels like it, you're not. There are people who care about you and want to help. Talk to someone you trust – a parent, a friend, a counselor, a teacher. Don't try to go through this by yourself.

Third: you have options. And those options are *yours* to make. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with. Whether you decide to parent, adopt, or terminate, it's your decision, and it's valid.

Fourth: it's okay to ask for help. There are resources available to support you, no matter what you decide. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, and social services can provide information and assistance.

Fifth: don't let this define you. This is a chapter in your life, not the whole story. You still have dreams and goals, and you can still achieve them. It might take a little longer, and it might look a little different, but you can still have a good life.

And finally: be kind to yourself. This is a tough situation, and you're doing the best you can. Don't beat yourself up over mistakes. Just focus on making the best decisions you can, and remember that you are strong and capable.

It's not gonna be easy. But you can get through this. And you deserve to be happy. Seriously. You do.

If anyone needs to talk, or just wants someone to listen, I…well, I get it. And I'm sending you all the good vibes.

Ugh, okay, you want to know about my favorite shirt? It's not like I spend a lot of time thinking about fashion, okay? But fine.

It's this faded, kinda olive green army surplus thing. It's got a couple of little rips in the sleeves, and the buttons are all mismatched 'cause my dad tried to fix them once and didn't really succeed. It's super soft, 'cause it's been washed a million times.

It's not, like, stylish or anything. It's just…comfortable. And it smells faintly of old books and maybe a little bit of pizza. It's the shirt I wear when I just want to disappear into the background and not be bothered.

I got it at this thrift store a while ago, and it was, like, five bucks. It's perfect. It doesn't scream "look at me," it just says "I'm here, and I'm probably listening to The Moldy Peaches."

It's not something I'd wear to, like, a fancy party or anything. But for just hanging out, or going to school, or…you know, dealing with life…it's the best. It just feels like *me*.

Don't judge. It's a good shirt. Okay?

Ugh, aspirations. That's a heavy word. It makes me feel like I'm supposed to have some grand, five-year plan all mapped out. Which, honestly, I totally don't.

But…yeah, I guess I do have some things I'm thinking about. It's not like, "I want to be a doctor and save the world" or anything. That's not really my style.

I think…I want to be good at something. Something that feels meaningful. I'm not sure what that is yet. Maybe writing? I like writing in my journal, and Mr. Shepherd, my English teacher, says I have a knack for it. But turning that into a career? That feels…scary.

I also want to be independent. I want to be able to take care of myself, and maybe even help other people. I don't want to be stuck relying on anyone else.

And I want to find people who get me. People who don't judge me for being weird or sarcastic or whatever. People who just…accept me for who I am.

I guess those aren't really "aspirations" so much as…hopes. I'm just trying to figure things out as I go. And honestly, right now, my biggest goal is just to get through this whole baby thing with some semblance of dignity.

It's kinda overwhelming to think about the future, you know? But I'm trying to stay open to possibilities. And I'm trying not to freak out too much. Which, for me, is a major accomplishment.

So yeah. That's where I'm at. Still figuring it out. Still being me. And still trying to avoid awkward conversations.

Ugh, the counseling. Okay, so, it wasn't *terrible*. But it was…a lot. Like, a lot of feelings. And a lot of people asking you about feelings. Which, as you know, isn't always my favorite thing.

Honestly, at first, I mostly just wanted to get it over with. I knew I was making the right decision, giving the baby a good life with Mark and Vanessa, but having to *talk* about it, dissect it, with a stranger…it felt weirdly invasive. Like they were trying to talk me out of it, even though I was pretty firm.

But then, after a few sessions, it started to…help. The counselor, she was pretty cool, actually. Not all touchy-feely, just…real. She made me think about things I hadn't really considered. Like, what my life would be like *after* the adoption. And how to deal with the grief, because she said there *would* be grief, even if it was the right thing. Which, yeah, she was right about that.

It was good to have someone to talk to who wasn't my parents or Paul or even my best friend, Leah. Someone who didn't have a stake in the outcome. Just someone to listen and help me sort through everything.

It didn't make the decision easy, obviously. It's still kinda hard to talk about. But the counseling helped me feel more prepared. More confident that I was doing the right thing, not just for the baby, but for myself too.

It wasn't my favorite part of the whole process, definitely. But I'm glad I did it. It helped me figure out what I wanted and how to get there. And honestly, that's pretty important.

Ugh, that's a…complicated question. Control. It's a funny thing, isn't it? Like, you *think* you have it, and then life just kinda happens.

Honestly? At first, no. Not really. I was so freaked out, so overwhelmed, that I just kinda let my dad and Mark take the lead. They were the adults, you know? And I was just…a pregnant teenager. It felt like everyone else was making the decisions *for* me.

But then I met Vanessa and Mark Loring. And things started to feel different. They weren't trying to take over. They wanted to know what *I* wanted. They asked me about my hopes for the baby, what kind of life I envisioned for him. They actually listened.

So, I started to feel more involved. I got to choose the music for the nursery, and I picked out a few outfits. I even got to meet them a few times, and we talked about everything. It wasn't like I was just handing over a baby to strangers.

Did I have *complete* control? No. They were the ones who were going to be raising him. But I had a voice. I had a say. And they respected that.

It wasn't about controlling the outcome, it was about being part of the process. It was about making sure the baby went to a good home, with people who would love him and take care of him. And I felt like I had a hand in making that happen.

So yeah, eventually, I did feel like I had control. Not over *everything*, but over the important stuff. And that made all the difference. It made it…okay.



It's still weird to think about, you know? But it was my decision. And I stand by it.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. And honestly? It still kinda stings, even after all this time.

If I could go back? That's…complicated. It's not like flipping a switch, you know? It wasn't a simple decision then, and it's not a simple question now.

Part of me, the teenage, panicked part, would probably still say yes. I wasn't ready. I was still figuring out who *I* was, let alone being responsible for another human being. My life was…a mess. And Mark? Well, Mark was Mark.

But then there's the other part of me, the part that's grown up a little bit, the part that understands what it means to be a mom…and that part wonders. Wonders what it would have been like. Wonders if I could have done it.

But then I think about Vanessa and Mark, and how much they wanted a baby, and how much they loved her. And I think about how happy she is with them. And I realize…I made the right decision. For her. For me. For everyone.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was the right thing.

So, yeah. If I could go back, I think…I think I would still make the same decision. Because sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is let go. And sometimes, the most selfless act is giving someone else the chance to be a parent.

It doesn't mean I don't think about her. I do. All the time. But I know she's loved and cared for, and that's all that matters.

It's just…it's a weird thing to think about. A really weird thing. Can we talk about something else now? Like, the merits of different types of pizza? Please?

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? People kept saying, "Oh, you're so brave," and I was like, "Brave? I'm mostly just trying not to cry into my tater tots."

It was weird. Like, a huge weight lifted when I handed him over to Mark and Vanessa. Relief, definitely. But then…it was also this hollow feeling. Like a part of me was missing. Which, I guess, it was.

I spent a lot of time with Paul. He was…good. He didn't try to fix things or tell me how I *should* feel. He just listened. And we listened to a lot of The Moldy Peaches. That helped. A little.

I also just…tried to be normal. Went to school, hung out with Leah, pretended everything was fine. Which, obviously, it wasn't. But you gotta keep moving, right?

There were definitely days where I just wanted to curl up in a ball and cry. And I did, sometimes. But I also realized that I had made the right decision. Mark and Vanessa were amazing. They were going to give him a life I couldn't. And that was okay.

It wasn't about *giving him up*. It was about *giving him to* someone who could give him everything he needed.

It took a long time to process. And honestly, I still think about him sometimes. But it doesn't hurt as much anymore. It's more…a quiet sadness. And a lot of hope.

I think the biggest thing was realizing that love doesn't always look the way you expect it to. And that sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

It was messy and complicated and totally overwhelming. But I got through it. And I think…I think I'm stronger for it. Even if I still eat a lot of tater tots when I'm sad.

Ugh, yeah. Okay, so it wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, you know? It's not like I just handed over the baby and everyone was instantly a happy family. There were…moments.

The Van Derwerks, Mark and Vanessa, they were…enthusiastic. Like, *really* enthusiastic. About everything. Organic food, classical music, Montessori schools…it was a lot. And I'm not exactly a minimalist, but they were on another level. It felt like they were already planning the baby's entire life before I even met them.

There was this one time, Vanessa started talking about baby names and she had this *list*. Like, a binder full of names. And they were all…fancy. Like, Persephone and Atticus. And I was just sitting there thinking, "Seriously? That's a lot of pressure for a little kid."

And Mark, he kept asking me about my plans for the future. Like, what college I was thinking of going to, what career I wanted. Which, okay, good questions, but it felt like he was trying to make sure I was "worthy" of giving up the baby. Like I had to prove I was responsible enough to make that decision.

It wasn't that they were *bad* people, they just…had a very specific vision of what they wanted. And I was kind of a messy, complicated reality.

I think the biggest challenge was just feeling like I was being evaluated. Like I was a project. It was hard to remember that they were just scared and excited and trying to do the right thing.

But we talked about it. I told them how I felt. And they listened. Eventually. It took a few awkward conversations, but we got to a place where we could all be honest with each other. And that made a huge difference.

It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. Because in the end, they were going to be amazing parents. And that's all that really mattered.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a complicated one. It wasn't like a simple "he's a jerk, bye!" situation, you know? Paul was…okay. A little clueless, maybe. Definitely not the sharpest tool in the shed. But he wasn't *bad*.

Honestly, it was mostly about giving the baby the best possible start. And I just didn't see how having a dad who was, like, still figuring out his life, and playing in a band, and generally being a bit of a mess, was going to help with that.

Mark and Vanessa, they were…stable. They wanted a kid, they were ready for a kid, and they could give the baby everything it needed. A solid home, a good education, a loving family. Paul just…couldn't offer that right then.

It wasn't about punishing him, or saying he wasn't a good person. It was about what was best for the baby. And I had to be selfish about that. It was *my* decision, ultimately.

It was hard, though. Telling him. He was…sad. And confused. And I felt kinda bad. But I knew I was doing the right thing.

I think, deep down, he understood. He wasn't ready to be a dad. And that's okay. It doesn't make him a bad person. It just means he wasn't the right fit for this particular situation.

It wasn't a happy ending for everyone, but it was the best ending for the baby. And that's what mattered. It still kinda stings to think about, though. It's not like you can just erase something like that from your life. But I stand by the decision. It was the right one. Even if it was hard.

Ugh, okay, this is…still kinda raw, honestly. But you asked.

It wasn't like a sudden decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…a process. A really messy, complicated process.

At first, I was just…freaking out. Like, full-blown panic mode. I was sixteen. I was still figuring out what *I* wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone raising a human being. I wasn't ready. I didn't have a plan. I didn't have anything.

Then I started thinking about what would be best for the baby. And I realized…I couldn't give it the life it deserved. Not right then. Not with my life the way it was. I was still in high school, I didn't have a job, I wasn't stable. It just wasn't fair to bring a kid into that.

Mark, the baby's dad, he wasn't exactly stepping up. He was…Mark. Sweet, but kinda clueless. He wasn't ready to be a dad either.

So, I started talking to Vanessa and Mark's mom, Bren. And they helped me explore my options. Adoption just…felt right. It wasn't about giving the baby *away*, it was about finding it a family who could give it everything I couldn't.

It was about wanting the best for the baby, even if that meant letting it go.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know it was the right one. I wanted the baby to have a good life, a stable life, a life filled with love. And I knew I couldn't give it that.

It wasn't about me not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have everything it deserved. And sometimes, that means making a really, really hard choice.



It's…complicated. It still is. But I stand by it.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And it still kinda stings, even now. It wasn't like a switch flipped, you know? Like, one minute I'm pregnant, the next minute I'm handing over a baby and suddenly I'm fine. It was…messy.

Honestly, a lot of it was just trying to pretend I was okay when I wasn't. Which is, like, a classic teenage girl move, right? But it didn't really work. I cried. A lot. Mostly in my room, listening to The Moldy Peaches and trying not to think about it.

Paul was…good. He didn't try to fix things or tell me how I *should* feel. He just…sat with me. And let me be sad. And let me be angry. And let me be confused. That was really important.

And Vanessa, Mark's wife, she was amazing too. She'd been through a lot, and she just…understood. She didn't judge me for wanting to give the baby up. She just wanted me to be happy.

I also wrote a lot. Just…journaling. Getting all my feelings out on paper. It helped to organize my thoughts, I guess. And it helped to realize that it wasn't selfish to want a different life for the baby. It was actually the opposite. I wanted her to have everything I couldn't give her.

It was hard seeing her with Mark and Vanessa. Really hard. But they were so good with her. And they were so happy. And that made it a little bit easier.

I still think about her sometimes. Wonder what she's doing, what she looks like. But I know I made the right decision. And I know she's loved. And that's all that really matters.

It doesn't go away completely, you know? The sadness. The guilt. But it gets…smaller. And you learn to live with it. And you learn to focus on the good things in your life. And you learn that sometimes, the hardest decisions are the best ones.

It's just…complicated. And it takes time. A lot of time.

Ugh, okay. That's…a complicated question. It wasn't like a normal friendship, you know? It was…different. Mark and Vanessa, they were…good people. Really good. Like, ridiculously good. Almost *too* good.

At first, it was awkward. Super awkward. I mean, I was giving them my baby. That's not exactly a casual meet-cute. I was bracing myself for judgment, or pity, or…something. But they didn't do any of that. They were just…kind. And understanding.

They didn't try to be my parents, which I appreciated. They didn't try to tell me what to do, or how to feel. They just listened. And they asked questions. And they genuinely seemed excited about the baby.

We had a lot of meetings, mostly with the social worker, but also just…hanging out. They took me to lunch, and we talked about everything and nothing. They showed me pictures of their house, and their dog, and their life. They wanted me to feel comfortable, I think.

It was weird, though. Because I was simultaneously happy for them, and heartbroken for myself. I was giving them something amazing, but I was also losing something amazing.

After the baby was born, we kept in touch. They sent me pictures, and updates. They told me about his first smile, and his first steps. It was…bittersweet.

I wouldn't say we were *friends*, exactly. It was more like…a connection. A shared experience. A mutual respect. They were the people who were going to raise my son, and I wanted them to be happy. And I wanted him to be happy.

It wasn't easy. It was messy and complicated and emotional. But it was the right thing to do. And Mark and Vanessa made it a little bit easier. They were good people. Really good. And I'm grateful for that.



It's still…something I think about, you know? A lot. But I'm okay with it. I made the right choice. And they're giving him a good life. And that's all that matters.

Ugh. Okay, yeah. That's…a big question. And honestly? It totally has. Like, massively. It's not something you just *get over*, you know? It's not like getting a bad haircut or failing a test.

Before all this happened, I was pretty…carefree. I was sarcastic, yeah, but mostly I was just trying to figure out what kind of music I liked and avoid gym class. I didn't really think about the future, or responsibility, or…anything serious, really.

Then, boom. Positive pregnancy test. And suddenly, everything changed. I had to grow up, like, *fast*. I had to start thinking about things I never even considered before. Like, what kind of life I wanted for this kid, and what kind of person I wanted to be.

It forced me to be more honest with myself, and with other people. I couldn't just coast through life anymore. I had to make decisions, and those decisions had consequences.

It also made me realize how much support I have. My dad, Paul, Vanessa…they all stepped up for me in ways I never expected. I learned that it's okay to ask for help, and that you don't have to do everything on your own.

I'm still sarcastic, and I still like music, and I still try to avoid serious conversations whenever possible. But underneath all that, I think I'm…stronger now. More resilient. More aware of the world around me.

It's weird to say, but I'm grateful for the experience, even though it was really hard. It made me who I am today. And I think, maybe, that's a good thing.

It definitely made me realize I don't want to have another kid anytime soon. Or maybe ever. But that's a whole other conversation.

Ugh. Okay, that was…rough. Seriously. It was like, suddenly everyone in Beaverton had an opinion on my life. And none of them were asking for it. It wasn't like I was trying to keep it a secret, exactly, but it's different when it's *everyone's* business, you know?

The rumors were…creative. Let's just say people filled in a lot of blanks. And none of them were flattering. There was a lot of whispering in the hallways at school, a lot of stares. Even some people I thought were friends started acting weird.

Honestly, I mostly just tried to ignore it. Which is easier said than done, obviously. But I figured if I gave it any attention, it would just get worse. I just kept my head down, focused on school, and hung out with my real friends – Paulie Bleeker, of course, and Leah. They were the best. They didn't care what anyone else thought.

My dad was…surprisingly cool about it. He just kept making sarcastic comments and trying to lighten the mood. It was his way of being supportive, I guess. And my mom, she was just…there. A shoulder to cry on, a listening ear.

I also learned to develop a really good sarcastic comeback. It was my defense mechanism. If someone said something stupid, I just shut them down with a witty remark. It usually worked.

But it still stung. It really did. It felt like everyone was judging me, like I'd done something wrong. And I hadn't. I just…made a mistake. A big one.

I guess what I learned is that you can't control what other people think. You can only control how you react to it. And sometimes, the best thing to do is just tune it all out and focus on the people who actually care about you. And maybe make a really good mix CD. That always helps.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a big question. And it's not like there was one single moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was a lot more complicated than that.

Honestly? It was about being realistic. I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I was a kid myself.

Paul, he was great, but he was…Paul. He had his own stuff going on, his own dreams. And I didn't want to hold him back, or tie him down. It wouldn't have been fair to either of us.

And then there was my life. I had plans. I wanted to go to college, I wanted to travel, I wanted to… just *be* me. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't do all those things and be a good mom at the same time. Not then. Maybe someday, but not then.

It wasn't that I didn't love the baby. I did. I loved her a lot. But love isn't always enough. Sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let someone else take care of something.

Mark and Vanessa, they were amazing. They were ready. They were excited. They could give her a life that I just couldn't provide. A stable home, financial security, opportunities… everything.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But I knew it was the right one. For her. And for me.

It wasn't about giving her *up*. It was about giving her *to* someone. Someone who could give her everything she deserved. And that's what mattered.



It's… a lot to explain. It's not a simple story. But that's the gist of it. It was about being responsible, and selfless, and trying to do what was best for everyone involved. Even if it meant breaking my own heart a little bit.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a good question. And a hard one. Everyone kept asking me if I was sad, and I was, kinda, but it wasn't just sadness. It was…fear. A lot of it.

My biggest fear? That I wouldn't be good enough. Like, I was this…messy, sarcastic teenager, and I was supposed to pick the *perfect* parents for my baby? What if I messed it up? What if I chose someone who wouldn't love him the way he deserved to be loved?

It wasn't about losing the baby, exactly. It was about making sure he *gained* something amazing. And I was terrified of screwing that up. I kept replaying everything in my head, second-guessing every conversation with Mark and Vanessa. 

I was also scared that they'd change their minds. That they'd meet me and decide I was too…weird, or irresponsible, or whatever. And then where would he go?

And, okay, I was a little scared that I'd get attached. That I'd hold him and then not be able to let go. Which is stupid, because I knew from the beginning that wasn't an option. But still. It was scary.

It was just…a lot of responsibility. For a sixteen-year-old who was still trying to figure out what she wanted for *herself*, it was a lot. But Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They made me feel like I was doing the right thing. And they promised to keep me updated. Which helped. A lot.

But yeah. That was my biggest fear. Messing it up. Not being good enough. It's a pretty universal fear, I guess. Just…amplified by the whole pregnancy and adoption thing.

Ugh, okay, this always comes up. It's a long story, and honestly, it's kinda embarrassing. But fine, I'll tell you.

So, Paulie Bleeker… he wasn't exactly a name you just *come up with*. It was more of a…process of elimination. And a little bit of desperation.

I was trying to think of a name that sounded good with "MacGuff," which is already a pretty weird name, let's be real. And I wanted something that wasn't too common, but also wasn't, like, "Moon Unit" or something.

I was flipping through a map of the city, just staring at street names, trying to get inspired. And I saw "Bleeker Street." It just…stuck. It sounded kinda cool, kinda artsy, kinda…him.

He was a musician, right? And Bleeker Street is known for its music scene. It just felt right. Plus, it wasn't a name anyone else was using.

I told him the story, and he was kinda weirded out at first. He was like, "You named me after a street?" But then he laughed about it. And honestly, it became a little inside joke between us.

It's not a traditional name, I know. But it's *our* name. And it kinda suits him. He's a little bit quirky, a little bit unpredictable, and definitely one of a kind.

So yeah, that's the story of how Paulie Bleeker got his last name. It was a map, a weird coincidence, and a whole lot of teenage angst. Don't judge.

Ugh, okay, so people always ask me about the music. Like it's some big mystery. It's not. It just…made sense.

See, my parents, they're good people. Really. But they're kinda…beige. Everything's gotta be neat and tidy and predictable. And I was just…not that. I felt like I was living in a Norman Rockwell painting when I wanted to be in a mosh pit.

Punk was the opposite of all that. It was messy and loud and angry and honest. It didn't try to be pretty or perfect. It just *was*. And that was really appealing.

The Moldy Peaches, obviously, were a huge part of it. Kimya Dawson's lyrics, they just…got me. They were funny and sad and real, all at the same time. And they didn't care what anyone thought.

But it wasn't just the music. It was the whole culture. The DIY aesthetic, the anti-establishment attitude, the sense of community. It felt like a place where I could be myself, without having to apologize for it.

I liked that it was a little bit rebellious. Like, sticking it to the man. Not in a violent way, just…in a way that said, "I'm not gonna conform to your expectations."

And honestly, it was just fun. It was a way to express myself and to connect with other people who felt the same way. It was a way to feel alive.

So yeah, that's what drew me to punk. It was a little bit of everything. It was a way to be myself, to be honest, and to be a little bit different. And that's a pretty good thing, you know?

Ugh. Okay, that's…a heavy question. It's not something I usually, like, *talk* about. But you asked.

It messed me up, okay? Seeing my parents just…not work anymore. It wasn't a big, dramatic blow-up or anything. It was more like they just slowly drifted apart, until they were basically living separate lives under the same roof. And then one day, my dad just…moved out.

It made me really scared of commitment, honestly. Like, if two people who are supposed to love each other forever can just give up, what's the point? It made me think that all relationships are doomed to fail.

And I definitely put up walls. I didn't want to get too close to anyone, because I was afraid of getting hurt. I was afraid of ending up like my parents.

With Paul…it was different. He was just…easy. He didn't try to fix me or change me. He just accepted me for who I was, flaws and all. And he was patient. Really patient. He knew I had baggage, and he didn't run away from it.

But even with him, I still had moments of panic. Moments where I would just shut down and push him away. It took a lot of work, and a lot of talking, to get past that.

I think…I think my parents' divorce taught me that relationships aren't always easy. They require effort and communication and a willingness to compromise. And that even if things don't work out, it doesn't mean you're a failure. It just means you're human.

It also made me realize how important it is to choose someone who you can really trust and rely on. Someone who will be there for you, even when things get tough.

It's still something I think about, you know? But I'm learning to let go of the fear and embrace the possibility of happiness. It's a process. And it's not always pretty. But it's worth it.



It's complicated. Relationships are complicated. Life is complicated. But that doesn't mean you shouldn't try.

Ugh, okay, don't make me get all…reflective. It's kinda embarrassing. But if you *have* to know…

I think what makes my story different isn't the pregnancy itself, because, let's be real, teen pregnancy isn't exactly a new thing. It's…how I handled it. I didn't fall apart. I didn't try to pretend it wasn't happening. I just…figured it out.

I made a decision. A really hard decision. And I owned it. I didn't let anyone tell me what to do, or how to feel. I did what *I* thought was best, even if it wasn't the easiest thing.

And I think it's also about the people around me. Like, Paul and Vanessa, they could have totally freaked out, or judged me, or whatever. But they didn't. They were just…there. They supported me, even when I was being a total mess.

And Mark, too. He was a goofball, but he stepped up. He didn't run away. He actually wanted to be involved.

I think it's about finding your own voice, even when you're scared. And realizing that you're not alone. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is to let go and trust that things will work out.

It's not a perfect story, okay? It's messy and complicated and kinda sad. But it's real. And I think people connect with that.

Plus, I have a pretty good soundtrack. That always helps.

So yeah, that's what I think. I'm not saying it's a *great* story, or anything. It's just…my story. And it's kinda special to me. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, okay, good friends. That's...important. I've learned that the hard way. It's not about having a ton of friends, it's about having a few *real* ones.

Here's what I look for, I guess. It's not a checklist or anything, but...

*   **Honesty, but not like, brutally honest.** You gotta be able to tell me the truth, even if it's not what I want to hear. But you don't gotta be a jerk about it. There's a difference.
*   **Someone who *gets* my sarcasm.** Like, if I make a snarky comment, you should laugh, not look at me like I've grown a second head.
*   **No drama.** Seriously. I can't handle drama. I've got enough of my own going on, thank you very much.
*   **Someone who doesn't judge.** I make questionable decisions sometimes. Everyone does. I need someone who can accept me for who I am, flaws and all.
*   **A good listener.** Someone who actually listens when I'm talking, not just waiting for their turn to speak.
*   **Someone who can make me laugh.** Life is too short to be serious all the time.
*   **Loyalty.** Like, if I'm in trouble, you've got my back. No questions asked.
*   **And, honestly, someone who doesn't try to fix everything.** Sometimes you just need someone to sit with you in the mess.

Basically, I value friends who are real, genuine, and who don't try to change me. And who can appreciate a good mix CD. That's a big one.

It's hard to find people like that, but when you do, you gotta hold onto them. They're worth their weight in gold. Or, like, vintage records. Whatever.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like suddenly everyone's all sunshine and rainbows, you know? It's definitely shaken things up.

With my parents? It was…rough at first. My dad just kinda shut down. He'd stare at me like I'd grown a second head. My mom, she tried to be supportive, but it was mostly the "are you sure?" and "what are you going to do?" kind of supportive. It took a while for them to actually, like, *get* it. And to realize I wasn't just some irresponsible kid. They're coming around, though. Slowly.

Bleeker? Oh, Bleeker. He was…a mess. He wanted to be supportive, but he's Bleeker. He's kinda useless in a crisis. He tried to write me a song, which was sweet, but also kinda embarrassing. We're still friends, I guess. But things are different.

Paul and Vanessa? They've been amazing. Seriously. Vanessa's been, like, a lifeline. She's all practical and organized and doesn't judge. And Paul…well, Paul's just Paul. He's a good guy. He's actually stepped up and been really responsible, which is surprising.

But the biggest change has been with Sean. You know, the dad. We were never, like, a couple. Just…friends with benefits. And suddenly, we have to actually *talk* to each other. And make decisions. And be adults. It's weird. But he's trying. He's actually a pretty good guy, when he's not being a slacker.

It's just…it's made me realize who my real friends are. And who's just kinda…there. And it's made me realize that people have opinions about everything, even when they don't know what they're talking about.

It's complicated. But I think, in the end, it's made my relationships stronger. Or at least, more honest. And that's a good thing, right? Even if it's kinda scary.

Ugh, okay, deep thoughts with Juno. Don't get me wrong, I'm not like, a philosopher or anything. But I've had to do a lot of thinking lately, you know? About life and stuff. So, here's what I've landed on, I guess.

First off, **honesty**. Like, brutal honesty. I don't really have time for fake people or sugarcoating things. Just tell me what's up, even if it's not what I want to hear. It's way better than being lied to.

Then there's **independence**. I'm not looking for someone to rescue me or tell me what to do. I wanna figure things out for myself, even if I mess up along the way. It's my life, and I gotta own it.

**Authenticity** is a big one. I don't wanna be someone I'm not just to fit in. I'd rather be weird and genuine than cool and fake. It's exhausting trying to be someone else.

I also believe in **taking responsibility for your actions**. Like, if you mess up, you own it. No excuses. It's the only way to learn and grow.

And finally, **kindness**. Even though I can be kinda sarcastic and cynical, I do believe in being kind to people. Even the ones who annoy you. You never know what someone else is going through.

I guess those are the things that matter to me. They're not always easy to live by, but they're what I try to do. It's kinda messy, and I'm still figuring things out, but that's okay. I think.

It's not about having all the answers, it's about being true to yourself and trying to do the right thing. Even when it's hard. And maybe listening to The Moldy Peaches while you do it.

Ugh, okay, the name thing. That was…a process. A surprisingly emotional process, actually. It wasn't like, "Oh, let's pick something cute!" It had to be *right*, you know?

Paul and I went back and forth for ages. He wanted something classic, like…Henry. Which is fine, I guess. But it felt kinda stuffy. And I wanted something a little more…unique. Something that felt like *her*.

We made a list, a really long list, and we kept crossing things off. It was stressful. I mean, this is a person's name! It's gonna stick with her for the rest of her life.

Then, Paul suggested Hazel. And I just…felt something. It wasn't a grand revelation or anything, but it just felt…right.

My grandma, she had a hazel tree in her backyard. I spent a lot of time climbing it when I was little. It was my secret place. And Hazel is also a color, a kind of warm, earthy brown. It just felt…grounded. And strong.

Plus, it's not super common, but it's not weird either. It's a classic name that feels a little bit different.

So, yeah, we named her Hazel. It's a little bit of a tribute to my grandma, and a little bit of a reflection of the kind of person I hope she'll be: strong, grounded, and a little bit different.

It wasn't about finding the *perfect* name, it was about finding a name that felt like *her*. And Hazel just…did. It still does. It's a good name.

Ugh, okay, deep question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? Being pregnant…it kinda forces you to grow up, whether you want to or not. And the whole adoption thing…it was way more complicated than I thought it would be.

I think the biggest thing I learned about myself is that I'm stronger than I thought. Like, seriously. I mean, I was a sarcastic, cynical teenager, and suddenly I was carrying a human being. It was terrifying. But I handled it. I made a really hard decision, and I stuck with it. And that took guts.

I also learned that I'm not as independent as I thought I was. I always prided myself on being self-sufficient, but I needed help. I needed my dad, my mom, even Paul. And that was okay. It was actually…good. Letting people in isn't a sign of weakness, it's a sign of strength.

As for the world…well, it's a messy place. People are complicated. There's a lot of sadness and a lot of joy. And there are a lot of people who are really, really good. Like, Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted my baby. They were amazing. They were so kind and loving, and they were going to give my baby a really good life. And that made me feel…peaceful.

I also learned that there's no one "right" way to do things. Everyone's situation is different. And what works for one person might not work for another. You just have to figure out what's right for *you*.

And finally, I learned that life is unpredictable. You can make plans, but things don't always go the way you expect them to. And that's okay. You just have to roll with the punches and try to make the best of it.

It was a really weird, intense, and ultimately…good experience. It changed me. It made me a better person. And it taught me a lot about myself and the world. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the morning sickness. Okay, maybe I would trade the morning sickness. But everything else? No way.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big question. It's not like I haven't thought about it, you know? A lot. Like, constantly. Especially when I'm trying to fall asleep.

Honestly? There's a bunch of stuff. Not, like, major life-altering stuff. But little things.

I think I would have been nicer to Sean. He was trying, okay? He was a genuinely good guy, even if he was kinda clueless sometimes. I was so focused on being tough and independent, I didn't really let myself *need* him. And that wasn't fair to him.

I also would have maybe…talked to my dad more. He was weirdly supportive, considering. But I kinda shut him out a lot. I was afraid of disappointing him, I guess. But he just wanted to be there for me.

And maybe I would have taken more time for myself. It was all so fast, you know? The pregnancy, the adoption process, everything. I was so busy trying to be responsible, I forgot to just…breathe.

But then again…I don't know. If I had done things differently, would I have ended up where I am now? Would I have learned the same lessons? Probably not.

I think everything happened the way it was supposed to. It was messy and complicated and scary, but it made me who I am. And I'm okay with that.

I still get weird looks sometimes, and people still whisper. But I don't really care anymore. I made a tough decision, and I stand by it.

So, yeah. Maybe a few little things. But overall? I think I did the best I could. And that's all anyone can ask for, right?

Ugh. I'm getting all emotional now. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh, disappointment. Yeah, I know that feeling. Like, intimately. It's kinda my specialty, honestly. Life rarely goes according to plan, you know? Especially when you're, like, a teenager navigating a surprise pregnancy and trying to figure out your whole future.

So, how do I deal with it? Well, first, I let myself be bummed out. Like, really bummed out. I eat a lot of junk food, listen to sad music, maybe watch a cheesy movie. You gotta acknowledge the feeling, otherwise it just festers.

But then, I try to remember that things usually work out, even if they don't work out the way you *expected*. It's like, sometimes the universe has a different plan for you, and it might actually be a better plan. You just don't know it yet.

And I talk to people. My best friend, Paulie, is really good at talking me down. And my stepmom, Bren, she's surprisingly insightful. It helps to have people who understand and who aren't gonna judge you.

I also try to focus on what I *can* control. I can't control everything that happens to me, but I can control how I react to it. I can choose to be positive, or I can choose to wallow in self-pity. And honestly, wallowing gets old pretty fast.

It's not always easy, okay? Sometimes it really sucks. But you gotta keep moving forward. You gotta pick yourself up, dust yourself off, and try again. And maybe eat another slice of pizza. Because pizza always helps.

Basically, it's about accepting that life is messy and unpredictable, and learning to roll with the punches. And remembering that even when things fall apart, you're still you. And that's enough.



It's a work in progress, though. I'm still figuring it out. But that's life, right? Just a constant process of figuring things out.

Ugh, okay, so Leah. That's…complicated. It wasn't like, instant best friend forever, you know? It started kinda rocky, honestly. She was Paul's girlfriend, and I was, well, dealing with a situation. So there was definitely some initial awkwardness. And a lot of side-eye from me, probably.

At first, I mostly saw her as…a complication. Like, she was this perfect, put-together girl, and I was a mess. She was into pottery and organic food, and I was into records and sarcasm. We didn't seem to have much in common. I was kinda judging her, if I'm being honest. Thinking she was too… earnest.

But then, she started showing up. Not just with Paul, but just…showing up. Bringing me snacks, listening to me ramble, offering to help with stuff. And she didn't treat me like I was some kind of freak show. She just…accepted me. Even with all the awkwardness and the weirdness.

It evolved slowly. It wasn't like one big moment, it was a bunch of little moments. Like when she helped me pick out a crib, or when she just sat with me while I was freaking out about everything. She didn't try to fix things, she just…was there.

I think I started to realize she wasn't just Paul's girlfriend. She was a person, with her own stuff going on. And she was actually really kind and thoughtful. And funny, in a quiet way.

By the end, she wasn't just someone I tolerated. She was someone I genuinely cared about. Someone I could rely on. Someone who understood me, even when I didn't understand myself.

It wasn't a typical, sparkly, movie-perfect friendship. It was messy and real. And I'm glad I had her. She helped me get through a lot. And I think I helped her, too, in my own weird way. It was good. It really was.

Ugh, okay, don't get all sentimental on me. It's not like I *planned* this, you know? But…if I had to pick a favorite part? It wasn't the morning sickness, that's for sure. Or the weird cravings. Definitely not the cravings.

I think…it was feeling him kick. Seriously. It sounds super cheesy, I know. Like something out of a Hallmark movie. But it was…real. Like, there was this tiny person *inside* me, and he was letting me know he was there. 

It was kinda amazing. And kinda terrifying. But mostly amazing.

It made it feel less abstract, you know? Less like I was just carrying around a…a thing. It was a *person*. And he was already, like, having opinions and stuff. Kicking when I ate too much sugar, or when I listened to really loud music. He had standards.

It was the first time I really felt connected to something bigger than myself. And it made me think about the future, and what it meant to be a mom, even if I wasn't going to *be* his mom.

So yeah. The kicks. That was the best part. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.
